Official name: Consumer Literacy and Empowerment to Advance Responsible Navigation of Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: Consumers LEARN AI Act
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Commerce to develop a national strategy and conduct a public campaign in collaboration with federal, state, and industry partners to enhance AI consumer literacy and promote understanding of AI capabilities and limitations for informed decision making.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Commerce to develop a national strategy and and conduct a public service campaign to enhance artificial intelligence consumer literacy.

Requires the strategy to promote understanding of AI capabilities and limitations, and support informed decisions on AI use.

Instructs the Secretary to coordinate with various federal agencies, local governments, and private organizations to ensure comprehensive strategy development.

Requires the creation of specialized use cases for AI literacy in domains like healthcare, finance, and communication.
 
Mandates the dissemination of educational materials through multiple communication channels, including a dedicated website, and requires periodic updates to these materials.

Obliges the Government Accountability Office to report on existing federal AI literacy programs and the Secretary to annually report on the strategy's progress and effectiveness.

Authorizes necessary appropriations for fiscal years 2025 through 2034 to implement the Act's activities.

Official name: Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act
Casual name: Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a plan for identifying, integrating, and deploying advanced technologies, including AI, to enhance border security. Involves privacy impact assessments, CBP Innovation Teams, and collaboration with private and public sectors.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop and submit a plan within 180 days to identify, integrate, and deploy advanced technologies, including AI and machine learning, to enhance border security operations.

Mandates inclusion of information on how CBP utilizes its Innovation Teams and other mechanisms to achieve these goals.

Requires assessments of technology contributions, team compositions, and coordination efforts within CBP and DHS.

Identifies non-utilized technologies from other federal agencies that could enhance border security.

Includes an analysis of procurement authorities and whether additional ones are needed.

Demands explanations on scaling existing programs and descriptions of planned security technology programs with objectives, goals, and timelines.

Assesses the privacy and security impact on border communities and legacy technology phase-outs.

Requires coordination with DHS's Science and Technology Directorate to develop and incentivize new technologies.

Specifies metrics for evaluating effectiveness and identifies recent technological advancements in various surveillance and inspection technologies.

Authorizes CBP Innovation Teams to research and adapt commercial technologies, establishing procedures and strategic goals.

Requires annual reporting on Innovation Team activities, including successful technology transitions.

Official name: Google DeepMind Frontier Safety Framework Version 1.0
Casual name: Google DeepMind Frontier Safety Framework Version 1.0
Short summary: Establishes protocols for identifying and mitigating severe AI risks from Critical Capability Levels (CCLs) in domains like Autonomy, Biosecurity, Cybersecurity, and Machine Learning R&D. Implements security and deployment mitigations to manage risks, evolving with insights and future research.
Long summary:
Establishes protocols within the Frontier Safety Framework to address severe risks from future foundation models' capabilities.

Defines "Critical Capability Levels" (CCLs) to identify when AI models pose heightened risks, focusing initially on Autonomy, Biosecurity, Cybersecurity, and Machine Learning R&D.

Implements periodic evaluations to detect when models approach CCLs and articulates mitigation plans.

Proposes security mitigations to prevent model weight exfiltration and deployment mitigations to control access and expression of critical capabilities.

Outlines graded mitigation levels ranging from industry-standard controls to advanced protection environments.

Plans to implement the framework by early 2025 and expects it to evolve with emerging risks and insights.

Involves external parties to guide and inform the approach.

Commits to periodically reviewing and updating the framework as understanding of AI risks and benefits improves.

Official name: AI Advancement and Reliability Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Advancement and Reliability Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the Center for AI Advancement and Reliability to lead efforts in AI research and development, and the evaluation of AI systems' robustness, resilience, and safety.
Long summary:
Establishes the Center for AI Advancement and Reliability to ensure U.S. leadership in AI research, development, and evaluation.

Outlines activities of the Center including conducting measurement research to develop best practices for AI reliability and safety, evaluating AI capabilities and developing methods for risk management.

Mandates the Under Secretary of Commerce for Standards and Technology to coordinate with federal agencies in establishing the Center.

Creates a consortium of stakeholders to support the Center and the National Institute of Standards and Technology in AI-related activities.

Authorizes $10 million for fiscal year 2025 for the establishment of the Center.

Official name: Idaho House Bill 575
Casual name: Idaho HB 575 (Disclosing Explicit Synthetic Media)
Short summary: Criminalizes disclosing explicit synthetic media without consent if it causes distress or is intended to harass. Defines terms, provides penalties, and exemptions. Excludes certain services from liability unless they aid disclosure. Effective July 1, 2024.
Long summary:
Establishes the crime of disclosing explicit synthetic media without consent, intending to cause distress or obtain valuables, punishable as a misdemeanor or felony for repeat offenders.

Defines "explicit synthetic media" as AI-altered images or videos depicting sexual conduct involving identifiable individuals without their engagement.

Exempts disclosures for lawful purposes, such as criminal investigations, public interest reporting, scientific research, or legal proceedings.

Excludes liability for interactive computer services and telecommunications providers for third-party content, unless they intentionally aid disclosures.

Declares provisions severable, ensuring unaffected sections remain valid if parts are invalidated.

Declares an emergency and sets the effective date for July 1, 2024.

Official name: New York Senate Bill 1042
Casual name: New York SB 1042 (Unlawful Dissemination of Intimate Images)
Short summary: Amends the penal law to criminalize dissemination or publication of digitized intimate images without consent. Defines "digitization" as realistic alteration using images of another person or computer-generated images. Repeals subdivision 2-a of section 245.15.
Long summary:
Amends the penal law to include the unlawful dissemination or publication of intimate images created or altered by digitization.

Defines "digitization" as altering an image realistically using other persons' images or computer-generated images.

Requires intent to cause harm to the emotional, financial, or physical welfare of another person for the offense to occur.

Mandates that the actor knew or should have known that the person depicted did not consent to the dissemination or publication.

Repeals subdivision 2-a of section 245.15 of the penal law.

Specifies that the act takes effect on the sixtieth day after becoming law.

Official name: Washington Senate Bill 5152
Casual name: Washington SB 5152 (Synthetic Media)
Short summary: Defines "synthetic media" in political campaigns as manipulated media creating false impressions. Permits candidates to seek legal relief against such media use. Requires disclosure of manipulation. Holds sponsors liable, not media, unless disclosure is altered. Encourages prompt court rulings.
Long summary:
Defines "synthetic media" as manipulated images, audio, or video that create a false impression of a real individual's appearance, speech, or conduct.

Allows candidates to seek injunctive relief or damages if their appearance, speech, or conduct is altered using synthetic media in electioneering communications.

Requires disclosure for synthetic media, stating, "This (image/video/audio) has been manipulated," with specific guidelines for visibility and audibility.

Places the burden of proof on plaintiffs to demonstrate synthetic media use by clear and convincing evidence.

Encourages courts to expedite proceedings related to synthetic media disputes.

Holds sponsors, but not mediums, liable unless mediums alter content or remove required disclosures.

Exempts interactive computer services from being treated as publishers of third-party content, except under specific conditions.

Mandates the public disclosure commission to adopt rules supporting this chapter without constituting violations under existing campaign finance laws.

Official name: Improving Diagnosis in Medicine Act of 2024
Casual name: Improving Diagnosis in Medicine Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes a research program to improve diagnostic safety and quality, including integrating AI-enabled tools. Requires expert panel consultation for data needs, involving the Chief AI Officer. Forms an interagency council to enhance research, policy, and collaboration in diagnosis improvement.
Long summary:
Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a comprehensive research program on diagnostic safety and quality, focusing on reducing diagnostic errors and integrating AI tools.

Directs funding for new and existing research centers and mandates stakeholder engagement to enhance diagnostic quality and safety.

Requires the convening of an expert panel, including the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer, to recommend data types and sources for research improvement.

Establishes an Interagency Council on Improving Diagnosis in Health Care, including members from AI-related departments, to enhance diagnosis quality and identify research gaps.

Mandates the creation of a strategic federal plan to improve diagnosis, with updates and progress reports submitted biennially to Congress.

Authorizes appropriations for these initiatives from 2025 to 2029, ensuring sustained financial support for improving diagnostic practices and integrating AI solutions.

Official name: Nebraska L 1284 (Teacher Incentive Programs), Sec. 2.
Casual name: Nebraska L 1284 (Teacher Incentive Programs), Sec. 2.
Short summary: Creates the Dyslexia Research Grant Program for Nebraska businesses researching AI-based writing assistance for dyslexia. Limits total grants to $500,000 from the Education Future Fund. Requires compliance; misuse triggers legal action to recover funds. Allows State Board rulemaking.
Long summary:
Create the Dyslexia Research Grant Program, administered by the State Department of Education, to support research on AI-based writing assistance for individuals with dyslexia.

Allow privately owned businesses in Nebraska researching AI writing tools for dyslexia to apply for grants, using a prescribed form.

Limit the total grant awards to $500,000, intended to be funded by the Education Future Fund.

Require all grant funds to be used specifically for researching AI tools that use aggregate writing analytics to help develop literacy plans for dyslexic students.

Mandate notification of the Attorney General if grant funds are misused, prompting a civil action to recover funds, which are then credited back to the Education Future Fund.

Authorize the State Board of Education to adopt rules and regulations to implement the program.

Official name: Maryland House Bill 1128
Casual name: Maryland  H 1128  (Talent Innovation Program and Fund )
Short summary: Establishes the Talent Innovation Program to enhance AI job training using innovative financing. Creates a nonlapsing Talent Innovation Fund to support the program, including AI sector initiatives. Allows fund investments and requires annual reporting to government officials starting in 2025.
Long summary:
Establishes the Talent Innovation Program in the Maryland Department of Labor to increase access to high-quality job training, with a focus on industries such as artificial intelligence.

Creates the Talent Innovation Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund to support the program, including job training and talent financing mechanisms.

Requires the program to conduct pilots, research, and stakeholder engagement to develop sustainable talent financing approaches.

Mandates an initial pilot program focused on the cybersecurity sector to expand regional cyber ranges for job training.

Authorizes the Department to provide grants and funding to various entities and individuals for training and support services.

Directs the State Treasurer to invest the fund's money, with interest earnings credited to the fund.

Compels the Department to adopt regulations and report annually on program activities and fund utilization to state leadership.

Official name: ENFORCE Act
Casual name: ENFORCE Act
Short summary: Amends the Export Control Reform Act to prevent foreign adversaries from exploiting U.S. AI technologies. Defines "covered AI systems" posing national security risks. Grants the President authority to control activities related to these systems. Requires licenses for certain exports and related activities.
Long summary:
Amends the Export Control Reform Act of 2018 to prevent foreign adversaries from exploiting U.S. artificial intelligence and other critical technologies.

Defines "artificial intelligence" and "artificial intelligence system" as per the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020.

Specifies an interim and final definition of "covered artificial intelligence system," focusing on AI systems posing serious national security risks.

Authorizes the President to control the activities of U.S. persons related to critical AI systems and emerging technologies essential to national security.

Empowers the President to require U.S. persons to obtain licenses for exporting or transferring critical AI systems and technologies.

Amends the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to align with the updated export control provisions.

Official name: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review
Casual name: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review
Short summary: Requires agencies to use AI in retrospective reviews of regulations. Directs the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance on AI use for identifying obsolete or burdensome regulations. Mandates agency plans and implementation strategies for these AI-assisted reviews.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to report on the Federal Government's progress in making agency regulations available in machine-readable format within 180 days after enactment.

Mandates the OMB Director to issue guidance within 18 months on using technology, including AI, for efficient and accurate retrospective reviews of regulations.

Obliges agency heads to submit a detailed plan within two years for implementing OMB guidance on retrospective reviews, identifying regulations for review, and including necessary data and analysis.

Directs agency heads to implement the submitted plan within 180 days of submission, focusing on retrospective regulatory reviews.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
Casual name: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
Short summary: Requires the Election Assistance Commission to develop voluntary guidelines addressing AI use and risks in elections, emphasizing AI's role in election disinformation. Directs a study on AI's impact in the 2024 elections, with findings used to update guidelines.
Long summary:
Requires the Election Assistance Commission to develop and issue voluntary guidelines for election offices addressing the use and risks of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies in election administration within 60 days of enactment.

Mandates inclusion of guidelines on the risks and benefits of AI in election activities, cybersecurity risks, the impact of AI-generated information on sharing accurate election information, and the spread of election disinformation.

Directs the Election Assistance Commission to study and report on the use and impacts of AI technologies in the 2024 federal elections by November 5, 2025, including the sharing of AI-generated information and the use of AI by election offices.

Requires the Election Assistance Commission to review and update the voluntary guidelines based on the study's findings.

Official name: NSF AI Education Act of 2024
Casual name: NSF AI Education Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the NSF AI Education Act of 2024, providing scholarships for AI and quantum hybrid computing studies at undergraduate and graduate levels. Creates AI-focused professional development fellowships, training grants for agriculture, and AI excellence centers. Promotes AI education, outreach, and workforce frameworks, prioritizing underserved areas and diverse institutions.
Long summary:
Establishes the NSF AI Education Act of 2024 to provide scholarships and fellowships for AI education at various educational levels, including undergraduate and graduate studies. 

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation (NSF) to award scholarships for AI studies in fields such as agriculture, education, and advanced manufacturing, prioritizing institutions in underserved areas.

Directs the NSF to create professional development fellowships for AI and related emerging technologies, fostering collaboration between academia and industry.

Requires grants for AI training at land-grant colleges and universities, focusing on agricultural applications.

Authorizes the establishment of Centers of AI Excellence at community colleges and vocational schools to advance AI education and training.

Advises on guidelines for AI use in primary and secondary education and supports AI education research.

Prohibits funding to institutions in violation of anti-discrimination laws.

Directs the development of workforce frameworks for AI and other emerging technologies.

Official name: Political Declaration on Responsible Military Use of Artificial Intelligence and Autonomy
Casual name: Political Declaration on Responsible Military Use of AI and Autonomy
Short summary: Requires endorsing States to ensure military AI use aligns with international law. Mandates oversight, transparency, and rigorous testing for military AI systems. Urges minimizing bias, implementing safeguards, clear system functions, and staff training. Promotes public commitment and international cooperation for responsible AI deployment.
Long summary:
Require States to ensure military AI use complies with international law, particularly international humanitarian law.

Mandate accountability through a responsible human command chain.

Impose legal reviews to align military AI with international obligations and enhance civilian protection.

Demand oversight by senior officials for high-consequence AI applications.

Advocate minimizing unintended bias in military AI.

Insist on transparent, auditable methodologies and documentation for military AI development.

Oblige training for personnel to understand AI capabilities and limitations, preventing automation bias.

Prescribe explicit, well-defined uses for military AI, with rigorous testing for safety and effectiveness.

Implement safeguards to detect and mitigate AI failures, with the ability to deactivate systems if needed.

Encourage States to publicly commit to these measures, support responsible AI use, and engage internationally to refine and promote these standards.

Official name: Disrupt Explicit Forged Images And Non-Consensual Edits Act of 2024
Casual name: DEFIANCE Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, to define "digital forgery" as AI-created intimate visual depictions. Allows civil action for non-consensual digital forgeries. Specifies damages and relief. Permits privacy protections. Establishes a 10-year statute of limitations. Ensures non-preemption.
Long summary:
Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, to include "digital forgery" as any intimate visual depiction created via AI or other technological means to appear indistinguishable from an authentic visual depiction.

Allows identifiable individuals to bring civil action against those who produce, possess, disclose, or solicit digital forgeries without consent, with knowledge or reckless disregard of the lack of consent.

Specifies relief for plaintiffs, including actual or liquidated damages of $150,000, attorney’s fees, and equitable relief such as injunctions.

Permits courts to issue orders to protect plaintiffs' privacy, including the use of pseudonyms and sealing personal identifying information.

Establishes a 10-year statute of limitations for actions, starting from the discovery of the violation or the individual reaching 18 years of age.

Ensures the Act does not preempt state, federal, or tribal laws that provide at least as much protection.
Tags: Harms: Detrimental content;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Civil liability;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Discrimination;Incentives: Civil liability;Harms: Discrimination

Official name: Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights
Casual name: Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies;Editors' Picks
Short summary: Requires pre-deployment testing, risk mitigation, and ongoing monitoring for automated systems' safety and effectiveness. Mandates independent evaluations, public reporting, and avoiding inappropriate data. Demands protections against algorithmic discrimination and data privacy. Institutes oversight on surveillance technologies. Requires clear user notifications and explanations. Insists on transparency and accountability through independent evaluations.
Long summary:
Requires automated systems to undergo pre-deployment testing, risk identification, mitigation, and ongoing monitoring to ensure safety and effectiveness.

Requires that systems avoid the use of inappropriate or irrelevant data and that independent evaluations and public reporting confirm system safety and effectiveness.

Imposes protections against algorithmic discrimination by incorporating proactive equity assessments, representative data usage, and continuous disparity testing and mitigation.

Enforces data privacy through built-in protections, user consent for data collection, and limitations on data use and sharing, particularly in sensitive domains such as health, education, and finance.

Institutes heightened oversight and limits on surveillance technologies to protect civil liberties, privacy, and democratic values, with specific restrictions on continuous surveillance in sensitive contexts.

Requires designers and deployers of automated systems to provide clear, timely, and accessible notice and explanations of system use, including the rationale behind decisions impacting individuals.

Calls for independent evaluations and public reporting to ensure transparency and accountability in the use of automated systems, with detailed documentation and assessments.

Official name: Measures for the Management of Generative Artificial Intelligence Services (Draft for Comment)
Casual name: Measures for the Management of Generative Artificial Intelligence Services (Draft for Comment)
Short summary: Requires AI-generated content in China to meet a series of criteria, including accuracy, intellectual property protection, and respect for individual privacy; also requires AI developers to perform security assessments on their generative AI systems and submit those assessments to regulators.
Long summary:
Requires AI-generated content in China to meet a series of criteria, including accuracy, non-discrimination with regard to an array of protected characteristics, intellectual property protection, exclusion of violent content or content that subverts state power, and respect for individual privacy.

Requires AI developers to conduct a security assessment on generative AI systems that evaluates the cybersecurity of the system and its ability to comply with regulations; the assessment must be submitted to regulators before the system can be released for public use. 

Requires AI developers to prevent their generative AI systems from being used for various purposes, including engaging in unfair economic competition, and requires generative AI systems to make themselves inaccessible to individuals who use the systems for such purposes. 

Describes the legal liability that developers hold for the content generated by their AI systems and the punishments, including fines, they may face for violating these rules.
