Official name: National Critical Capabilities Defense Act of 2023
Casual name: National Critical Capabilities Defense Act
Short summary: Defines "national critical capability sector" as including artificial intelligence and defines "covered activities" as being related to "national critical capability sectors". Establishes the "Committee on National Critical Capabilities" to review U.S. investments abroad threatening national security.
Long summary:
Defines "national critical capabilities sector" as sectors, including artificial intelligence, subject to regulation described in the bill.

Establishes the "Committee on National Critical Capabilities" to review U.S. investments in foreign countries that may threaten national security.

Requires U.S. persons to notify the Committee of covered activities in critical sectors, including artificial intelligence, at least 90 days before initiation.

Instructs the Committee to review and potentially mitigate risks posed by such activities, with authority to prohibit or regulate investments.

Defines "covered activities" broadly to include acquisitions, joint ventures, and other engagements with foreign entities in critical sectors.

Identifies countries of concern, including China, Russia, and North Korea, where such investments are scrutinized more closely.

Grants the Committee authority to enforce compliance, including imposing civil penalties up to $250,000 or twice the amount of the covered activity.
Tags: Strategies: New institution;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Disclosure;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Convening

Official name: DATA Privacy Act
Casual name: DATA Privacy Act
Short summary: Establishes national data privacy standards for covered entities. Requires clear privacy notices. Mandates FTC regulations within one year. Imposes data minimization requirements. Empowers individuals with data rights. Mandates privacy officers for large entities. Grants FTC and state enforcement authority. Allocates FTC resources.
Long summary:
Establishes national data privacy standards for covered entities handling personal data.

Requires covered entities to post clear, accessible privacy notices detailing data collection, processing, storage, and disclosure practices.

Mandates the FTC to create regulations within one year for reasonable, equitable, and non-deceptive data practices, including opt-out and affirmative consent mechanisms.

Imposes data minimization requirements, limiting data collection to what is necessary for specified purposes and ensuring timely deletion.

Empowers individuals with rights to access, correct, delete, and transfer their data.

Mandates large entities to appoint privacy protection officers to oversee compliance and advocate for privacy policies.

Directs the National Science Foundation to support research on privacy-enhancing technologies.

Grants enforcement authority to the FTC and state attorneys general, with civil penalties for violations.

Allocates resources to the FTC for enforcement and compliance activities.

Official name: STOP HATE Act of 2023
Casual name: STOP HATE Act
Short summary: Mandates social media companies to submit terms of service reports to the Attorney General's office that provide data on how artificial intelligence is being used to flag content and manage disinformation.
Long summary:
Requires social media companies to make their terms of service publicly available.

Requires social media companies to disclose content moderation data, including the total number of flagged items, actioned items, user engagement, and how artificial intelligence is used to support content moderation efforts.

Allows Attorney General's office to bring a civil penalty of $5,000,000 per violation per day against social media companies who fail to meet these requirements

Official name: Advisory for AI-Generated Content Act
Casual name: Advisory for AI-Generated Content Act
Short summary: Requires all entities that generate AI materials for public consumption to label them with watermarks.
Long summary:
Requires all AI-generated materials to be labeled with a watermark. 

Authorizes the federal government to establish requirements and standards for watermarks.

Enables the federal government to levy penalties against entities that violate the above stipulation.

Defines key terms including AI-generating entity, AI-generated material, and covered AI-generated material, specifying criteria for materials that must be watermarked.
Tags: Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Convening;Risk factors: Transparency;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Harms: Detrimental content;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Detrimental content

Official name: Ensuring Safe and Ethical AI Development Through SAFE AI Research Grants
Casual name: SAFE AI Research Grants
Short summary: Requires the National Academy of Sciences to establish a grant program for the development of safe AI models and AI research; directs and outlines the submission of a proposal for the program in accordance with guiding principles.
Long summary:
Requires the National Academy of Sciences to establish a grant program for the development of safe AI models and AI research.

Mandates the development of guiding principles and ethical considerations for the grant program.

Directs the Director of the National Academy of Sciences to submit a detailed proposal of the grant program to relevant Congressional committees within one year, including a budget, proposed appropriation request, and an evaluation of existing AI models and methodologies.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Reliability;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Risk factors: Safety;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D

Official name: United States-Israel Health Technologies Cooperation Act
Casual name: US-Israel Health Technologies Act
Short summary: Authorizes $4,000,000 annually (2024-2026) for a bilateral health tech program with Israel emphasizing AI, drugs, vaccinations, and telemedicine. Requires matching Israeli contributions.
Long summary:
Authorizes $4,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2024 through 2026 to fund a bilateral cooperative program with Israel for developing health technologies. Emphasizes advancing technology, personalized medicine, and data usage in relation to emerging infectious diseases.

Includes artificial intelligence, drugs, vaccinations, respiratory assist devices, diagnostic tests, and telemedicine as eligible health technologies. Requires matching contributions from the Government of Israel to access funding. Allows funding for existing bilateral programs or the establishment of new programs in consultation with the Secretary of State under the 2008 Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement.
Tags: Strategies: Government support;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: New institution

Official name: CONSULT Act of 2023
Casual name: CONSULT Act
Short summary: Prohibits the Department of Defense from awarding contracts to any individual or entity, including those producing AI-powered products and services, that has entered into working agreements with any organization from a blacklist of national security threats.
Long summary:
Requires the Department of Defense to refrain from awarding contracts to any individual or entity, including those producing AI-powered products and services, that has worked with any organization from a blacklist of national security threats.

Authorizes the DOD to punish any contractor of the Department who has a proven conflict of interest with the DOD and fails to disclose that conflict of interest.
Tags: Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: Voluntary Commitments from Leading Artificial Intelligence Companies
Casual name: Voluntary Commitments from Leading Artificial Intelligence Companies
Short summary:
Establishes the commitments of leading artificial intelligence companies to manage risks posed by AI.

Announces the Biden-Harris Administration's development of an executive order and intent to pursue bipartisan legislation in these matters.
Long summary:
Acknowledges the voluntary commitments received from Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI to the Biden-Harris Administration to help move toward the safe, secure, and transparent development of AI technology.   

Specifies various actionable commitments that will support three broad goals: ensuring products are safe before public release, building systems that put security first, and earning public trust. Commitments include internal and external security testing, sharing information across the industry and with governments, civil society, and academia, and investing in cybersecurity and insider threat safeguards.

Announces the Biden-Harris Administration's development of an executive order and intent to pursue bipartisan legislation in these matters.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Transparency;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Risk factors: Security;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Evaluation;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Disclosure: About incidents;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Risk factors: Bias;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Risk factors: Privacy;Strategies: Convening;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Risk factors: Bias;Harms: Discrimination;Risk factors: Reliability;Harms: Harm to health/safety

Official name: Kids Online Safety Act, Sec. 13 ("Filter Bubble Transparency Requirements")
Casual name: Kids Online Safety Act, Sec. 13 ("Filter Bubble Transparency")
Short summary: Requires covered internet platforms to inform users about opaque algorithm and user data usage and provide detailed algorithm operational information. Mandates offering an input-transparent algorithm alternative and prohibits discrimination against users of this alternative.
Long summary:
Requires providers of covered internet platforms that use opaque algorithms to notify users about their use and provide detailed information about their operation, including their features, user-specific data collection, and algorithmic inputs in an easily accessible form.

Mandates platforms to offer an easily accessible input-transparent algorithm alternative and prohibits discrimination, via methods like differential pricing, against users who choose the alternative.

Empowers enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission to treat violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Exempts small downstream providers and non-profit organizations from certain enforcement provisions.
Tags: Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls: Data circulation;Strategies: Input controls: Data use;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Discrimination;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls: Data use;Incentives: Civil liability

Official name: Secure Artificial Intelligence Act of 2024
Casual name: Secure A.I. Act
Short summary:
Requires the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to improve accounting for AI security vulnerabilities in their existing databases.

Establishes an AI Security Center within NSA for research and secure AI practices.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to update the National Vulnerability Database to include AI security vulnerabilities.

Establishes a voluntary, comprehensive database to track AI security and safety incidents, ensuring confidentiality and standardized reporting.

Requires the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to update the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures Program for AI vulnerabilities.

Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within NSA to facilitate AI security research, develop counter-AI techniques, and promote secure AI practices.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Harm to property;Harms: Harm to infrastructure;Harms: Ecological harm;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Harm to infrastructure;Harms: Ecological harm;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure: About incidents;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Tiering;Strategies: Tiering: Tiering based on impact;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Business services and analytics;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Strategies: New institution;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: Child Exploitation and Artificial Intelligence Expert Commission Act of 2024
Casual name: Child Exploitation and AI Commission Act
Short summary: Establishes a Commission of Experts to evaluate the existing capabilities of law enforcement to detect and prosecute child exploitation crimes involving AI, and recommend solutions.
Long summary:
Establishes the Commission of Experts on Child Exploitation and Artificial Intelligence to investigate and recommend solutions for the prevention, detection, and prosecution of child exploitation crimes involving AI.

Directs the Commission to assess the role of AI in child exploitation and evaluate law enforcement's current capabilities to detect and prosecute such crimes.

Requires the Commission to recommend statutory or constitutional amendments to address obstacles to prosecution identified by the Commission and enhance law enforcement's ability to combat AI-facilitated child exploitation.

Mandates the Commission to submit to Congress interim reports as needed and a final report within two years of member appointments.

Details membership of the Commission as composed of 13 appointed experts from various fields, and outlines guidelines on membership qualifications and operational procedures.

Empowers the Commission to hold hearings, obtain official data, and utilize various support services for its operations.

Official name: Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act of 2024
Casual name: GenAI Copyright Disclosure Act
Short summary: Requires anyone that creates or alters a training dataset for a generative AI system to submit a notice to the Register of Copyrights detailing copyrighted works used in the dataset 30 days before the model being made available to consumers or 30 days after the Act takes effect. Imposes a $5,000 penalty for non-compliance and instructs the Register to create a public database of filed notices.
Long summary:
Requires anyone who creates or alters a training dataset used for a generative AI system to submit a notice to the Register of Copyrights with a summary of any copyrighted works used in the dataset and the URL for the dataset.

Requires the notice must be submitted 30 days before the AI system is made available to consumers or within 30 days of the Act taking effect for systems already available.

Imposes a civil penalty of at least $5,000 for non-compliance.

Requires the Register to establish and maintain a public database of filed notices.
Tags: Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Harm to property;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form

Official name: AI PLAN Act
Casual name: AI PLAN Act
Short summary: Requires the Secretaries of the Treasury, Homeland Security, and Commerce to submit an annual report to Congress on the risks of use of AI in the commission of financial crimes.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Treasury, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Secretary of Commerce to submit a joint report to Congress on the risks of use of AI in financial crimes, including fraud and misinformation, within 180 days of enactment and annually thereafter.

Mandates the inclusion in the report of interagency policies, procedures, and resources needed to defend against AI-driven financial crimes.

Directs the report to include the consideration of risks such as deepfakes, voice cloning, foreign election interference, synthetic identities, false market signals, and overall digital fraud.

Requires the subsequent submission of legislative recommendations and best practices to address risks identified within 90 days of each report.
Tags: Harms: Detrimental content;Harms: Financial loss;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Finance and investment;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: AI CONSENT Act
Casual name: AI CONSENT Act
Short summary: Requires companies to obtain informed consent from consumers before using their data for training AI systems.
Long summary:
Requires companies to obtain informed consent from consumers before using their data to train AI systems.

Requires companies to explain clearly and concisely how consumer data will be used for AI training.

Mandates disclosure of further data usage, including transfers to third-party entities.

Directs the FTC to issue a report on the progress of converting covered data to de-identified data (for Congress' evaluation).

Treats violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act and subjects violators to penalties.

Official name: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Matters Related to Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 101 ("Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities")
Casual name: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 101 ("Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities")
Short summary: Identify categories of technologies and prohibit certain activities in sectors related to AI development that that poses acute threats to US national security.
Long summary:
Requires the President to identify, list, and annually update categories of technologies and products in the AI sector that pose acute threats to U.S. national security if acquired by adversaries.

Requires the President to prescribe regulations prohibiting U.S. persons from engaging in covered activities involving listed technologies and products in the AI development sector.

Directs the President to submit annual congressional reports on notifications of covered activities and assessing the need for regulatory amendments.

Encourages multilateral engagement to align with allied countries on similar mechanisms for prohibitions and notifications on technologies in the AI sector.

Authorizes $25 million for implementation and allows direct hiring to administer the entire Act.
Tags: Strategies: Input controls: Compute circulation;Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government study or report;Incentives: Civil liability;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls: Data use

Official name: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Matters Related to Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 102 ("Sanctions with Respect to Communist Chinese Military and Surveillance Companies")
Casual name: Countering Communist China Act, Title I ("Trade, Investment, and Economic Relations"), Sec. 102 ("Sanctions for Chinese Military and Surveillance Companies")
Short summary: Requires the President to impose sanctions on AI development activities and ownership by foreign persons to knowingly be involved/associated with the Chinese military and surveillance apparatus.
Long summary:
Requires the President to impose sanctions on foreign persons engaged in significant operations in China's defense or surveillance technology sectors.

Focuses particular attention on foreign persons engaged in AI, machine learning, robotics, quantum information science, and other advanced technologies.

Utilizes the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to block and prohibit transactions involving sanctioned foreign persons' property within U.S. jurisdiction.
Tags: Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls;Strategies: Input controls;Incentives: Criminal liability;Incentives: Civil liability

Official name: Countering Communist China Act, Title VII ("Matters Related to Defense"), Sec. 701 ("Modifications to Use of Emergency Sanctions Authorities Regarding Communist Chinese Military Companies")
Casual name: Countering Communist China Act, Title VII ("Defense"), Sec. 701 ("Emergency Sanctions Regarding Chinese Military Companies")
Short summary: Requires amendments to emergency sanctions on Chinese military companies to includes sectors like AI.
Long summary:
Mandates the exercise of emergency sanctions authorities regarding Communist Chinese military companies.

Defines affected companies as those engaged in commercial services, manufacturing, producing, or exporting in the AI sector.
Tags: Strategies: Input controls

Official name: Countering Communist China Act, Title VI ("Matters Related to Democracy, Human Rights, and Taiwan"), Sec. 615 ("Deterring America's Technological Adversaries Act")
Casual name: Countering Communist China Act, Title VI ("Democracy, Human Rights, and Taiwan"), Sec. 615 ("DATA Act")
Long summary:
Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in transactions involving sensitive personal data with entities subject to Chinese influence.

Requires the President to impose sanctions on foreign persons dealing in connected software applications under Chinese control, facilitating military, espionage, or malicious cyber activities.

Mandates sanctions for foreign persons involved in election interference against the U.S. or its allies, or influencing U.S. policy in favor of China.

Directs the President to determine and report on whether entities like ByteDance and TikTok meet criteria for sanctions.

Empowers the President to block all transactions involving property of sanctioned foreign persons within U.S. jurisdiction.

Allows the President to waive sanctions on a case-by-case basis if vital to U.S. national security interests.

Terminates the section's authorities five years after enactment.

Official name: New Jersey Bill A537
Casual name: New Jersey Bill A537 ("Discrimination in Automobile Insurance")
Short summary: Require insurers using AI in underwriting to annually prove non-discrimination in pricing based on race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or religion. Require balanced pricing segments. Define automated underwriting as including AI and other technologies.
Long summary:
Require automobile insurers using automated or predictive underwriting systems to annually provide the Department of Banking and Insurance with documentation demonstrating no discriminatory outcomes in pricing based on race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or religion.

Mandate insurers to show that each pricing segment is balanced and not disproportionate to the overall policyholder population.

Define ‚Äúautomated or predictive underwriting system‚Äù as a computer-generated process, including robotic process automation, artificial intelligence, or other specialized technology, used to evaluate risk and determine insurance rates.

Authorize the Commissioner of Banking and Insurance to adopt rules and regulations to implement the act.

Specify that the act takes effect on the first day of the sixth month following enactment and applies to automobile insurance policies initiated or renewed from that date.

Official name: New Jersey SB 3876
Casual name: New Jersey SB 3876 ("Artificial Intelligence Officer")
Short summary: Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Officer and Implementation Officer to oversee AI systems in New Jersey's state agencies. Mandates development of procedures for using AI in critical decisions, ensuring compliance with national standards, and mitigating risks. Creates an AI Advisory Board for oversight and recommendations.
Long summary:
Establishes the position of Artificial Intelligence Officer to develop and update procedures regulating automated systems used by state agencies for critical decisions.

Mandates state agencies to comply with these procedures and submit inventories of their automated systems, which will be published online.

Creates the New Jersey Artificial Intelligence Advisory Board to advise state agencies, hold public hearings on preliminary procedures, and issue reports and recommendations.

Establishes the position of Artificial Intelligence Implementation Officer to review and approve or deny new automated systems based on compliance with procedures, and conduct periodic reevaluations.

Forms a task force to study AI and create an AI Bill of Rights, with a report due within one year.

Subjects officers and the board to open public records laws while protecting trade secrets and work product protections.

Official name: New York Bill A5309
Casual name: New York Bill A5309 ("Responsible AI Standards")
Short summary: Amends state finance law to require state units to purchase algorithmic decision systems adhering to responsible AI standards, focusing on harm avoidance, transparency, fairness, and risk evaluation. Expands "unlawful discriminatory practice" definition to include algorithmic decision systems.
Long summary:
Amend the state finance law to require state units to purchase products or services containing algorithmic decision systems that adhere to responsible artificial intelligence standards.

Mandate the avoidance of harm, including minimizing risks of physical or mental injury, unjustified information deletion or disclosure, and unwarranted damage to property, reputation, or the environment.

Require a commitment to transparency, including full disclosure of the algorithmic decision system's capabilities, limitations, and potential problems.

Prioritize fairness by eliminating discrimination, promoting equality, tolerance, respect, and justice, and providing feedback mechanisms to redress harms.

Conduct comprehensive evaluations and analyses of the algorithmic decision system's impact and potential risks.

Amend the executive law to define "unlawful discriminatory practice" to include actions performed through algorithmic decision systems.

Require the commissioner of taxation and finance to adopt regulations to implement these provisions.

Official name: Massachusetts Bill S. 31
Casual name: Massachusetts Bill S. 31 ("Regulate GenAI")
Short summary: Regulate generative AI models to protect safety, privacy, and IP rights. Define models as those with ‚â•1 billion parameters. Prohibit discriminatory AI use. Mandate AI text watermarks/authentication. Require data security, informed consent, and timely data deletion. Conduct regular risk assessments. Mandate registration with the attorney general, detailing practices. Authorize attorney general to enforce compliance.
Long summary:
Regulate generative AI models, such as ChatGPT, to protect public safety, privacy, and intellectual property rights.

Define "large-scale generative artificial intelligence model" as those with at least one billion parameters.

Prohibit the use of AI models for discrimination or bias based on protected characteristics.

Mandate AI-generated text to contain a distinctive watermark or offer an authentication process to prevent plagiarism.

Require companies to implement reasonable security measures to protect training data.

Obtain informed consent from individuals before collecting, using, or disclosing their data.

Delete or de-identify data when no longer needed for the intended purpose.

Conduct regular risk assessments to identify and mitigate foreseeable risks and harms.

Mandate companies operating large-scale AI models to register with the attorney general within 90 days, including detailed model and data practices.

Authorize the attorney general to adopt regulations and enforce compliance, including bringing legal action for violations.

Official name: New York A7106
Casual name: New York A7106 ("PAID Act")
Short summary: Amends election law to require disclosure of synthetic media use in political communications, stating "This political communication was created with the assistance of artificial intelligence." Defines synthetic media as AI-modified text, image, video, or sound. Effective January 1, 2024.
Long summary:
Amends the election law to mandate disclosure of synthetic media in political communications.

Requires disclosure for printed or digital political communications to state: "This political communication was created with the assistance of artificial intelligence."

Mandates non-printed or digital political communications to clearly display or speak the same statement.

Defines "synthetic media" as any media created or modified using artificial intelligence algorithms.

Sets the effective date of this act to January 1, 2024.

Official name: California AB 1282
Casual name: California AB 1282 ("AI and mental health")
Short summary: Requires the Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission to report a strategy by July 1, 2025, addressing mental health risks from social media and AI for youth. Involves assessing mental health service access and recommending resiliency strategies. Repeals January 1, 2029.
Long summary:
Requires the Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission to report a statewide strategy on mitigating mental health risks from social media use among children and youth by July 1, 2025.

Mandates the report to include data on access to mental health services by those negatively impacted by social media and recommendations to enhance resiliency strategies and service utilization.

Obligates the commission to explore social media types, user populations, and associated mental health risks, including suicide, eating disorders, and substance abuse.

Includes artificial intelligence in the assessment of negative health risks.

Prioritizes engagement with children and youth, especially at-risk and underserved populations, in the report formulation.

Repeals the provisions on January 1, 2029.

Official name: Illinois HB 3563
Casual name: Illinois HB 3563 ("GenAI Task Force")
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Amends the Department of Innovation and Technology Act to establish the Generative AI and Natural Language Processing Task Force. Tasks the Task Force with investigation, public meetings, recommendations, and a comprehensive report by December 31, 2024.
Long summary:
Amends the Department of Innovation and Technology Act to establish the Generative AI and Natural Language Processing Task Force.

Requires the Task Force to investigate and report on generative AI and natural language processing software.

Comprises the Task Force of appointed members from various government, educational, and expert backgrounds.

Mandates the Task Force to hold at least five public meetings across different regions of Illinois.

Tasks the Task Force with recommending legislation for consumer information protection, model policies for schools, and assessing AI's impact on public services, civil rights, employment, and cybersecurity.

Obligates the Department to provide administrative and technical support to the Task Force.

Requires the Task Force to file a comprehensive report by December 31, 2024, with the Governor and the General Assembly.

Official name: New York A7838
Casual name: New York A7838 ("Long-term impact of AI on workforce")
Short summary: Requires the New York Department of Labor to study AI's long-term impact on the workforce, issuing interim reports every five years and a final report by 2035. Prohibits state entities from using AI to displace employees until the final report.
Long summary:
Mandates the Department of Labor to begin a study on the long-term impact of artificial intelligence on the state workforce within six months.

Requires consultation with the Department of Civil Service and the Office of Information Technology Services.

Calls for examination of job performance, productivity, training, education requirements, privacy, and security.

Obligates the Department of Labor to issue an interim report every five years and a final report by January 1, 2035, with recommendations for legislative action.

Prohibits all state departments and governmental entities from using AI to displace any natural person from their employment until the final report and recommendations are received.

Ensures immediate effect upon enactment.

Official name: North Carolina SB 460
Casual name: North Carolina SB 460 ("Automation and Workforce")
Short summary: Establishes a Study Committee on Automation and the Workforce to assess the impact of automation technologies, including AI, on North Carolina's workforce, especially low-income and minority workers. Requires biennial reports with recommendations to the Governor and legislature.
Long summary:
Establishes the Study Committee on Automation and the Workforce to analyze the impact of automation on North Carolina's workforce, with a focus on low-income and minority workers.

Requires the Committee to include 11 voting members representing labor organizations, employers, and state legislators, appointed by the Governor and legislative leaders.

Designates seven nonvoting ex officio members from key state departments and educational institutions.

Mandates the Committee to review the effects of automation technologies such as AI, industrial robotics, and self-service technologies on employment.

Instructs the Committee to assess educational and training requirements for workers to adapt to automation.

Requires the Committee to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and Joint Legislative Commission on Governmental Operations before the 2025 General Assembly and biennially thereafter.

Official name: Pennsylvania HB 49
Casual name: Pennsylvania HB 49 ("AI Business Registry")
Short summary: Establishes a registry for businesses operating AI systems in Pennsylvania. Requires submission of business details, including code type and contact information. Prohibits commercial use of collected data. Mandates annual reporting to legislative committees. Defines "artificial intelligence."
Long summary:
Establishes a registry of businesses operating artificial intelligence (AI) systems in Pennsylvania.

Requires the Department of State to coordinate with other state agencies to create paper and online registry forms.

Mandates the collection of specific information from businesses, including business name, IP address, type of AI code, software intent, and contact details.

Prohibits the sale or commercial use of collected information and exempts it from Right-to-Know Law disclosure.

Maintains a searchable online database for businesses operating AI systems.

Obligates the Department of State to submit an annual report on the registry to legislative committees, detailing the number of registered businesses, registrant distribution by agency, and incurred expenses.

Defines "artificial intelligence" as computer systems performing tasks requiring human intelligence.

Sets the act to take effect 60 days post-enactment.

Official name: Pennsylvania HB 1380
Casual name: Pennsylvania HB 1380 ("Administration of Assistance Programs")
Short summary: Utilizes artificial intelligence for eligibility verification and fraud detection in public assistance programs. Authorizes data access from state agencies to verify residency and eligibility. Prioritizes job training programs to increase employment and self-reliance.
Long summary:
Authorizes the department to utilize data analytics and artificial intelligence for eligibility verification and fraud detection in public assistance programs.

Permits the department to access data from other state agencies to verify residency and eligibility of applicants.

Empowers the department to establish rules, regulations, and standards for assistance program administration, including eligibility criteria and benefit modifications.

Requires the department to ensure expenditures do not exceed appropriations and to seek necessary federal waivers or approvals.

Allows the establishment of health savings accounts and medical assistance premiums to aid residents transitioning out of assistance programs.

Mandates physical health managed care organizations to share medical assistance claims data with providers.

Official name: Rhode Island SB 146
Casual name: Rhode Island SB 146 ("Consumer Protection Gaming Act")
Short summary: Prohibits the use of facial recognition, biometric recognition, and certain automated decision systems in video-lottery terminals and online betting applications. Restricts AI use for influencing gaming outcomes. Excludes standardized rewards programs from these prohibitions.
Long summary:
Prohibits the use of facial recognition technology and biometric recognition programs in video-lottery terminals and online betting applications.

Prohibits the use of algorithmic programs that modify gaming based on a consumer's betting history to increase wagers.

Prohibits the use of artificial intelligence or automated decision systems to promote increased play through intermittent reinforcement based on cognitive-behavioral algorithms and prior gaming data.

Applies these prohibitions to sports betting applications and vendors of gambling products licensed by Rhode Island.

Excludes standardized rewards programs from these prohibitions.

Takes effect upon passage.

Official name: Alabama SB 78
Casual name: Alabama SB 78 ("Council on Advanced Technology")
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Establishes the Alabama Council on Advanced Technology and Artificial Intelligence to review and advise on AI use and development. Requires annual reports with recommendations. Comprises appointed experts and legislative members. Emphasizes diversity in appointments. Effective one year after approval.
Long summary:
Establishes the Alabama Council on Advanced Technology and Artificial Intelligence.

Requires the council to review and advise the Governor and Legislature on the use and development of advanced technology and artificial intelligence.

Composes the council of 22 members, including appointees from the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, and Senate President Pro Tempore, and ex officio members from commerce and information technology departments.

Mandates that non-legislative appointees have expertise in AI, technology, ethics, privacy, workforce development, or computer science.

Stipulates that the council meets at least twice a year and allows virtual participation.

Obliges the council to submit an annual report with recommendations on AI and advanced technology to the Governor and Legislature.

Enforces diversity in appointments regarding gender, race, and geography.

Prohibits salary for non-legislative members but allows expense reimbursement; provides legislative members with regular compensation for meeting attendance.

Sets the act’s effective date to one year post-approval.

Official name: California SJR 6
Casual name: California SJR 6 ("Artificial Intelligence")
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Urges President and Congress to develop an AI Advisory Committee. Highlights need for AI policy, ethical standards, workforce planning, and innovation. Notes California's AI investment. Calls for bridging tech-regulation gaps. Directs resolution to federal and state officials.
Long summary:
Urges the President and Congress to develop a comprehensive Artificial Intelligence Advisory Committee.

Urges the adoption of a comprehensive artificial intelligence policy.

Highlights the importance of federal government planning for workforce changes due to AI.

Emphasizes the need for ethical standards in AI development and employment.

Encourages promoting innovation to help American companies grow.

Notes that California has attracted significant global AI investment.

Calls for bridging the gap between technological change and regulatory response.

Directs transmission of the resolution to key federal officials and California representatives.

Official name: Illinois HB 0645
Casual name: Illinois HB 0645 ("Future of Work Act")
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Creates the Illinois Future of Work Task Force to plan for future labor needs. Requires assessment of emerging technologies like AI. Mandates job standards development. Instructs identification of future job opportunities. Proposes workforce training programs. Submits report by May 1, 2022.
Long summary:
Creates the Illinois Future of Work Task Force to proactively plan for the future of work and address current labor issues.

Requires the Task Force to identify and assess emerging technologies, particularly automation and AI, that significantly impact employment, wages, and skills.

Mandates the development of job standards and working conditions to build a vibrant middle class.

Instructs the Task Force to identify future job opportunities and shape them to improve life in Illinois.

Compiles research and best practices from other regions on deploying technology for the public good.

Develops tools to evaluate the impact of proposed technologies on workers, employers, and the state.

Proposes workforce development and training programs for future jobs.

Requires the Task Force to submit a report with findings to the Governor and General Assembly by May 1, 2022, and dissolves upon report submission.

Official name: New Jersey S 2723
Casual name: New Jersey S 2723 ("Integrated Digital Experience Act")
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Authorizes the Chief Technology Officer to evaluate AI, machine learning, and cloud services use by state agencies for public services. Requires agencies to submit IT modernization plans leveraging data analytics and enhancing digital services, ensuring mobile-friendly and accessible websites.
Long summary:
Requires each state agency to develop and submit an information technology modernization and improvement plan to the Chief Technology Officer within one year of request.

Mandates the plan to include strategies for improving digital services using data analytics, cloud computing, electronic forms, and digitized workflows, ensuring mobile-friendly and accessible websites.

Authorizes the Chief Technology Officer to review these plans in collaboration with the Chief Innovation Officer.

Mandates the Chief Technology Officer to annually evaluate the feasibility of using AI, machine learning, and cloud services for public services, and to develop data analytics capabilities for policy development.

Requires the development of metrics to assess each agency's implementation of a modern digital experience, updated at least every two years and reevaluated every three years.

Official name: A bill to specify control and management of Department of Defense data and to establish the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council, and for other purposes.
Casual name: S. 3004 (Chief AI Officer Governing Council)
Short summary: Establishes the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council to oversee AI policy, ethics, and coordination within the Department of Defense. Requires the Council to streamline AI development, ensure ethical practices, and provide periodic reports to Congress.
Long summary:
Establishes the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council to oversee AI and data policies within the Department of Defense.

Requires the Council to ensure responsible, coordinated, and ethical use of AI across DoD missions.

Mandates the Council to streamline AI development, implementation, and oversight within the DoD.

Improves coordination on AI governance with the defense industry.

Oversees ethical requirements and protections for AI usage, mitigating unintended bias in AI algorithms.

Monitors and updates recommendations for AI operational usage.

Reviews AI program funding to ensure compliance with DoD AI policies.

Provides periodic updates on AI development and implementation efforts.

Guides access and distribution restrictions for data and AI tools.

Implements educational programs on AI applications for all DoD levels.

Submits periodic reports to the Secretary of Defense and congressional defense committees.

Official name: To direct the Secretary of Defense to establish a working group to develop and coordinate an artificial intelligence initiative among the Five Eyes countries, and for other purposes.
Casual name: H. R. 6425 (Five Eyes countries AI initiative)
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish the Five AIs Strategic AI Working Group to develop and coordinate AI initiatives among Five Eyes countries. Requires comparison of AI systems, testing interoperability, ethical frameworks, and expanding innovation efforts.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish a working group named “Five AIs Strategic Artificial Intelligence Working Group” within 90 days of enactment.

Mandates the working group to develop and coordinate an AI initiative among the Five Eyes countries.

Requires designation of a senior civilian or military officer to lead the working group.

Encourages participation of Five Eyes Intelligence Oversight and Review Council members.

Tasks the working group with comparing AI systems, identifying interoperability solutions, and testing AI model redundancy.

Instructs the development of shared strategies for AI research, development, and data management.

Promotes the comparison and use of ethical frameworks and the acceleration of AI technology procurement.

Obligates the submission of a plan within 60 days and biannual reports to congressional committees.

Sets the termination date for the working group on September 30, 2028, with an option for extension.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Literacy Act of 2023
Casual name: H. R. 6791 (AI Literacy Act of 2023)
Short summary: Amends the Digital Equity Act to promote AI literacy. Establishes grants for AI education in schools, community colleges, and higher education. Supports teacher training, lab development, and virtual learning platforms. Requires annual Congressional reports on AI education initiatives.
Long summary:
Amends the Digital Equity Act of 2021 to include artificial intelligence (AI) literacy within the scope of digital literacy.

Defines "artificial intelligence literacy" as understanding basic AI principles, applications, implications, limitations, and ethical considerations.

Requires grants to support AI literacy initiatives in public elementary and secondary schools, including teacher training, professional development, resource development, and partnerships with the private sector.

Supports community colleges by funding interdisciplinary AI literacy programs, lab development, and virtual learning platforms.

Funds higher education institutions to develop AI learning labs, virtual platforms, and educational tools for teachers and community educators.

Provides grants to community anchor institutions for AI education and training programs.

Mandates an annual report to Congress summarizing and analyzing the progress and impact of AI literacy initiatives, with recommendations for expansion or modification.

Official name: Strategy for Public Health Preparedness and Response to Artificial Intelligence Threats
Casual name: S. 2346 (Public Health Response to AI)
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a strategy addressing AI misuse threats to national health security. Involves public health preparedness, identifying gaps, and mitigating risks like biological weapons. Ensures national security protection in reporting to Congress.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a strategy for public health preparedness and response to artificial intelligence (AI) threats within 180 days of enactment.

Mandates consultation with stakeholders, including those developing countermeasures and those with AI expertise, for strategy formulation.

Includes a framework for mitigating AI misuse risks threatening national health security and outlines duties, functions, and metrics for preparedness and response.

Identifies gaps in public health capabilities and proposes strategies to address these gaps and strengthen emergency preparedness against AI threats.

Focuses on mitigating risks such as the development of biological weapons and drug-resistant viruses and bacteria.

Requires the strategy to be submitted to relevant congressional committees without compromising national security.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to integrate this AI threat strategy into the broader federal response to public health emergencies.

Official name: To direct the Director of the National Institutes of Health to establish a grant program to facilitate research regarding the use of generative artificial intelligence in health care, and for other purposes.
Casual name: H.R. 7381 (Health AI)
Short summary: Directs the NIH Director to establish a grant program promoting research on generative AI in healthcare. Prioritizes projects enhancing AI adoption, workforce development, reducing disparities, and improving underserved care. Supports AI applications in documentation, insurance, and customer service efficiency.
Long summary:
Establishes a grant program by the Director of the National Institutes of Health to fund research on the use of generative AI in health care.

Permits research to include enhancing note-taking, reducing administrative burdens, expediting insurance claims, improving customer service efficiency, and other health care improvements.

Prioritizes grants for entities promoting AI adoption in health care, investing in workforce development, mitigating workforce burnout, reducing health disparities, and improving care for medically underserved populations.

Defines eligible entities to include higher education institutions, nonprofit organizations, and various governmental agencies.

Defines "generative artificial intelligence" as AI producing content in response to prompts.

Official name: A bill to promote United States leadership in technical standards by directing the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the Department of State to take certain actions to encourage and enable United States participation in developing standards and specifications for artificial intelligence and other critical and emerging technologies, and for other purposes.
Casual name: S. 3849 (US Leadership in AI Standards)
Short summary: Requires NIST Director to brief Congress on federal AI standards participation within one year. Directs federal agencies to notify NIST of AI standards activities. Mandates NIST to create a reporting mechanism and establish a web portal. Establishes a pilot program for U.S.-based standards meetings. Obligates annual NIST briefings to Congress on the pilot program. Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from 2024 to 2028.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to brief Congress within one year on federal participation opportunities in AI and emerging technology standards development.

Directs federal agencies to notify NIST of their involvement in AI standards activities and mandates NIST to create a reporting mechanism for this purpose.

Mandates NIST to establish a web portal to inform U.S. industry and federal agencies about international standards efforts and participation opportunities.

Establishes a pilot program for supporting U.S.-based standards meetings, including prestandardization and coordination meetings, through grants to eligible entities.

Obligates NIST to brief Congress annually on the pilot program’s effectiveness and provide recommendations for permanent implementation if deemed feasible.

Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from fiscal years 2024 through 2028.

Official name: Advanced Weather Model Computing Development Act
Casual name: Advanced Weather Model Computing Development Act
Short summary: Directs the Department of Energy and NOAA to collaborate on AI and high-performance computing for climate and weather modeling. Establishes competitive processes, data sharing, and infrastructure improvements, with progress reports required two years post-enactment. Termination occurs five years post-enactment.
Long summary:
Directs the Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to collaborate on AI and high-performance computing research to improve climate models and weather prediction.

Requires the establishment of a memorandum of understanding to facilitate this collaboration through a competitive, merit-reviewed process.

Authorizes the Secretary of Energy and NOAA Administrator to conduct research on modeling, simulation, machine learning, data assimilation, and predictive analysis techniques.

Mandates the promotion of collaboration and data sharing among federal agencies, National Laboratories, educational institutions, and nonprofits, while ensuring compliance with national security policies.

Instructs the submission of a report within two years detailing interagency coordination, research achievements, and future opportunities.

Initiates a high-performance computing project to enhance weather prediction models, requiring a comparative analysis with current forecasts.

Sunsets the authority for this initiative five years post-enactment.

Ensures compliance with research security provisions under the CHIPS Act of 2022.

Official name: DOE and NSF Interagency Research Act
Casual name: DOE and NSF Interagency Research Act
Short summary: Facilitates collaborative AI research between the Department of Energy and National Science Foundation, focusing on machine learning, data analytics, and computational advancements. Requires interagency agreements and promotes data sharing, infrastructure support, and STEM education initiatives.
Long summary:
Requires the Department of Energy (DOE) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) to coordinate research and development activities.

Mandates the establishment of a memorandum of understanding between the DOE and NSF, utilizing a competitive, merit-reviewed process for project applications.

Authorizes collaborative research in key areas including artificial intelligence, machine learning, data analytics, quantum computing, and computational sciences.

Promotes interagency collaboration and data sharing among Federal agencies, National Laboratories, and other institutions.

Supports research infrastructure development and STEM education initiatives, including internships and professional development.

Allows reimbursable agreements between the DOE and NSF to enhance research effectiveness.

Obligates the DOE and NSF to report on interagency coordination, research achievements, and future opportunities within two years of enactment.

Ensures activities comply with research security provisions under existing law.

Official name: No AI FRAUD Act
Casual name: No AI FRAUD Act
Short summary: Establishes property rights in likeness and voice, transferable post-mortem for ten years. Prohibits unauthorized cloning and replicas, imposing liabilities. Specifies damages per violation. Allows punitive damages and attorney fees. Provides First Amendment defense. Exempts negligible harm. Sets four-year limitations period.
Long summary:
Establishes property rights for individuals in their likeness and voice, treating them as intellectual property that is transferable and descendible for ten years post-mortem.

Prohibits unauthorized distribution, transmission, or availability of personalized cloning services, digital voice replicas, or digital depictions without the individual’s consent, imposing liabilities for violations.

Specifies that unauthorized use incurs damages of $50,000 per violation for cloning services and $5,000 per violation for voice replicas or depictions, plus actual damages and profits.

Allows for punitive damages and attorney fees for injured parties and invalidates disclaimers as a defense.

Provides a First Amendment defense, balancing public interest with intellectual property rights, and considers commercial use and impact on the value of the original work.

Exempts negligible harm from liability and defines harm to include financial, physical, and severe emotional distress.

Sets a four-year limitations period for civil actions and ensures no preemption of other rights or laws.

Official name: FAIRR Act
Casual name: FAIRR Act
Short summary: Amends the Financial Stability Act to require the Financial Stability Oversight Council to assess AI risks in financial systems, identify regulatory gaps, and recommend improvements. Enhances oversight of AI service providers, imposes treble penalties for machine-manipulated media, and establishes liability for AI deployment.
Long summary:
Amends the Financial Stability Act of 2010 to assign the Financial Stability Oversight Council duties regarding AI in the financial sector.

Requires the Council to coordinate with member agencies on AI-related financial system risks and direct the Office of Financial Research to study AI use by financial institutions.

Obligates the Council to identify AI-related threats to financial stability, including market manipulation and disruption by malign actors.

Mandates submission of a report within 180 days identifying regulatory gaps and recommending solutions, including referencing the NSA's September 2023 Cybersecurity Information Sheet.

Calls for scenario-based exercises to test AI-related financial disruption defenses.

Expands authority to oversee third-party AI service providers to financial institutions.

Increases penalties for securities violations involving machine-manipulated media to three times the standard amount.

Imposes liability on developers for AI model outcomes under Federal securities laws, with limited potential for waivers.

Official name: Jobs of the Future Act of 2023
Casual name: Jobs of the Future Act of 2023
Short summary:
Requires the Secretary of Labor and the NSF Director to submit interim and final reports on AI's workforce impact. 

Mandates identification of necessary data, affected industries, and vulnerable demographics. 

Requires analysis of skills and education needed to work with AI.

Demands recommendations to mitigate displacement and promote equitable AI education. 

Requires collaboration with educational institutions, industry stakeholders, and federal agencies.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Labor and the Director of the National Science Foundation to submit interim and final reports on AI's impact on the U.S. workforce.

Mandates these reports to identify data necessary for analyzing AI's workforce impact, industries most affected by AI, and demographics vulnerable to job displacement.

Requires analysis of skills, expertise, and education needed to work alongside AI and methods to deliver these to the workforce.

Demands recommendations to mitigate workforce displacement, promote knowledge sharing, and ensure underserved demographics have access to necessary AI-related education.

Requires collaboration with educational institutions, industry stakeholders, and federal agencies in preparing the reports.

Official name: Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
Casual name: Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
Short summary: Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to prohibit distributing AI-generated audio impersonating candidates' voices with actual malice. Exempts certain media entities. Imposes fines or imprisonment for violations. Requires the Federal Election Commission to issue regulations and reports on compliance.
Long summary:
Prohibits the distribution of political communications containing materially deceptive AI-generated audio that impersonates a candidate’s voice, with actual malice, intended to harm the candidate’s reputation or deceive voters.

Applies to communications distributed within 90 days of a general election or 60 days of a primary, special, or runoff election.

Excludes radio/television stations, bona fide news broadcasts, satire or parody, and certain internet and media entities from this prohibition.

Defines "materially deceptive audio" as AI-generated impersonation of a candidate’s voice without approval and lacking a clear disclaimer.

Defines "actual malice" as knowingly or recklessly using AI to create false representations.

Mandates criminal penalties of fines or up to 2 years imprisonment for violators.

Requires the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations and provide annual compliance reports.

Official name: Small Business Broadband and Emerging Information Technology Enhancement Act of 2023
Casual name: S. 2677 Small Business Technology Enhancement Act
Short summary: Designates a coordinator to assist small businesses in adopting AI and emerging technologies, requiring collaboration with federal agencies. Mandates biennial reports on broadband's impact on small businesses, and updates training for SBA employees on AI technologies.
Long summary:
Designates a senior employee of the Office of Investment and Innovation as the broadband and emerging information technology coordinator to assist small businesses in adopting broadband and emerging technologies.

Requires the coordinator to work with the SBA's chief information officer, chief technology officer, and other relevant federal agencies.

Mandates the coordinator to identify best practices and catalog tools and training for small businesses on broadband and emerging technologies.

Obligates the coordinator to provide training to SBA employees on these technologies and relevant federal programs.

Requires biennial reports on the SBA's activities related to broadband and emerging technologies.

Instructs the Chief Counsel for Advocacy to study and report on the impact of broadband availability, speed, and price, and the deployment of emerging technologies on small businesses.

Amends the Small Business Act to include provisions for increasing small business access to broadband and emerging technologies.

Official name: Digital Platform Commission Act of 2023
Casual name: Digital Platform Commission Act of 2023
Short summary: Establishes the Federal Digital Platform Commission to regulate digital platforms, including AI processes, ensuring fairness, transparency, and safety. Designates systemically important platforms, mandates algorithmic accountability, and requires age-appropriate design and verification standards. Coordinates with other agencies for oversight.
Long summary:
Establishes the Federal Digital Platform Commission to regulate digital platforms.

Mandates oversight of algorithmic processes, including those using AI, for fairness, transparency, and safety.

Requires systemically important digital platforms to meet commercial and technical standards for data portability and interoperability.

Obligates platforms to ensure recommendation systems and other algorithmic processes are free from harmful, abusive, anticompetitive, or deceptive biases.

Introduces transparency requirements for terms of service and content moderation policies.

Imposes regular public risk assessments for harmful content distribution and steps to mitigate such harms, including those from algorithmic processes.

Provides for inter-agency consultation and support, including with the FTC and DOJ, on matters related to digital platforms.

Allows private persons and governmental entities to enforce the Act through complaints, civil actions, and penalties.

Official name: Protecting Kids on Social Media Act
Casual name: Protecting Kids on Social Media Act
Short summary: Prohibits social media platforms from using algorithmic recommendation systems for users under 18. Requires age verification and parental consent for minors on social media. Bans access for users under 13. Establishes enforcement mechanisms and a secure digital identification credential pilot program.
Long summary:
Requires social media platforms to verify the age of users beyond simple attestations, using current age verification technologies.

Prohibits social media platforms from allowing individuals under 13 from accessing their services.

Mandates parental or guardian consent for users under 18, requiring platforms to take reasonable steps to verify this consent.

Prohibits the use of algorithmic recommendation systems on individuals under 18, except for contextual suggestions or advertising.

Establishes a Pilot Program for secure digital identification credentials to facilitate age and parental consent verification, overseen by the Secretary of Commerce.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general to enforce compliance, with civil penalties for violations.

Grants extraterritorial jurisdiction for violations involving individuals in the United States.

Official name: RESTRICT Act
Casual name: RESTRICT Act
Short summary: Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to identify, prohibit, and mitigate risks from foreign adversary transactions and holdings in AI and ICT sectors. Prioritizes AI, machine learning, and critical infrastructure. Allows the President to compel divestment actions against risky foreign investments.
Long summary:
Authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to review and prohibit certain transactions involving information and communications technology (ICT) between U.S. persons and foreign adversaries.

Empowers the Secretary to identify, deter, disrupt, prevent, prohibit, investigate, or mitigate risks arising from covered transactions.

Defines "covered transactions" broadly, including those involving foreign adversaries or entities under their jurisdiction.

Establishes procedures for the Secretary to refer covered holdings posing national security risks to the President, who can then compel divestment or take other actions to mitigate risks.

Prioritizes critical ICT areas such as AI, quantum computing, and telecommunications for evaluation.

Exempts actions from standard administrative and judicial reviews, limiting legal challenges to specific high courts.

Imposes civil and criminal penalties for violations, including fines, imprisonment, and forfeiture.

Official name: Next Generation Pipelines Research and Development Act
Casual name: H. R. 7073 Pipelines R&D Act
Short summary: Establishes a demonstration initiative to advance AI technologies for pipeline systems, focusing on machine learning models for infrastructure optimization and real-time monitoring. Supports AI-based research in coordination with federal agencies, emphasizing cybersecurity and environmental impact mitigation. Allocates significant funding for AI advancements.
Long summary:
Creates a demonstration initiative to advance next-generation pipeline technologies, awarding financial assistance to eligible entities through a competitive process.

Establishes a joint research and development program within the Department of Energy, coordinated with the Department of Transportation and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, to develop advanced materials and technologies for pipeline systems.

Forms the National Pipeline Modernization Center to collaborate on research, development, and demonstration projects for commercializing cost-effective pipeline products and procedures.

Mandates the development of measurement research, testing, and standardization programs by the National Institute of Standards and Technology to ensure pipeline integrity and support safety, security, and efficiency.

Authorizes significant appropriations for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 to support these initiatives.

Official name: Technology Workforce Framework Act of 2024
Casual name: S. 3792 Technology Workforce Framework Act
Short summary: Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop and update an AI workforce framework. Expands NIST's functions to include workforce frameworks for emerging technologies. Mandates reports to Congress on frameworks and their applications.
Long summary:
Expands the functions of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to include developing workforce frameworks for critical and emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI).

Requires the Director of NIST to develop, maintain, and update an AI workforce framework and review it at least every three years.

Mandates the inclusion of professional, support, and operational skills in AI workforce frameworks, considering nontraditional backgrounds.

Instructs the Director to consult with various stakeholders, including federal agencies and educational institutions, in developing these frameworks.

Obliges the Director to produce multilingual resources to support global adoption of these frameworks.

Requires periodic reports to Congress on updates and the process of reviewing workforce frameworks, including the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education Workforce Framework for Cybersecurity.

Directs the development and publication of additional workforce frameworks for other critical technologies, such as quantum information science.

Official name: MEANS Act
Casual name: MEANS Act
Short summary: Establishes the Office of Manufacturing Security and Resilience to enhance supply chain resilience, focusing on critical goods. Supports domestic manufacturing, reduces reliance on concerning countries, and incentivizes relocation of facilities. Provides loans, loan guarantees, and sets criteria for eligible entities.
Long summary:
Establishes an Office of Manufacturing Security and Resilience within the Department of Commerce to oversee the Manufacturing Security and Resilience Program.

Mandates the Under Secretary to develop and implement a strategy to strengthen supply chains for critical goods, reducing reliance on concentrated supply chains, particularly from countries of concern.

Requires collaboration with other federal agencies to support allies and key international partners in building manufacturing capacity for critical goods.

Incentivizes domestic manufacturers to relocate production from countries of concern and increase production capacity, using loans, loan guarantees, and other financial supports.

Prioritizes support for activities that enhance the resilience, security, and diversity of supply chains and address supply chain shocks.

Mandates periodic submission of strategy reports and program evaluations to Congress, with updates every four years.

Allocates $35 billion for fiscal years 2024-2028 to fund the program, with specific allocations for loans, loan guarantees, and administrative costs.

Official name: Data Science and Literacy Act of 2023
Casual name: Data Science and Literacy Act
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Education to award grants to enhance data literacy education, including AI, at pre-kindergarten through postsecondary levels. Supports curriculum development, teacher training, and industry partnerships. Authorizes $10 million annually from 2024 to 2028.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to eligible entities to enhance data literacy education from pre-kindergarten through postsecondary levels.

Requires grant applications to detail plans for increasing access to data literacy and STEM education, evaluating project activities, and continuing efforts post-grant.

Mandates the use of grant funds for developing data literacy curricula, providing professional development for educators, and collaborating with industry and educational institutions.

Limits equipment purchases to 15% of grant funds annually.

Obligates recipients to submit biannual reports on grant fund usage, with data disaggregated by race, ethnicity, gender, and eligibility for free/reduced lunch.

Tasks the Secretary with submitting a comprehensive report to Congress within five years, including recommendations for program expansion.

Authorizes $10 million annually for fiscal years 2024-2028, with caps on administrative expenses and program evaluation costs.

Official name: To establish in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration a program to improve precipitation forecasts, and for other purposes.
Casual name: H. R. 4913 NOAA Precipitation Forecasts
Short summary: Supports AI and machine learning research to enhance precipitation prediction accuracy and reliability. Encourages collaboration with academic and private sectors to evaluate emerging technologies. Uses high-performance computing to advance Earth System Models' predictive skills for extreme precipitation phenomena.
Long summary:
Establishes a program within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to improve precipitation forecasts.

Requires the use of fully coupled Earth System Models to enhance precipitation prediction.

Mandates the utilization of high performance computing and other technologies, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, to advance precipitation forecasts.

Supports research and development in collaboration with academic and private sector partners to test and evaluate emerging technologies.

Improves the accuracy, reliability, and timeliness of precipitation predictions across various timescales.

Incorporates social and behavioral sciences to enhance precipitation forecast products and communication.

Coordinates efforts with Federal, State, local, Tribal, and academic entities.

Authorizes appropriations of $15 million annually from fiscal year 2024 through fiscal year 2028 for the program.

Official name: DOE and NASA Interagency Research Coordination Act
Casual name: DOE and NASA Research Coordination Act
Short summary: Authorize collaborative AI research between the Department of Energy and NASA, focusing on machine learning, data analytics, and algorithm optimization. Require competitive merit-based awards for projects, and promote data sharing with secure transfer capabilities.
Long summary:
Requires the Department of Energy (DOE) and NASA to coordinate research and development activities, including AI-related areas such as machine learning, data analytics, and predictive analysis.

Mandates the use of memoranda of understanding for coordination.

Allows for competitive awards to support collaborative R&D activities.

Directs the development of methods to handle large data sets on high-performance computing systems.

Promotes data sharing between DOE, NASA, National Laboratories, and other entities, ensuring secure data transfer.

Authorizes reimbursable and non-reimbursable agreements between DOE and NASA.

Ensures competitive awards follow merit-review processes and consider applications from various entities.

Obligates a report within two years on coordination activities, achievements, and future plans.

Requires consistency with research security laws.

Official name: Weather Information for Agriculture Act
Casual name: Weather Information for Agriculture Act
Short summary: Advances AI and machine learning for drought forecasting. Requires developing next-gen technologies and optimizing federal data for drought indicators. Establishes partnerships for nationwide drought and soil moisture information. Authorizes appropriations for AI-related enhancements in drought information systems.
Long summary:
Reauthorizes the National Integrated Drought Information System.

Requires advancement and deployment of AI, machine learning, and cloud technologies for drought forecasting.

Mandates strengthening observational networks and drought indicators, addressing gaps in snowpack and soil moisture monitoring.

Establishes memoranda of understanding with the National Mesonet Program for coordinated drought information.

Requires migration to probabilistic forecasts and incorporation of new modeling tools with the Climate Prediction Center.

Authorizes appropriations from $15,000,000 in fiscal year 2024 to $17,000,000 in fiscal year 2028 for these activities.

Mandates development, deployment, and maintenance of the National Coordinated Soil Moisture Monitoring Network.

Requires establishment of a user-friendly website, high-quality data criteria, and increased in situ soil moisture monitoring stations.

Promotes research, data sharing, and engagement with the citizen science community for soil moisture monitoring.

Allows partnerships to provide nationwide soil moisture information.

Official name: Integrating New Technologies to Empower Law Enforcement at Our Borders Act
Casual name: New Technologies at Borders Act
Short summary: Requires the Department of Homeland Security to plan integrating AI and emerging technologies for border awareness.
