Specifies assessments, cost estimates, capability gaps, and coordination with other agencies. Emphasizes transitioning new technologies and incentivizing private sector development.
Long summary:
Requires the Department of Homeland Security to develop a comprehensive plan within 180 days to identify, deploy, and integrate emerging and advanced technologies to enhance situational awareness along the northern and southern borders of the United States.

Mandates the inclusion of artificial intelligence, machine learning, automation, fiber-optic sensing, nanotechnology, optical and cognitive radar, modeling and simulation technology, hyperspectral and LIDAR sensors, and other similar technologies.

Includes an assessment of current technology utilization by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and how capability gaps can be addressed through technology integration.

Requires cost estimates for technology acquisition and maintenance, metrics for measuring technology impact, and an assessment of multi-domain awareness improvements.

Mandates an analysis of other Federal technologies, procurement authorities, and the transition of new technology systems.

Requires coordination with the Department of Homeland Security's Science and Technology Directorate for research, development, and incentivizing private sector innovation.

Official name: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act of 2023
Casual name: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act
Short summary: Establishes a Defense Department education course on digital content provenance, addressing AI-driven forgery challenges. Initiates a pilot program to implement industry standards for verifying media authenticity, assessing feasibility, and consulting experts. Requires reporting on progress, effectiveness, and potential permanence.
Long summary:
Establishes a course at the Defense Information School to educate on digital content provenance for Department of Defense (DoD) media content.

Requires the course to cover challenges from digital content forgery, industry open technical standards, and techniques for secure digital content documentation.

Mandates a report on the curriculum development and implementation plan for the course, including resource needs.

Initiates a pilot program to assess the feasibility of using industry open technical standards for digital content provenance in DoD media.

Directs the pilot program to verify digital content provenance, apply technology solutions, assess historical records, and develop effectiveness measures.

Allows the Director to consult with research centers, private industry, and educational institutions.

Terminates the pilot program on January 1, 2027.

Requires a report by January 1, 2026, detailing findings, consultations, effectiveness, and recommendations on the pilot program's permanence.

Official name: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act of 2023
Casual name: Digital Defense Content Provenance Act
Short summary: Requires the DMA Director to establish a DINFOS course on digital content provenance within one year. Mandates coverage of forgery challenges and authentication standards. Obligates a pilot program with an interim report by January 1, 2026, ending January 1, 2027. Defines key terms.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the Defense Media Activity (DMA) to establish a course of education at the Defense Information School (DINFOS) on digital content provenance within one year of enactment.

Mandates the course to cover digital content provenance, challenges posed by digital content forgery, and the use of industry open technical standards for authenticating digital content.

Obligates the Director to start a pilot program within one year to assess the implementation of industry standards for digital content provenance for official Department media.

Sets termination date for the pilot program on January 1, 2027, with an interim report due by January 1, 2026, to assess effectiveness and feasibility.

Defines key terms including "digital content forgery" and "digital content provenance" to ensure clarity in implementation.

Official name: Advancing Nuclear Regulatory Oversight Act
Casual name: Advancing Nuclear Regulatory Oversight Act
Short summary: Incorporates AI and machine learning to improve nuclear oversight. Requires the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to assess and integrate advanced technologies for risk-informed inspections and operational efficiency. Seeks stakeholder input and recommends specific actions for training and regulatory updates.
Long summary:
Requires the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to report to Congress within 180 days on regulatory changes made during the COVID-19 emergency, examining their impact on licensing and safety.

Mandates the NRC to develop and submit a report within one year identifying specific improvements in oversight and inspection programs, emphasizing risk-informed, performance-based procedures and the use of advanced technologies, including AI and machine learning.

Instructs the NRC to seek input from stakeholders including the Secretary of Energy, National Laboratories, the nuclear energy industry, and relevant NGOs in developing the report.

Requires assessment of potential modifications to oversight and inspections, improvement measures, and incorporation of advanced technologies to enhance operational efficiency and safety.

Obligates the NRC to identify and implement actions based on assessments and recommendations to improve training, inspection, oversight, and licensing activities without compromising its mission.

Official name: Shifting Forward Vehicle Technologies Research and Development Act
Casual name: Vehicle Technologies R&D Act
Short summary: Establishes programs for AI-driven vehicle technology research, focusing on electrification, machine learning for manufacturing, autonomous systems, cybersecurity, and advanced energy solutions. Requires periodic reporting and coordination among federal agencies. Allocates funding for these initiatives through 2028.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Energy to conduct a research, development, and demonstration program for advanced vehicle technologies, focusing on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and vehicle manufacturing costs.

Mandates coordination with other federal agencies and existing programs on electric vehicle integration and critical material recycling.

Supports the development of advanced batteries, power electronics, electric drive systems, and vehicle electrification technologies.

Includes provisions for cybersecurity and physical security of vehicle interconnections with the electric grid and other infrastructure.

Establishes a program for medium- and heavy-duty commercial and transit vehicles, emphasizing advanced energy technologies and efficiency improvements.

Authorizes the creation of Graduate Automotive Technology Education Centers of Research Excellence to foster advancements in automotive energy technologies.

Allocates substantial funding for these initiatives through fiscal year 2028, with a total authorization exceeding $2.9 billion.

Official name: Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act
Casual name: Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act
Short summary: Supports research on privacy-enhancing technologies, including de-identification and machine learning. Requires National Science Foundation to coordinate with federal agencies. Integrates privacy technologies into cybersecurity. Mandates progress reports and policy recommendations to improve technology adoption and coordination.
Long summary:
Introduces the "Promoting Digital Privacy Technologies Act."

Requires the National Science Foundation to support research on privacy enhancing technologies, including de-identification, pseudonymization, and algorithms for data privacy.

Mandates integration of privacy enhancing technologies into the Computer and Network Security Program as per the Cyber Security Research and Development Act.

Obliges coordination among the Office of Science and Technology Policy, National Science Foundation, National Institute of Standards and Technology, and Federal Trade Commission to expedite development and use of privacy enhancing technologies.

Demands outreach by the National Institute of Standards and Technology to gather stakeholder input and promote private and public sector engagement.

Requires submission of a report within three years on research progress, development of voluntary resources, and policy recommendations to improve communication and coordination among stakeholders.

Official name: Exploitative Workplace Surveillance and Technologies Task Force Act of 2023
Casual name: Exploitative Workplace Technologies Task Force Act
Short summary: Establishes an interagency task force to study workplace surveillance and AI decision systems. Evaluates surveillance's impact on various worker aspects, including compensation and safety. Requires reports and recommendations on addressing surveillance and AI technologies in workplaces.
Long summary:
Establishes the White House Task Force on Workplace Surveillance and Technologies within 180 days of enactment.

Mandates the Task Force to study and evaluate the use of workplace surveillance and automated decision systems by employers.

Requires the Task Force to analyze the prevalence, types, and impacts of workplace surveillance across industries, including data collection, storage, security, and transfer practices.

Necessitates examination of the effects of workplace surveillance on worker compensation, performance reviews, scheduling, career advancement, safety, health coverage, and discipline.

Obligates the Task Force to consider the impact on vulnerable populations, including workers with disabilities, low-wage workers, and workers of color.

Orders the Task Force to submit initial, interim, and final reports to Congress, detailing findings and providing recommendations on addressing workplace surveillance and related technologies.

Terminates the Task Force 60 days after submitting the final report.

Official name: National Strategy to Utilize Microreactors for Natural Disaster Response Efforts Act
Casual name: Microreactors for Natural Disaster Response Act
Short summary: Requires the President to develop a national strategy for using microreactors in natural disaster response. Involves consultation with multiple federal agencies and includes assessments, goals, and recommendations for deploying microreactors efficiently and safely, emphasizing technological integration and partnerships.
Long summary:
Mandates the President develop a national strategy for utilizing microreactors to assist with natural disaster response efforts.

Requires consultation with FEMA, DOE, National Guard, Army Corps of Engineers, and Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Obligates submission of the strategy to Congress within one year and biennially thereafter.

Includes an assessment of current diesel generator usage and environmental impacts compared to microreactors.

Outlines goals and objectives for replacing diesel generators with microreactors.

Calls for a Department of Defense analysis on translating operational microreactor technology for disaster response.

Recommends expedited design approval and licensing for microreactors.

Assesses strategic considerations, including storage, transportation, and integration into existing grids.

Evaluates partnership opportunities for effective deployment.

Encourages the use of AI and predictive tools for disaster preparation involving microreactors.

Official name: Promoting Resilient Supply Chains Act of 2023
Casual name: Promoting Resilient Supply Chains Act
Short summary: Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to promote U.S. leadership in AI and strengthen supply chains. Mandates a resiliency program. Requires coordination with agencies. Promotes domestic manufacturing. Supports best practices. Mandates regular reporting on AI supply chains.
Long summary:
Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to promote U.S. leadership in emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI), and strengthen critical supply chains and national security.

Mandates the establishment of a critical supply chain resiliency and crisis response program within the Department of Commerce, which includes mapping and monitoring AI supply chains.

Requires coordination with other agencies, industry, and international partners to identify vulnerabilities and prepare for supply chain shocks affecting AI technologies.

Promotes the growth of domestic manufacturing capacities for AI and other emerging technologies and encourages the relocation of manufacturing facilities to the U.S. or allied countries.

Supports the development and dissemination of best practices for supply chain resilience, including the use of blockchain and other technologies to authenticate and trace critical goods.

Mandates regular reporting on the state of AI and other emerging technology supply chains, including assessments of vulnerabilities and recommendations for enhancing resilience.

Official name: Do Not Disturb Act
Casual name: Do Not Disturb Act
Short summary: Requires AI robocalls to disclose AI use. Increases penalties for AI voice impersonation in robocalls and telemarketing. Mandates free robocall-blocking services and regulations for VoIP providers. Enhances tracking of illegal robocall campaigns. Expands AI-related telemarketing rules.
Long summary:
Requires disclosure at the beginning of robocalls or text messages if artificial intelligence is used to emulate a human being.

Enhances penalties for robocall and telemarketing violations involving AI impersonation, doubling fines for fraudulent or harmful AI-generated calls or messages.

Mandates the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to offer robocall-blocking services at no charge and to develop a tracking system for the top 100 illegal robocall campaigns.

Obligates Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) providers to verify customer identities, monitor robocall patterns, and report violations.

Directs both the FCC and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to study and regulate AI usage in robocalls and telemarketing, including text message authentication and inbound call restrictions.

Official name: Novel, Advanced Spectrum and Communications Technology Networks Promotion Act
Casual name: Advanced Communications Technology Networks Act
Short summary: Directs the Assistant Secretary of Commerce to advance spectrum management through prototyping AI and advanced communications technologies, including dynamic spectrum access and optical communications. Encourages workforce development and partnerships for prototyping advanced communications technologies.
Long summary:
Directs the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to support the establishment, prototyping, and implementation of common models and methodologies to inform electromagnetic spectrum management decisions.

Requires the development of technologies and techniques to control radio frequency emissions and interference.

Mandates the prototyping of artificial intelligence systems and technologies capable of operating advanced antenna arrays and dynamic spectrum access.

Encourages the development and participation of a skilled workforce to prototype advanced communications technologies.

Supports partnerships among institutions for workforce development in advanced communications technologies.

Identifies and implements technologies that promote dynamic spectrum access, network sensing, monitoring, and optical and quantum communications.

Amends section 104 of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to include these additional responsibilities for the Assistant Secretary.

Official name: Oversee Emerging Technology Act
Casual name: Oversee Emerging Technology Act
Short summary: Requires federal agencies substantially engaged with emerging technologies to appoint a senior official as an emerging technology lead. Tasks them with advising on AI use, policy expertise, interagency collaboration, and procurement input. Mandates informing Congress of appointments and responsibilities.
Long summary:
Requires the head of each covered federal agency engaged in emerging technologies to appoint or designate a Senior Executive Service individual or equivalent as an emerging technology lead.

Mandates that these leads advise agencies on the responsible use of emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Obliges these leads to provide expertise on responsible policies and practices, collaborate with interagency bodies, and input on procurement policies.

Instructs the President to inform Congress within 180 days of enactment about the appointed leads and their authorities and responsibilities.

Official name: Diversify Tech Act
Casual name: Diversify Tech Act
Short summary: Establishes a task force within the Department of Commerce to promote diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility (DEIA) in the tech industry. Evaluates AI's role in DEIA, monitors minority treatment, and reports on layoffs and DEIA progress.
Long summary:
Establishes a Tech Industry Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) Task Force within the Department of Commerce.

Mandates the Task Force to conduct audits on minority representation, hiring policies, and layoff trends in the tech industry.

Requires submission of an initial audit report to Congress within 60 days of the Task Force’s establishment.

Obliges the Task Force to promote DEIA, offer guidance to tech entities, and consult with stakeholders on DEIA issues.

Tasks the Task Force with advising on outreach programs and encouraging venture capital investment in minority-owned startups.

Mandates annual reports evaluating tech industry progress on DEIA goals, the impact of AI on discrimination, and proposing policy solutions for accountability.

Requires a special report on how 2023 tech layoffs affected DEIA, including potential violations of federal laws.

Official name: Water Infrastructure Modernization Act of 2023
Casual name: Water Infrastructure Modernization Act
Short summary: Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and Safe Drinking Water Act to authorize grants for smart water infrastructure technology. Supports AI and intelligent optimization tools to improve water systems' efficiency, reliability, and decision-making.
Long summary:
Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and the Safe Drinking Water Act to authorize grants for smart water infrastructure technology.

Requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to provide grants for intelligent wastewater treatment systems using AI for predictive maintenance and real-time monitoring.

Mandates grants for smart drinking water systems with AI tools to reduce water loss, improve decision-making, and enhance operational efficiency.

Specifies that 25% of the grant funds are set aside for rural communities and 10% for Tribal communities.

Obligates the EPA to issue guidance for grant applications within 30 days of enactment and make funding decisions within 60 days.

Requires annual reports to Congress on the projects funded and their impacts.

Authorizes $25 million for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 for both wastewater and drinking water infrastructure projects.

Official name: Counseling for Career Choice Act
Casual name: Counseling for Career Choice Act
Short summary: Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to enhance career counseling, including using AI for career development. Supports career guidance, workforce trend identification, professional development, postsecondary opportunities, and partnerships with workforce centers, emphasizing improved career counseling infrastructure and technology utilization.
Long summary:
Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to expand career counseling opportunities.

Requires career counseling programs to leverage resources and emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Mandates the development of professional development or career development training certification programs for counselors and educators.

Encourages partnerships with one-stop centers and integration with local and state workforce entities.

Promotes the establishment and coordination of postsecondary opportunities such as internships, apprenticeships, and dual enrollment programs.

Requires the identification and assessment of school counseling activities and postsecondary options within and outside the state.

Mandates the evaluation of secondary and postsecondary outcomes for individuals served by career counseling programs.

Official name: Wildfire Technology Demonstration, Evaluation, Modernization, and Optimization Act
Casual name: Wildfire Technology DEMO Act
Short summary: Establishes a wildfire technology testbed pilot program prioritizing emerging technologies including AI. Requires collaboration with federal agencies and private entities to test and report on new technologies for wildfire prevention, detection, and mitigation over four years.
Long summary:
Establishes a wildfire technology testbed pilot program within 60 days of the Act's enactment, coordinated by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior.

Incorporates the program into an existing interagency coordinating group on wildfires.

Identifies key technology priority areas, including hazardous fuels reduction, dispatch communications, remote sensing, safety equipment, and operational dashboards.

Partners selected private entities, nonprofits, and higher education institutions with federal agencies for real-time testing during wildfire mitigation.

Prioritizes emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, quantum sensing, augmented reality, and advanced communications for wildfire mitigation.

Requires covered entities to submit applications, including technology testing proposals.

Mandates annual reports to Congress on participating entities, tested technologies, costs, outreach efforts, and technology assessments.

Terminates the program four years after establishment.

Official name: Outbound Investment Transparency Act of 2023
Casual name: Outbound Investment Transparency Act
Short summary: Amends the Defense Production Act to establish an investment screening mechanism targeting AI and other sensitive sectors. Requires U.S. persons to notify the Treasury of certain investments in countries of concern. Mandates annual reporting and promotes international coordination.
Long summary:
Requires mandatory notification by U.S. persons engaging in specific foreign investments related to advanced sectors, including artificial intelligence, to the Secretary of the Treasury.

Defines covered activities involving equity interests, debt obligations with governance rights, and joint ventures in countries of concern, with specific focus on AI and other advanced technologies.

Establishes penalties for non-compliance, including failure to notify or providing false information.

Mandates the creation of regulations to ensure clarity and minimize compliance burdens, with a focus on transparency and stakeholder involvement.

Directs the Secretary of State to engage with allied countries to coordinate investment screening mechanisms and share information on covered activities.

Requires annual reporting to Congress on trends, national security risks, and recommendations related to these foreign investments in AI and other sectors.

Official name: Forest Data Modernization Act of 2023
Casual name: Forest Data Modernization Act
Short summary: Amends the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act to integrate AI and advanced technologies, including machine learning, for enhanced forest data collection and analysis. Mandates improved carbon data evaluation, strategic plan updates, and accessible data for public and private sectors.
Long summary:
Amends the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Research Act to include forest carbon in resource assessments.

Requires the Secretary to conduct timber products output studies and national woodland owner surveys.

Mandates the integration of forest carbon data in bi-decadal reviews.

Specifies the need for clear definitions of "forest" in reporting data.

Updates strategic plan to include consistent data collection protocols, integration of new technologies, and enhanced transparency.

Ensures collected data is accessible while maintaining confidentiality of sensitive information.

Compiles and publishes biennial national forest statistics.

Establishes an office or platform to handle complex data requests, with possible fees imposed on requestors.

Publishes annual reports detailing progress on strategic plan implementation, including costs and priorities.

Amends Agriculture Improvement Act to utilize advanced remote sensing and machine learning technologies for data collection and modeling.

Official name: SAFE from PRC Investments Act
Casual name: SAFE from PRC Investments Act
Short summary: Amends the Securities Exchange Act to require public companies and exchange-traded funds to disclose ties to the Chinese government or Communist Party, including board memberships, financial operations, military involvements, and data management, focusing on governance and security implications.
Long summary:
Requires public companies and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing in companies with ties to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to disclose whether senior officials of the PRC government or Communist Party of China (CPC) sit on their boards or have executive roles.

Mandates disclosure of cash held in PRC operations, restrictions on cash repatriation, and details of assets, liabilities, and technology transfers.

Obligates reporting on interactions with CPC officials, expenditures on PRC operations, and any lobbying activities in the United States.

Compels ETFs to reveal ownership, CPC branches, contractual agreements, and involvement in PRC industrial policies or military contracts of invested PRC companies.

Requires disclosure of PRC companies’ products and services, U.S. defense contracts, and involvement in sectors like AI, telecommunications, and semiconductors.

Official name: Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities Act
Casual name: Preventing Adversaries from Developing Critical Capabilities Act
Short summary: Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in certain AI-related activities with countries of concern. Requires mandatory notification of AI activities posing national security threats. Establishes regulations to enforce prohibitions and notifications. Authorizes penalties for non-compliance and promotes international coordination.
Long summary:
Prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in covered activities involving certain technologies and products in countries of concern, particularly in sectors like AI, if they pose acute national security threats.

Requires the President to annually identify and publish lists of such critical technologies and products.

Mandates U.S. persons to notify the President of any covered activities that may threaten national security.

Empowers the President to impose civil penalties for violations and to delegate enforcement authority to federal agencies.

Encourages bilateral and multilateral engagements to promote compliance with these prohibitions and notifications.

Allocates $25 million annually for implementation and allows direct hiring to support administration.

Permits the President to issue waivers for activities deemed in the national interest, with required congressional notification.

Official name: Strengthening Consumer Protections and Medical Debt Transparency Act
Casual name: Medical Debt Transparency Act
Short summary: Establishes a public database for medical debt collection, requiring health care entities to report debt collection practices. Prohibits extraordinary collection actions during pending insurance appeals or before determining patient eligibility for assistance. Requires detailed patient billing information and imposes penalties for non-compliance.
Long summary:
Amends the Public Health Service Act to prohibit health care entities and their debt collectors from initiating extraordinary collection actions if a health insurance appeal is pending.

Mandates health care entities to determine patients' eligibility for assistance programs before commencing extraordinary collection actions.

Prohibits extraordinary collection actions until 180 days after the initial bill is sent to the patient.

Requires health care entities to provide patients with itemized statements and detailed payment receipts, and information on language assistance services.

Establishes a public database for medical debt collection, requiring health care entities to submit detailed annual reports, including data on debt collection practices and patient demographics.

Imposes penalties for non-compliance, including actual damages and additional court-permitted amounts.

Requires the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to report on medical debt collections, incorporating data from the public database and other sources.

Official name: Facial Recognition Act of 2023
Casual name: Facial Recognition Act
Short summary: Regulates law enforcement use of facial recognition, requiring court orders, ensuring civil rights protection, and mandating transparency. Prohibits reliance on facial recognition alone for arrests, bans use with body cameras, and demands accuracy and bias testing. Establishes reporting, auditing, and public notice requirements.
Long summary:
Prohibits law enforcement from using facial recognition without a court order, except in emergencies.

Mandates the removal of photos of minors and individuals not charged or acquitted from databases used for facial recognition.

Requires prosecutors to approve and courts to authorize the use of facial recognition with detailed applications.

Prohibits the use of facial recognition with body cameras, for face surveillance, or for immigration enforcement.

Enforces annual accuracy and bias testing of facial recognition systems by independent entities.

Requires public reporting and logging of facial recognition use, including demographic data.

Mandates audits of law enforcement agencies' use of facial recognition to ensure compliance and prevent misuse.

Allows civil actions and administrative discipline for violations of the Act.

Ensures public notice and transparency regarding the use of facial recognition by law enforcement.

Official name: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title II ("National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes")
Casual name: Drone R&D Act, Title II ("National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes")
Short summary: Establishes a program to fund Institutes focusing on unmanned aircraft systems, including AI research. Encourages partnerships, supports interdisciplinary education, and requires data management strategies. Allocates $5 million annually for 2024-2028. Prioritizes merit-based selection and avoids duplicative efforts.
Long summary:
Establishes a program to award financial assistance for creating and supporting a network of National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research Institutes.

Requires collaboration among public and private organizations, including Federal agencies, academic institutions, and industry, to form these Institutes.

Mandates the Institutes to focus on economic or social sectors and address ethical, societal, safety, and security implications of unmanned aircraft systems.

Supports interdisciplinary research, education, and workforce development, including broadening participation of underrepresented communities.

Provides funds for managing data sets, developing testbeds, conducting research, and supporting AI and machine learning related to advanced air mobility systems.

Imposes a competitive merit review process for awarding financial assistance and prohibits duplication of efforts.

Authorizes $5 million annually for fiscal years 2024-2028 to support these activities.

Official name: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title IV ("National Science Foundation Activities")
Casual name: Drone R&D Act, Title IV ("NSF Activities")
Short summary: Supports research and education on AI integration into advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft. Encourages ethical use, cybersecurity, data management, and workforce development. Establishes partnerships and coordinates with agencies to enhance domestic development, allocating specific funds through 2028.
Long summary:
Mandates the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support research and STEM education in advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems.

Supports fundamental research on technologies including AI, safety, autonomous control, materials, and communications systems.

Funds research on practical applications such as weather prediction, disaster response, and infrastructure monitoring.

Supports research on data modeling, validation, security, and ethical use, including privacy concerns.

Encourages middle and high school STEM education related to unmanned aircraft systems through curriculum development and student engagement activities.

Promotes undergraduate and graduate education through curriculum development, hands-on research opportunities, and scholarships.

Develops a skilled technical workforce, including veterans, through national centers and community college programs.

Facilitates public-private partnerships and interagency coordination to avoid research duplication.

Authorizes appropriations increasing from $50 million in 2024 to nearly $61 million in 2028.

Official name: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title VI ("Department of Energy Activities")
Casual name: Drone R&D Act, Title VI ("DOE Activities")
Short summary: Advances unmanned aircraft systems and AI technologies through research, education, and financial support. Establishes data management strategies and interagency coordination. Allocates funding through 2028 for eligible entities, including universities and private sector, to enhance DOE missions.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Energy to execute a cross-cutting research, development, and demonstration program for unmanned aircraft system (UAS) technologies, including artificial intelligence.

Requires coordination across relevant DOE offices, including the Artificial Intelligence Technology Office.

Formulates goals for UAS research, leveraging existing research and providing training in AI, machine learning, and related fields.

Establishes a data management strategy ensuring digital access, interoperability, and machine-readability.

Supports institutes to advance UAS and DOE missions.

Awards financial assistance for research in areas such as AI, autonomous operation, advanced algorithms, and multi-sensor fusion.

Promotes technology transfer by partnering with industry.

Makes available DOE research facilities and high-performance computing infrastructure.

Coordinates with other federal departments to avoid duplication and ensure complementary activities.

Authorizes appropriations totaling $276,282,638 from fiscal years 2024 to 2028.

Official name: National Drone and Advanced Air Mobility Research and Development Act, Title VII ("Department of Homeland Security Activities")
Casual name: Drone R&D Act, Title VII ("DHS Activities")
Short summary: Establishes research support for advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems, emphasizing cybersecurity, safety, and data management. Creates a Counter-UAS Center of Excellence. Allocates funding for research, development, and coordination with federal agencies to prevent duplicative efforts.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to support research, development, evaluation, and testing of advanced air mobility, unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), and counter-UAS systems.

Directs coordination with relevant Department of Homeland Security offices and programs, including the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency and U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

Requires production of standardized, secure, and privacy-protected data sets for advanced air mobility and UAS systems.

Supports establishing one or more Institutes to advance research in these fields.

Establishes a Counter-UAS Center of Excellence within the Department of Homeland Security.

Specifies selection criteria for host institutions, emphasizing past performance, geographic proximity to federal facilities, and capabilities in AI and machine learning.

Permits use of funds for fundamental research, evaluation, education, and training related to counter-UAS systems.

Sets the federal share of grants at no more than 75% of costs.

Authorizes appropriations totaling $30 million to $36.5 million from fiscal years 2024 to 2028.

Official name: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 101 ("Establishment of list of certain products receiving support from government of People's Republic of China pursuant to Made in China 2025 policy")
Casual name: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 101 ("List of products supported by PRC's Made in China 2025 policy")
Short summary: Requires the United States Trade Representative to annually list Chinese products, including AI, receiving government support under the Made in China 2025 policy. Identifies specific industries such as AI, robotics, and quantum computing for inclusion.
Long summary:
Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to establish a list of products supported by the Chinese government under the Made in China 2025 policy.

Requires the United States Trade Representative to compile this list within 120 days of the enactment and update it annually.

Mandates inclusion of products specified in key Chinese government documents related to Made in China 2025.

Includes products that displace net exports of similar U.S. products.

Enumerates specific industries such as civil aircraft, motor vehicles, advanced medical equipment, agricultural machinery, semiconductors, lithium batteries, artificial intelligence, high-capacity computing, quantum computing, robotics, and biotechnology for inclusion.

Official name: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 102 ("Prohibition on export to People's Republic of China of national security sensitive technology and intellectual property")
Casual name: Fair Trade with China Enforcement Act, Sec. 102 ("Prohibit export of national security sensitive technology and IP to PRC")
Short summary: Prohibits the Secretary of Commerce from exporting national security sensitive technology or intellectual property, including AI-related goods or services, to China. Defines such technology as contributing to China's military, harming U.S. security, economy, or involving critical production components.
Long summary:
Prohibits the Secretary of Commerce from exporting any national security sensitive technology or intellectual property to the People's Republic of China.

Defines "intellectual property" to include patents, copyrights, trademarks, or trade secrets.

Defines "national security sensitive technology or intellectual property" to include contributions to China's military, protection of U.S. economic security, and components of key products listed under the Trade Act of 1974.

Includes in "technology" goods or services related to information systems, internet-based services, production-enhancing logistics, robotics, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, or computing.

Official name: FAA Research and Development Act of 2023, Sec. 210 ("Technology review of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies")
Casual name: FAA R&D Act, Sec. 210 ("Review of AI and ML")
Short summary: Requires the Administrator to review AI and machine learning technologies for airport efficiency and safety. Includes examination of jet bridges, airport service vehicles, aircraft taxi, and other areas. Mandates a report to Congress within one year, including China's AI applications.
Long summary:
Requires the Administrator to conduct a review of current and planned AI and machine learning technologies to enhance airport efficiency and safety.

Mandates the review to cover applications of AI and machine learning in jet bridges, airport service vehicles, and aircraft taxiing.

Allows the Administrator to include other relevant areas that can improve airport efficiency and safety.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress within one year, detailing the review's findings.

Includes a required examination of China's domestic application of AI and machine learning technologies in the report.

Official name: FAA Research and Development Act of 2023, Sec. 215 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
Casual name: FAA R&D Act, Sec. 215 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
Short summary: Requires the assessment of AI, machine learning, and other technologies to improve air traffic control training. Develops a deployment timeline for these technologies. Involves collaboration with stakeholders. Obligates a report to Congress within one year.
Long summary:
Requires the Administrator to carry out a research program to modernize and streamline air traffic control training, subject to available appropriations.

Mandates the assessment of advanced technologies, including AI, machine learning, and virtual/augmented reality, to enhance knowledge retention and training effectiveness.

Develops a timeline for deploying proven advanced technologies and processes for accreditation in training programs and facilities.

Includes collaboration with labor organizations and other stakeholders in the research process.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress on the research findings within one year of the Act's enactment.

Official name: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 108 ("Computing Resources Prioritization")
Casual name: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 108 ("Computing Resources Prioritization")
Short summary: Amends Section 108 to require leveraging AI and machine learning for NOAA's missions. Establishes centers of excellence for AI advancements. Permits multi-year contracts for computing infrastructure. Mandates a report evaluating initiative effectiveness and needs for computing collaboration with the Department of Energy.
Long summary:
Amends the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act to mandate collaboration between the Under Secretary and the Secretary of Energy in leveraging high-performance computing and AI for advanced weather forecasting.

Requires a competitive, merit-reviewed process for initiative applications, including Federal agencies, National Laboratories, and higher education institutions.

Mandates coordination of AI and computing research across NOAA to avoid duplication and enhance predictive analysis.

Directs sharing of model innovations through community-based activities and interagency coordination.

Authorizes leveraging AI to enhance NOAA’s computing infrastructure for critical missions.

Allows establishment of centers of excellence for AI and machine learning in weather forecasting.

Permits multi-year contracts for high-performance and cloud computing systems.

Requires a report to Congress evaluating the initiative’s effectiveness and future computing needs within two years.

Official name: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 116(f) ("National Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Observing Network")
Casual name: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 116(f) ("Algal Bloom Observing Network")
Short summary: Integrates Federal, State, regional, and local capabilities to establish a national network for harmful algal bloom monitoring, incorporating artificial intelligence. Establishes a Harmful Algal Bloom Data Assembly Center for data integration and ecological forecasting support.
Long summary:
Amends Section 606 of the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act to establish a national harmful algal bloom observing network.

Requires the Under Secretary, via NCCOS and IOOS, to integrate Federal, State, regional, and local observing capabilities.

Mandates the use of emerging technologies and data integration methods, including artificial intelligence, for monitoring, detecting, and forecasting harmful algal blooms.

Instructs the IOOS Program Office to coordinate with NCCOS for observations, data integration, and information dissemination.

Establishes a Harmful Algal Bloom Data Assembly Center to integrate, disseminate, and support ecological forecasting.

Official name: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 304 ("Data Assimilation, Management, and Sharing Practices")
Casual name: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 304 ("Data Assimilation, Management, and Sharing")
Short summary: Establishes data standards and infrastructure to support open science and efficient data transfer, including AI for data assimilation. Forms a consortium to advance data assimilation research and workforce development. Conducts a study on data management needs and practices.
Long summary:
Establishes the requirement for the Under Secretary, in collaboration with the weather enterprise, to develop consistent and open data and metadata standards to support open science.

Mandates the consolidation and efficient arrangement of data infrastructure, considering commercial cloud technologies, to ensure effective data transfer between National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) offices.

Authorizes the Under Secretary to partner with other federal agencies to support cloud architecture transitions and data collocation.

Ensures the long-term management and stewardship of archival data acquired through the Commercial Data Program.

Requires the Under Secretary to facilitate data sharing with the weather enterprise, making data accessible to U.S. persons under certain conditions.

Instructs the establishment of a program to advance data assimilation methods, including AI and machine learning, and the creation of a university consortium to address research challenges in data assimilation.

Mandates a study on NOAA's data practices and management needs, assessing costs, benefits, and recommending improvements.

Official name: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 402 ("Hazardous Weather or Water Event Risk Communication")
Casual name: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 402 ("Hazardous Weather Risk Communication")
Short summary: Improves NOAA's communication system for hazardous weather risks using social, behavioral, and AI research. Simplifies terminology, enhances communication methods, and evaluates effectiveness. Coordinates with governmental and educational partners to ensure timely, consistent public information dissemination.
Long summary:
Amends Section 406 of the Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 to enhance communication about hazardous weather or water events.

Requires the Under Secretary to maintain and improve NOAA's system for communicating risks of hazardous weather or water events to the public.

Mandates the creation of a social, behavioral, risk, communication, and economic sciences program to simplify and improve communication of hazardous weather or water events.

Directs the program to eliminate or modify confusing terms and improve communication methods.

Instructs the program to develop metrics for evaluating the effectiveness of these communications.

Mandates the development of a support plan informed by research and communications evaluation.

Requires recommendations to be based on the latest social, behavioral, economic, risk, and communications science research, validated using rigorous methods, including AI and machine learning.

Ensures coordination with federal, state, local, tribal, educational, and media partners.

Establishes best practices for timely and consistent communications across public platforms.

Official name: Weather Act Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 502 ("National Integrated Drought Information System")
Casual name: Weather Act Reauthorization, Sec. 502 ("National Integrated Drought Information System")
Short summary: Amends the National Integrated Drought Information System to include AI, machine learning, and cloud technologies for drought monitoring and forecasting. Establishes partnerships for coordinated drought information and updates modeling to probabilistic forecasts. Authorizes specific appropriations for fiscal years 2024-2028.
Long summary:
Amends the National Integrated Drought Information System Act of 2006 to advance and deploy next-generation technologies related to drought, including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and cloud technologies.

Requires incorporation of flash drought research and tools to enhance timely response.

Mandates utilization of observational networks and refinement of drought indicators for decision-support products by optimizing data from across the Federal Government.

Establishes memoranda of understanding with the National Mesonet Program to provide coordinated, high-quality, nationwide drought information.

Directs the transition of existing drought products to probabilistic forecasts and incorporation of new dynamical and statistical forecast modeling tools.

Authorizes appropriations increasing annually from $15,000,000 in fiscal year 2024 to $17,000,000 in fiscal year 2028.

Official name: National Quantum Initiative Reauthorization Act, Sec. 16 ("Department of Energy Quantum Information Science Research Program")
Casual name: National Quantum Initiative Reauthorization Act, Sec. 16 ("DOE Quantum Information Science Research Program")
Short summary: Amends the National Quantum Initiative Act to require the Department of Energy to enhance quantum information science research, including AI integration. Establishes strategic planning, industry outreach, and funding of up to $130 million annually through 2027 for related activities.
Long summary:
Amends the National Quantum Initiative Act to mandate the Secretary of Energy to implement a quantum information science, engineering, and technology research program.

Establishes National Quantum Information Science Research Centers to enhance quantum technology and infrastructure.

Requires cooperative research initiatives with industry, National Laboratories, and academic institutions, covering AI, machine learning, quantum communications, sensing, and other quantum technologies.

Mandates providing research experiences and training for students in quantum fields.

Directs the creation of a 10-year strategic plan for quantum high-performance computing, integrating AI and machine learning, to be submitted to Congress.

Supports industry outreach to promote quantum technology commercialization and advancements in the energy sector.

Allocates up to $130 million annually from 2024 to 2027 for these activities.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 906 ("Programs for Next-Generation Microelectronics in Support of Artificial Intelligence")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 906 ("Next-Generation Microelectronics for AI")
Short summary: Establishes a program to advance microelectronics research supporting AI. Focuses on next-generation computing models and overcoming microelectronics challenges. Requires collaboration with government, academia, and industry. Authorizes appropriations for contracts and grants. Mandates regular congressional briefings on progress.
Long summary:
Establishes a program to advance microelectronics research, overseen by the Director of National Intelligence through the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity.

Focuses research on next-generation computing models, materials, devices, architectures, and algorithms to enhance artificial intelligence and machine learning.

Addresses challenges in microelectronics engineering, including physical limits on transistors, interconnects, and memory elements.

Promotes advancements in computing technologies through multidisciplinary research, encompassing algorithm design, compute capability, generative AI, photonics-based microprocessors, new materials, optical networks, and AI safety for the intelligence community.

Requires active collaboration with government agencies, academic institutions, and private industry.

Authorizes appropriations for contracts, grants, and other transactions to support the program.

Mandates regular briefings to congressional intelligence committees on program progress, partnerships, and future research priorities.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 909 ("Requirement to Ensure Intelligence Community Directives Appropriately Account for Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Tools in Intelligence Products")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 909 ("Ensure IC Directives Account for AI and ML Tools in Intelligence Products")
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief Congress on AI and machine learning guidance in intelligence products within 120 days. Determines whether existing directives provide sufficient guidance and whether updates are necessary, including explanations or update plans and timelines.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief congressional intelligence committees within 120 days on whether current intelligence community directives provide sufficient guidance on the use of AI and machine learning tools in intelligence products.

Mandates the briefing to include a determination of whether Intelligence Community Directives 203 and 206, and other relevant directives, offer adequate guidance on using, sourcing, and providing transparency for AI and machine learning tools.

Requires the Director to assess if these directives need updates to enhance guidance and direction.

Obligates the Director to explain why no updates are needed if deemed sufficient, or to provide a plan and timeline for necessary updates if improvements are required.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Title V ("Matters Pertaining to United States Economic and Emerging Technology Competition with United States Adversaries"), Subtitle B ("Next Generation Energy, Biotechnology, and Artificial Intelligence")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Title V ("Emerging Technology Competition"), Subtitle B ("Next Generation AI")
Short summary: Amends intelligence assessments to include China's AI investments and establishes policies for AI capabilities within the intelligence community. Requires a strategy for notifying federal agencies about AI-related risks, including information security and biosecurity threats, by vendors and researchers.
Long summary:
**Subtitle B—Next-Generation Energy, Biotechnology, And Artificial Intelligence**

**SEC. 511. Expanded Annual Assessment of Economic and Technological Capabilities of the People's Republic of China.**

Requires a detailed assessment of China’s investments in AI, next-generation energy technologies, and biotechnology.

Identifies competitive practices and opportunities to counter them.

Determines U.S. vulnerabilities in the supply chain of these technologies.

**SEC. 514. Policies Established by Director of National Intelligence for Artificial Intelligence Capabilities.**

Mandates the establishment of policies for AI acquisition, adoption, development, use, coordination, and maintenance.

Requires guidelines for evaluating AI model performance, continuous monitoring, and documentation.

Calls for standards on imputed, augmented, or synthetic data used in AI training.

**SEC. 515. Strategy for Submittal of Notice by Private Persons to Federal Agencies Regarding Certain Risks and Threats Relating to Artificial Intelligence.**

Directs the President to establish a strategy for vendors and users to notify the government of AI-related risks.

Includes information security, biosecurity risks, foreign malign influence, and other unlawful activities related to AI.

Outlines a plan for Federal agencies to engage in public education on AI risks.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Sec. 758 ("Implementation of Technology for Classification and Declassification")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2024, Sec. 758 ("Technology for Classification and Declassification")
Short summary: Requires the Administrator to research AI and machine learning solutions for federal classification and declassification. Mandates submission of a technology recommendation to the President. Obligates the President to report to Congress on the recommended solution and adoption decision.
Long summary:
Requires the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government to research a technology-based solution using machine learning and artificial intelligence for efficient classification and declassification systems within 1 year.

Mandates consultation with various key agencies, including the Secretary of Defense and CIA Director, to ensure a comprehensive approach.

Calls for the solution to be interoperable and federated across the Federal Government.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a recommendation to the President regarding the adoption of the researched technology-based solution.

Permits the Administrator to hire sufficient staff to execute the tasks outlined.

Directs the President to submit a classified report to Congress within 540 days, detailing the recommended solution and the decision on its adoption.

Official name: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 303 ("Task force to address artificial intelligence-enabled influence operations")
Casual name: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 303 ("AI-enabled influence operations task force")
Short summary: Establishes a task force to counter AI-enabled disinformation, coordinate with academia and industry, and develop digital content provenance techniques. Requires reporting on progress and collaboration with international bodies to protect national security and mitigate AI misuse.
Long summary:
Establishes a Countering AI-Enabled Disinformation Task Force within 180 days to identify responses to AI-enabled disinformation threats.

Requires the Task Force to collaborate with private industry and academia to develop digital content provenance detection techniques.

Mandates internal coordination within the Department on AI-enabled disinformation issues.

Directs the Task Force to create a unified international approach for standards and frameworks to counter AI-enabled disinformation.

Requires the Task Force to identify necessary tools and resources for detecting AI-enabled disinformation, producing counter-messaging, expanding digital literacy, and coordinating with various stakeholders.

Mandates a report to Congress within one year on the Task Force’s establishment and progress.

Involves representatives from various relevant offices in the Task Force.

Defines key terms including "artificial intelligence" and "digital content provenance."

Official name: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 304 ("Establishment of the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of State")
Casual name: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 304 ("DOS Chief AI Officer")
Short summary: Establishes a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer within the Department of State to oversee AI adoption and advise on ethical AI use. Requires collaboration with the Chief Information Officer for scaling AI. Defines AI per the National Defense Authorization Act.
Long summary:
Establishes within the Department of State a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer (CAIO), potentially dual-hatted as the Department’s Chief Data Officer, and a member of the Senior Executive Service.

Requires the CAIO to evaluate, oversee, and facilitate the responsible adoption of AI and machine learning to inform decisions and support programs and operations.

Designates the CAIO as the principal advisor to the Secretary of State on the ethical use of AI and advanced analytics in diplomacy.

Mandates the CAIO to possess skills in data analytics, AI, machine learning, and organizational change management.

Requires the Chief Information Officer to consult with the CAIO on scaling AI capabilities across software applications.

Defines “artificial intelligence” as per section 238(g) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2019.

Official name: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 931 ("Priority for Australia and the United Kingdom in Foreign Military Sales and Direct Commercial Sales")
Casual name: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 931 ("Priority for Australia and UK in Military Sales")
Short summary: Establishes expedited processing for AI technology transfers to Australia, the UK, and Canada under AUKUS. Requires anticipatory release policy for AI and related technologies in military sales. Mandates interagency review and update of related policies and guidance.
Long summary:
Requires the President to institute expedited policies for defense article and service requests from Australia and the United Kingdom under the AUKUS partnership.

Mandates prioritization of these requests over all others, except those from Taiwan and Ukraine.

Instructs the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, to establish an anticipatory release policy for technology transfers to Australia, the UK, and Canada.

Specifies the inclusion of technologies related to submarines, combat systems, hypersonic missiles, cyber capabilities, artificial intelligence, quantum technologies, and other advanced technologies.

Subjects technology transfer reviews to an expedited decision-making process.

Directs the Secretary and the Secretary of Defense to update interagency policies and guidance to incorporate these anticipatory release provisions.

Official name: Department of State Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 941 ("Reporting Related to the AUKUS Partnership")
Casual name: Department of State Authorization Act, Sec. 941 ("Reporting Related to AUKUS")
Short summary: Requires the President to report non-binding instruments related to the AUKUS partnership. Mandates biennial reports on AI and other tech collaboration under Pillar Two, assessing efforts in AI, quantum, cyber, and other advanced capabilities.
Long summary:
Mandates the President to submit the text of any non-binding instrument related to the AUKUS partnership to appropriate congressional committees within 30 days of finalization.

Excludes the need to resubmit texts already submitted under other legal provisions, while not relieving other legal submission requirements.

Defines "text" to include all related annexes, appendices, side agreements, and implementing documents.

Requires the Secretary, in coordination with other officials, to submit a biennial report on the AUKUS partnership starting one year after enactment.

Specifies that reports must cover defensive capability gaps, costs, industrial base contributions, military benefits, and assessments of Australia’s nuclear submarine contributions.

Demands updates on progress for Australia’s nuclear submarine development, infrastructure, workforce training, and support facilities.

Requires assessments of trilateral collaboration efforts in areas including underseas capabilities, quantum technologies, AI and autonomy, advanced cyber capabilities, hypersonic technologies, electronic warfare, innovation, and information sharing.

Official name: Advanced Safe Testing at Residence Telehealth Act of 2023, Sec. 2 ("Coverage and Payment for Certain Tests and Assistive Telehealth Consultations; Demonstration Program Under Certain State Medicaid Programs")
Casual name: Testing at Residence Telehealth Act, Sec. 2 ("Tests and Assistive Telehealth Consultations Demonstration")
Short summary: Establishes a Value-Based Insurance Design Model for Medicare, covering AI-driven wearable medical devices and assistive telehealth. Limits demonstration to 25 plans, promoting rural access, and requires demographic data for reimbursement. Allocates funding for state Medicaid telehealth programs.
Long summary:
Establishes a Value-Based Insurance Design Model (VBID) demonstration program to provide Medicare beneficiaries with assistive telehealth consultations and home-based care.

Requires eligible Medicare Advantage (MA) plans to cover medical tests, including those utilizing adaptive AI and machine learning, for various diseases and conditions.

Limits the VBID program to a maximum of 25 MA plans, with at least 10 plans serving rural or underserved areas.

Mandates demographic data collection for reimbursement claims, including age, race, ethnicity, gender, and chronic conditions.

Administers a grant program for state Medicaid programs to cover similar tests and telehealth consultations, with grants awarded to 5-10 states or territories for a 4-year period, not exceeding $12 million per state.

Official name: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2023, Sec. 212 ("Report on Establishment of an Unmanned Systems Capabilities Office")
Casual name: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Sec. 212 ("Unmanned Systems Capabilities Office")
Short summary: Requires the Commandant to report on establishing a Coast Guard office for developing and acquiring unmanned and counter-unmanned systems. Details management, coordination, contracting strategies, and collaboration with federal agencies, and emphasizes integrating AI and machine learning tools in operations.
Long summary:
Requires the Commandant to submit a report within one year outlining a plan for establishing an unmanned systems capabilities office within the Coast Guard.

Mandates inclusion of a management strategy for acquiring, developing, and deploying unmanned system and counter-unmanned system technologies.

Demands a coordination strategy to synchronize efforts across the Coast Guard and pursue expanded research, development, testing, and evaluation opportunities.

Requires identification of contracting and acquisition authorities needed for expedited technology development and deployment.

Lists the need for a detailed inventory of commercially available unmanned and counter-unmanned systems useful to the Coast Guard.

Calls for a cross-agency collaboration plan with the Department of Homeland Security, Department of Defense, and other relevant agencies.

Encourages opportunities to obtain and share unmanned system data to enhance maritime domain awareness.

Mandates the development of a concept of operations for a data ecosystem integrating unmanned system technologies with AI, machine learning, and information-sharing capabilities.

Official name: Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness and Response Act, Sec. 407 ("Assessment of Artificial Intelligence Threats to Health Security")
Casual name: Pandemic Preparedness and Response Act, Sec. 407 ("AI Threats to Health Security")
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to contract the National Academies to assess AI vulnerabilities to health security. Includes roles, responsibilities, and risk mitigation recommendations. Mandates reports to Congress on findings and subsequent health security actions.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to seek a contract with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to conduct a study on AI-related health security vulnerabilities within 45 days of enactment.

Mandates the study to assess risks posed by AI advancements, including chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear threats.

Describes roles and capabilities of HHS agencies and other Federal entities in identifying and mitigating these vulnerabilities.

Summarizes ongoing Federal activities related to these risks.

Identifies current or anticipated gaps in roles, responsibilities, and capabilities regarding AI-related health security.

Provides recommendations for improving Federal efforts to address these vulnerabilities.

Requires the National Academies to submit a report on the study to relevant Senate and House committees within 2 years.

Mandates the Secretary of HHS to submit a follow-up report on actions taken to mitigate AI-related health security risks within 1 year after the National Academies' report.

Official name: NTIA Reauthorization Act of 2023, Sec. 203 ("Spectrum management improvements")
Casual name: NTIA Reauthorization Act, Sec. 203 ("Spectrum management improvements")
Short summary: Develops and supports AI systems for advanced antenna arrays and dynamic spectrum access. Encourages workforce development and partnerships for prototyping advanced communications technologies. Identifies spectrum management technologies like dynamic spectrum access and network sensing for Federal frequency assignments.
Long summary:
Requires the Under Secretary, in coordination with the Commission and in consultation with other relevant Federal agencies, to develop, establish, prototype, and support the implementation of models, methodologies, and inputs for spectrum management decisions involving AI systems, advanced antenna arrays, and dynamic spectrum access technologies.

Mandates the development of AI systems to enable dynamic spectrum access, Internet of Things networks, and other advanced communications technologies.

Amends Section 104 of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to require the identification and facilitation of technologies that promote dynamic spectrum access, network sensing and monitoring, and optical and quantum communications.

Encourages the development of a skilled workforce for prototyping advanced communications technologies.

Supports partnerships among institutions for workforce development in advanced communications technology prototyping.

Official name: Atomic Energy Advancement Act, Sec. 123 ("Advancement of Nuclear Regulatory Oversight")
Casual name: Atomic Energy Advancement Act, Sec. 123 ("Nuclear Regulatory Oversight")
Short summary: Advances nuclear regulatory oversight by encouraging the use of AI and machine learning to enhance risk-informed oversight and inspection decisions. Promotes efficiency through improved technology integration and staff training, while assessing and enabling licensee adoption of advanced technologies.
Long summary:
Requires the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to report to Congress on actions taken during the COVID-19 emergency, including revised or suspended regulatory policies and their impacts.

Mandates NRC to develop a report within one year identifying improvements in nuclear oversight and inspections using risk-informed, performance-based procedures, information technologies, and AI.

Obligates NRC to seek input from stakeholders like the Secretary of Energy, National Laboratories, and the nuclear energy industry.

Directs NRC to assess the use of AI and machine learning to enhance oversight and inspection decisions.

Instructs NRC to identify specific actions for incorporating advanced technologies into their activities without compromising their mission.

Official name: DEEPFAKES Accountability Act, Sec. 2 ("Transparency Requirements")
Casual name: DEEPFAKES Accountability Act, Sec. 2 ("Transparency Requirements")
Short summary: Amends U.S. Code to require disclosures for AI-generated false personation records. Imposes criminal and civil penalties for non-compliance. Establishes private rights of action and privacy protections. Mandates content provenance technologies. Designates coordinators for foreign and intimate deepfake violations. Defines related terms.
Long summary:
Amends Title 18, U.S. Code, to add transparency requirements for advanced technological false personation records (deepfakes).

Requires producers of such records to include content provenance technologies to identify alterations and disclosures detailing the extent of alterations.

Mandates specific disclosure formats for audiovisual, visual, and audio records.

Imposes criminal penalties, including fines and imprisonment up to 5 years, for non-compliance, especially in cases involving harassment, violence, fraud, or foreign influence.

Imposes civil penalties up to $150,000 per violation and allows for private rights of action for damages and injunctive relief.

Defines advanced technological false personation records and includes provisions for privacy protections and advisory opinions.

Establishes coordinators for deepfake-related violations in each U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Requires a report on enforcement trends and the impact of deepfakes on public policy and marginalized communities.

Official name: AREA Act, Part B ("National Center for Education Research"), Sec. 133 ("Duties")
Casual name: AREA Act, Part B ("National Center for Education Research"), Sec. 133 ("Duties")
Short summary: Amends duties of the Research Commissioner to support AI and digital literacy research, coordinate evidence use, and advance educational technology. Mandates AI-focused studies on educational technology, including developing evidence-based practices and supporting research-practice partnerships with AI considerations.
Long summary:
Amends the duties of the Research Commissioner to include maintaining peer-review standards and supporting scientifically valid research.

Requires the Commissioner to propose and implement a research plan, ensuring the research is relevant and informs decision-making.

Mandates the support of evidence-based practices and the dissemination of research findings.

Grants authority to conduct research on underrepresented student populations and to support research-practice partnerships.

Obligates the Commissioner to ensure research is reviewed for inclusion in the National Education Research Database.

Allows for the provision of technical assistance to underrepresented researchers and institutions.

Supports research on educational technology, including artificial intelligence, digital literacy, and other significant educational topics.

Official name: Health Care Price Transparency Act of 2023, Sec. 301 ("Establishing Requirements With Respect to the Use of Prior Authorization Under Medicare Advantage Plans")
Casual name: Health Care Price Transparency Act, Sec. 301 ("Requirements Regarding Prior Authorization Under Medicare Advantage Plans")
Short summary: Establishes electronic prior authorization programs for Medicare Advantage plans, requiring real-time decisions and transparency. Specifies enrollee protection standards, timely response requirements, and detailed reporting, including AI use. Mandates reports to Congress evaluating implementation and challenges.
Long summary:
Requires Medicare Advantage plans to establish an electronic prior authorization program by the third plan year after the enactment date.

Mandates that plans meet enrollee protection standards and transparency requirements by the fourth plan year.

Establishes a secure electronic transmission system for prior authorization requests and responses, excluding certain forms like facsimiles and non-compliant payer portals.

Specifies that real-time decisions must be made for certain prior authorization requests, with exceptions for extenuating circumstances.

Demands detailed annual reporting of prior authorization data, including the use of AI and decision-support technologies, and the publication of this information by the Secretary.

Calls for GAO and HHS to submit reports to Congress evaluating the implementation and impact of these requirements.

Official name: Online Privacy Act of 2023, Sec. 106 ("Right to individual autonomy")
Casual name: Online Privacy Act, Sec. 106 ("Individual autonomy")
Short summary: Prohibits collecting, processing, maintaining, or disclosing personal information for behavioral personalization without consent. Requires annual consent renewals. Mandates non-personalized versions if consent is denied. Allows service denial if non-personalization is infeasible. Exempts small businesses.
Long summary:
Prohibits covered entities from collecting, processing, maintaining, or disclosing personal information for behavioral personalization without affirmative express consent.

Requires covered entities to obtain express affirmative consent before providing behaviorally personalized products or services, and annually thereafter.

Mandates providing non-personalized versions of products or services if consent is denied, or core aspects if full functionality without personalization is infeasible.

Allows denial of products or services if no core aspect can function without personalization and consent is not given.

Permits processing personal information for usability improvements using aggregated data, provided the output is uniform and independent of individual characteristics.

Excludes optimizations aimed primarily at increasing user engagement time from the definition of "usability."

Exempts small businesses from these requirements.

Official name: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 1024 ("Technology Review of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Technologies")
Casual name: American Aviation Act, Sec. 1024 ("Review of AI and ML Technologies")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Conducts a review of AI and machine learning to enhance airport efficiency and safety. Considers best practices and international coordination. Examines AI applications in jet bridges, service vehicles, aircraft taxi, and air traffic control. Reports findings to Congress within a year.
Long summary:
Requires the Administrator to conduct a review of current and planned AI and machine learning technologies to enhance airport efficiency and safety.

Allows the Administrator to consider best practices and lessons learned from domestic and international AI and machine learning applications.

Permits coordination with other Federal agencies to identify China's use of AI and machine learning in airport operations.

Mandates the review to include AI and machine learning applications in jet bridges, airport service vehicles, aircraft taxi, air traffic control operations, and other areas deemed necessary by the Administrator.

Obligates the Administrator to submit a report to Congress within one year detailing the review's findings.

Official name: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 1028 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
Casual name: American Aviation Act, Sec. 1028 ("Air Traffic Control Training")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires the Administrator to assess AI and other advanced technologies for enhancing air traffic controller training. Involves collaboration with labor organizations. Obligates a report to Congress on research findings within one year.
Long summary:
Mandates the Administrator to carry out a research program to modernize, enhance, and streamline on-the-job training for FAA air traffic controllers.

Requires the assessment of benefits from advanced technologies, including AI, machine learning, adaptive computer-based simulation, virtual reality, and augmented reality, for improving training effectiveness, knowledge retention, and safety.

Includes collaboration with labor organizations and other stakeholders in the research program.

Obligates the Administrator to report findings to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment.

Clarifies that the section does not delay the installation of tower simulation systems at FAA air traffic facilities.
