Official name: Securing Growth and Robust Leadership in American Aviation Act, Sec. 908 ("Part 107 Waiver Improvements")
Casual name: American Aviation Act, Sec. 908 ("Part 107 Waiver Improvements")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Adopts a performance- and risk-based approach for waiver requests. Prohibits open-ended prompts unless necessary. Utilizes big data and machine learning for waiver data. Publishes waivers online, protecting proprietary info. Expedites similar waiver modifications and renewals. Considers property access control.
Long summary:
Adopts a performance- and risk-based approach for reviewing waiver requests under section 107.200 of title 14, CFR.

Improves the waiver application process and prohibits the use of open-ended descriptive prompts, except for unusual or irregular operations.

Leverages data, including big data analytics and machine learning, from previous waiver requests.

Requires consideration of control over access to real property within the operation area and recognizes safety enhancements from such control.

Publishes all issued certificates of waiver on the FAA website, including terms, conditions, limitations, and airspace class, while protecting proprietary information.

Allows streamlined approval for waiver applications substantially similar to previously approved ones.

Establishes an expedited review process for modifying or renewing previously issued waivers.

Official name: Lummis-Gillibrand Responsible Financial Innovation Act, Sec. 1001 ("Executive Office of the President Appropriations")
Casual name: Responsible Financial Innovation Act, Sec. 1001 ("EOP Appropriations")
Short summary: Authorize appropriations for AI-related specialist positions in the Office of Science and Technology Policy and the National Economic Council, each receiving $2.5 million annually from 2023 to 2027, to coordinate federal activities and advise on innovative technologies.
Long summary:
Authorize appropriations of $2,500,000 annually from fiscal years 2023 to 2027 to the Office of Science and Technology Policy for hiring specialists in AI, crypto assets, and distributed ledger technology, available until the end of the subsequent fiscal year.

Require these funds to support positions coordinating Federal activities and advising the President on research and development strategies related to these technologies.

Authorize similar appropriations of $2,500,000 annually from fiscal years 2023 to 2027 to the National Economic Council for hiring specialists in AI, crypto assets, and distributed ledger technology, also available until the end of the subsequent fiscal year.

Require these funds to support positions coordinating Federal activities and advising the President on financial and economic policies related to these technologies.

Official name: GRIData Act of 2024
Casual name: GRIData Act
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Energy to identify, analyze, and share data to improve electric grid reliability and resilience. Considers AI and machine learning for enhancing grid operations. Establishes a steering committee and mandates reports and websites for data dissemination.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Energy to identify, analyze, and share data to improve the reliability and resilience of the electric grid.

Mandates the Secretary to consider data types, temporal frequency, and spatial resolution, especially in rural, low-income, and disadvantaged communities.

Requires collaboration with National Laboratories, NOAA, and other agencies for weather data relevant to grid reliability and resilience.

Considers the use of emerging technologies, including AI and machine learning, to enhance grid reliability and resilience.

Establishes a steering committee with stakeholders from federal agencies, regulators, and the electric power sector to guide data-related activities.

Mandates the submission of a report to Congress within one year, detailing findings and recommendations for data collection and sharing.

Authorizes $10 million for the first fiscal year to support these activities.

Official name: Export Controls Enforcement Improvement Act of 2024
Casual name: Export Controls Enforcement Improvement Act
Short summary: Establishes the Export Enforcement Coordination Center to coordinate U.S. export control enforcement, focusing on AI and other sensitive technologies. Requires developing best practices to combat unlawful export transshipment. Authorizes $25 million for fiscal year 2025 establishment costs.
Long summary:
Establishes the Export Enforcement Coordination Center within the Department of Homeland Security to coordinate export enforcement among various federal departments and agencies.

Focuses the Center's efforts on sensitive technologies, including advanced artificial intelligence capabilities, semiconductors, and quantum technology.

Designates the Center as the primary forum for coordinating efforts against unlawful transshipment and diversion of exports, particularly to countries like China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.

Requires the Center to develop best practices and disseminate actionable information to the private sector about export control risks.

Mandates the submission of reports to Congress on the value and logistics of posting U.S. and foreign law enforcement officials to enhance export control enforcement. 

Authorizes $25,000,000 for the establishment of the Center for fiscal year 2025.

Official name: American Economic Independence Act of 2024
Casual name: American Economic Independence Act
Short summary: Requires regular reports on U.S.-China economic integration, assessing national security risks, including reliance on Chinese AI. Mandates analysis of risks like intellectual property theft and defense industrial base threats. Recommends mitigation steps and involves key government officials in the evaluation process.
Long summary:
Requires the President, through the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, to submit a report to Congress on the state of economic integration between the U.S. and China, and the national security risks posed by this integration, every three years for 15 years.

Mandates each report to assess the level of economic integration and its changes since 2000, with predictions for the next three years, specifically in priority sectors including artificial intelligence.

Includes analysis of risks such as reliance on Chinese entities, supply chain dependencies, intellectual property theft, and impacts on the U.S. defense industrial base, particularly in the AI sector.

Requires recommendations for mitigating identified risks.

Permits consultation with nongovernmental entities and submission of the report in an unclassified form, potentially with a classified annex.

Official name: CONSENT Act
Casual name: CONSENT Act
Short summary: Establishes a private right of action against individuals sending unsolicited explicit visual depictions. Defines “machine-manipulated media” as AI-modified. Permits recipients to sue for damages and attorney fees. Exempts third-party providers and certain senders. Allows legal guardians to sue for minors. Permits minors to use initials for privacy. Ensures civil remedies do not supersede criminal laws. Includes severability clause.
Long summary:
Establishes a private right of action against individuals who send unsolicited visual depictions of sexually explicit conduct.

Defines “machine-manipulated media” as media substantially modified using machine-learning techniques.

Permits recipients to bring civil actions for statutory damages up to $500, compensatory damages for emotional distress, attorney fees, and injunctive relief.

Exempts third-party providers, good faith medical, educational, or law enforcement senders, and lawful adult websites from liability.

Allows legal guardians to sue on behalf of minors, incompetent, or incapacitated individuals.

Permits plaintiffs who were minors at the time of the incident to use initials for privacy in court documents.

Ensures civil remedies do not modify or supersede criminal laws.

Includes a severability clause to maintain the act’s provisions if parts are deemed unconstitutional.

Official name: Department of Defense Financial Audits Using Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: DoD Financial Audits Using AI Act
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Defense to use AI technology for auditing the Department of Defense's 2024 financial statements. Requires AI development to improve audits and replace outdated systems. Mandates surplus funds' rescission and briefing on audit progress and AI technology.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to ensure the fiscal year 2024 audit of the Department of Defense's financial statements uses AI technology.

Requires the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) and the Inspector General to jointly develop the necessary AI technology for facilitating these audits.

Mandates the use of this AI technology to accelerate the retirement of older financial management systems without compromising essential controls or auditing standards.

Orders the rescission and deposit of any identified surplus funds from the audit into the General Fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction.

Obliges the Secretary of Defense to brief the Senate and House Committees on Armed Services within 180 days on the audit's progress and the AI technology development.

Official name: Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act
Casual name: Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act
Short summary: Establishes governance requirements for Federal AI systems, ensuring actions align with laws, promote fairness, manage risks, and maintain transparency. Mandates AI charters, oversight, and compliance assessments, with provisions for public disclosure, privacy protection, and periodic evaluations.
Long summary:
Amends chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code, to establish Federal AI system governance requirements.

Requires Federal AI actions to align with the Constitution, laws, and policies on civil rights and privacy.

Mandates the assessment and responsible management of AI risks, ensuring fair and impartial treatment.

Ensures AI applications are accurate, ethical, reliable, and secure.

Demands transparency and explainability of AI systems' purpose, operations, and outcomes.

Imposes accountability for human roles in AI management and documentation of AI actions.

Obligates regular testing and oversight of AI applications, including mechanisms to deactivate inconsistent AI systems.

Instructs agencies to publicly disclose AI use and establish notification and appeal processes for AI-based decisions.

Sets up a Federal AI System Inventory for cataloging agency AI governance charters.

Requires independent evaluations of AI governance compliance every two years.

Official name: Comment Integrity and Management Act of 2024
Casual name: Comment Integrity and Management Act
Short summary: Amends the E-Government Act to require verification of human origin for electronic comments, identify mass and AI-generated comments, and allow agencies to post representative samples. Directs OMB to issue guidance for managing these comments and mandates policy updates.
Long summary:
Amends the E-Government Act of 2002 to improve the handling of mass and computer-generated comments in the regulatory review process.

Requires agencies to verify whether electronic comments are submitted by humans.

Mandates agencies to identify and label mass comments and allows agencies to post representative samples of these comments.

Directs the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on verifying human submissions and managing mass comments, including the use of technology tools.

Obliges agencies to establish and publicly post policies on handling computer-generated and mass comments within one year of enactment.

Compels the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to report on the identification and impact of computer-generated comments within two years.

Official name: Promoting United States Leadership in Standards Act of 2024
Casual name: US Leadership in Standards Act
Short summary: Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology to increase U.S. participation in AI standards development. Establishes a pilot program to support U.S. meetings on AI standards. Requires web portal creation and congressional briefings on progress and effectiveness.
Long summary:
Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to brief Congress on opportunities for U.S. participation in developing AI standards within one year.

Requires the establishment of a web portal to inform U.S. industry and federal agencies about international AI standards efforts and participation opportunities.

Mandates federal agencies to report their participation in AI standards activities using a mechanism developed by the NIST.

Initiates a pilot program to support U.S.-based AI standards meetings through grants to eligible entities, with funding covering up to 50% of meeting costs.

Authorizes $10 million for the pilot program from fiscal years 2024 through 2028.

Official name: Americas Act, Title II ("Trade and Investment for the Americas"), Sec. 255 ("Transformational Energy Development")
Casual name: Americas Act, Title II ("Trade and Investment"), Sec. 255 ("Energy Development")
Short summary: Establishes a Chief Energy Officer to promote transformational energy technologies, including AI, in energy infrastructure. Requires 30% of project support for these technologies. Mandates annual reporting on such projects. Creates a database for international energy finance coordination.
Long summary:
Amends the BUILD Act of 2018 to define "transformational energy technology," including AI applications for energy efficiency and grid operation.

Inserts a Chief Energy Officer position within the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to promote transformational energy technology exports and ensure at least 30% of DFC support targets such projects.

Requires annual and quarterly reports on transformational energy technology projects and international finance of energy generation.

Establishes an Office of Energy in the Export-Import Bank to promote and finance exports of eligible technologies, including those involving AI.

Mandates the creation of a Joint Energy Export, Development, and Trade Database to coordinate inter-agency efforts.

Increases the DFC's maximum contingent liability and adjusts the Export-Import Bank’s loan, guarantee, and insurance authority limits.

Official name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VI ("Rural Development"), Sec. 6303 ("Promoting Precision Agriculture")
Casual name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VI ("Rural Development"), Sec. 6303 ("Precision Agriculture")
Short summary: Requires the Secretary to develop voluntary interconnectivity standards for precision agriculture, considering AI impacts. Directs coordination with industry and government stakeholders. Mandates GAO to assess these standards biannually for 8 years, evaluating voluntary adoption and industry coordination.
Long summary:
Promotes United States leadership in developing standards for precision agriculture.

Mandates the Secretary to develop voluntary, consensus-based interconnectivity standards for precision agriculture within two years.

Requires consultation with NIST, FCC, public, and private stakeholders, including voluntary consensus standards development organizations.

Considers the impact of advanced wireless communications technology and artificial intelligence on precision agriculture.

Addresses cybersecurity challenges and connectivity needs of precision agriculture technology.

Directs the Comptroller General to assess the developed standards one year after implementation and biennially for eight years.

Obligates the Comptroller General to report findings to relevant Senate and House committees.

Official name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VII ("Research, Extension, and Related Matters"), Sec. 7208 ("Centers of Excellence")
Casual name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VII ("Research and Extension"), Sec. 7208 ("Centers of Excellence")
Short summary: Establishes centers of excellence for research on digital agriculture, including AI and remote sensing. Requires partnerships to enhance coordination and address agricultural challenges. Mandates annual reporting on projects, funding, and intellectual property actions. Extends program duration to 2029.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to establish at least one center of excellence to conduct research, extension, and education activities.

Designates eligible host institutions, including land-grant colleges and accredited veterinary schools, and requires geographic diversity in selection.

Limits each institution to host or co-host only one center at a time.

Requires partnerships with federal agencies, state governments, higher education institutions, and agricultural industry groups to enhance coordination and cost-effectiveness.

Focuses on multiple areas, including digital agriculture, artificial intelligence, agricultural biosecurity, cybersecurity, precision agriculture technologies, biotechnology, and crop protection.

Prohibits using funds for new construction or facility alterations.

Requires an annual report on projects, funding, institutional participation, cost-sharing, and intellectual property actions to relevant Congressional committees.

Expands the number of centers from 3 to 8 and extends the program's authorization to 2029.

Official name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024, Title VIII ("Forestry"), Sec. 8414 ("Public-Private Wildfire Technology Deployment and Testbed Partnership")
Casual name: Farm, Food, and National Security Act, Title VIII ("Forestry"), Sec. 8414 ("Wildfire Technology Deployment and Testbed Partnership")
Short summary: Establishes a pilot program for deploying and testing wildfire prevention technologies, prioritizing AI and emerging technologies. Requires collaboration between federal agencies and private entities. Mandates annual reports on technologies tested and potential large-scale adoption. Program expires September 30, 2029.
Long summary:
Establishes a deployment and testbed pilot program for new and innovative wildfire prevention, detection, communication, and mitigation technologies.

Requires incorporation of the Pilot Program into an existing interagency coordinating group on wildfires.

Mandates consultation with covered agencies to identify key technology priority areas.

Partners with selected covered entities for real-time and on-the-ground testing of technology during wildfire mitigation activities.

Prioritizes emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence, quantum sensing, and augmented reality, for wildfire mitigation.

Requires submission of annual reports to appropriate committees, detailing participating entities, tested technologies, costs, outreach efforts, and assessments.

Expires the Pilot Program on September 30, 2029.

Official name: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2024, Title II ("Coast Guard"), Sec. 207 ("Report on establishment of unmanned systems capabilities office")
Casual name: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Title II ("Coast Guard"), Sec. 207 ("unmanned systems capabilities office")
Short summary: Require the Coast Guard to report on establishing an office for unmanned systems technologies. Include strategies for management, service-wide coordination, contracting, collaboration, and data sharing. Develop operational concepts integrating AI and machine learning tools.
Long summary:
Mandates the Commandant to submit a report within one year outlining a plan for establishing an unmanned systems capabilities office within the Coast Guard.

Requires the report to include a management strategy for the acquisition, development, and deployment of unmanned and counter-unmanned system technologies.

Specifies the need for a service-wide coordination strategy to synchronize efforts across the Coast Guard.

Identifies contracting and acquisition authorities necessary to expedite technology development and deployment.

Lists commercially available technologies useful for the Coast Guard.

Calls for a cross-agency collaboration plan with the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Defense, and other relevant agencies.

Highlights opportunities to share unmanned system data to improve maritime domain awareness.

Requires the development of a concept of operations for a data ecosystem supporting unmanned systems, including AI and machine learning tools.

Official name: Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2024, Title III ("Shipping and Navigation"), Sec. 342 ("Establishment of National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems")
Casual name: Coast Guard Authorization Act, Title III ("Shipping and Navigation"), Sec. 342 ("Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems")
Short summary: Establishes a National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems to advise on regulation and use within U.S. waters. Requires 9 expert members representing diverse maritime sectors, including marine safety, vessel design, and unmanned vehicle research, appointed by the Secretary.
Long summary:
Establishes the National Advisory Committee on Autonomous Maritime Systems.

Advises the Secretary on regulation and use of Autonomous Systems within U.S. territorial waters.

Comprises 9 members appointed by the Secretary with relevant expertise.

Ensures representation from various groups, including marine safety, vessel design, unmanned vehicle production, port authorities, vessel operators, labor unions, maritime pilots, commercial space operators, and academic institutions.

Mandates establishment of the Committee within 90 days post-enactment.

Official name: 21st Century Peace through Strength Act, Division D ("Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act")
Casual name: 21st Century Peace through Strength Act, Division D ("Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications")
Short summary: Prohibits entities from distributing, maintaining, or updating foreign adversary-controlled applications in the U.S. Requires user data portability before prohibition. Allows civil penalties for violations. Permits exemptions for qualified divestitures and necessary services. Grants judicial review in D.C. Circuit.
Long summary:
Prohibits entities from distributing, maintaining, or updating foreign adversary controlled applications within the U.S.

Requires data portability for users before prohibitions apply, enabling users to access their data in a machine-readable format.

Exempts applications undergoing "qualified divestiture" from prohibitions.

Enforces penalties up to $5,000 per user for distribution violations and $500 per user for data portability violations.

Mandates the Attorney General to investigate and enforce compliance through civil penalties or court actions.

Defines "foreign adversary controlled applications" and "qualified divestiture" to ensure clarity in application and exemptions.

Grants judicial review exclusively to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, with specified time limits for challenges.

Official name: Department of Peacebuilding Act of 2023, Sec. 107 ("Office of Technology for Peace")
Casual name: Department of Peacebuilding Act, Sec. 107 ("Office of Technology for Peace")
Short summary: Establishes an Office of Technology for Peace to evaluate AI and other technologies' impacts on peace. Grants research funding for nonviolent technologies that conserve resources and promote a sustainable, peaceful economy.
Long summary:
Establishes an Office of Technology for Peace within the Department, headed by the Assistant Secretary for Technology for Peace.

Tasks the Assistant Secretary with overseeing awareness, study, and ethical implications of technologies, including artificial intelligence, on domestic and international peace.

Mandates the dissemination of applicable policies and research in consultation with the Department of State.

Requires the Assistant Secretary to provide grants for technologies in transportation, communications, agriculture, medicine, and energy that are nonviolent.

Encourages grants that promote conservation and sustainability of natural resources to prevent future conflicts.

Promotes the development of a green, peaceful economy through these grants.

Official name: Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs Appropriations Act 2024, Title VII ("General Provisions"), Sec. 7032 ("Democracy Programs")
Casual name: DOS Foreign Operations Appropriations Act, Title VII ("General Provisions"), Sec. 7032 ("Democracy Programs")
Short summary: Include AI challenges in the President's democracy strategy within 180 days, focusing on digital security, countering disinformation, and AI-related democracy threats. Allocate funds for digital security and counter-disinformation initiatives as part of broader democracy programs.
Long summary:
Requires the allocation of $2,900,000,000 for democracy programs from various appropriations, including $159,240,000 for the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor.

Mandates the submission of a comprehensive five-year strategy for democracy promotion abroad within 180 days, addressing digital security, countering disinformation, and AI-related challenges.

Prohibits foreign governments from having prior approval over the implementation of democracy programs and protects the confidentiality of implementing partners in undemocratic countries.

Allocates $30,000,000 to protect civil society activists and journalists and $20,000,000 for international freedom of expression and independent media.

Requires the regular informing of the National Endowment for Democracy about planned and supported democracy programs.

Official name: New Mexico SM 63
Casual name: New Mexico SM 63 ("Structured Decision-making in Child Abuse")
Short summary: Requests the attorney general to form a task force to evaluate the use and effectiveness of AI-based structured decision-making tools by New Mexico's Children, Youth and Families Department, involving stakeholder input, with findings due by August 1, 2024.
Long summary:
Requests the Attorney General to convene a task force to study the Children, Youth, and Families Department's use of structured decision-making tools and philosophy.

Mandates the task force to assess the efficacy, impact, and results of these AI-based tools.

Requires the task force to determine if structured decision-making tools lead to better decisions in child abuse and neglect cases.

Directs the task force to analyze staff training, understanding, and data on repeat maltreatment rates since the tool’s introduction.

Instructs the task force to review the outcomes of voluntary placement agreements and safety plans under this new philosophy.

Obligates the task force to make recommendations for improvements and the future use of these tools.

Involves input from diverse stakeholders, including experts in law enforcement, child maltreatment, behavioral health, and representatives from various departments and communities.

Requires collaboration with a post-secondary institution for research.

Demands findings and recommendations be presented to the legislative health and human services committee by August 1, 2024.

Official name: An Act Providing for Transferring and Renumbering; Amending Section 41-2414, Arizona Revised Statutes, as Transferred and Renumbered; Relating to Crime Victims
Casual name: Arizona HB 2482 (2023)
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Creates a law enforcement crime victims notification system to (a) automatically update crime victims on their crime reports, investigations, and cases, and (b) respond to citizens' questions and comments through an artificial intelligence virtual agent.
Long summary:
Creates a law enforcement crime victims notification system to automatically update crime victims on their crime reports, investigations, and cases.

Requires the notification system to provide a virtual agent that employs artificial intelligence to answer citizens' questions and respond to their comments through voice, text, or email. 

Appropriates funds for the creation of the notification system.
Tags: Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Performance requirements;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 1531 ("Digital development infrastructure plan and working group")
Casual name: FY2022 NDAA, Section 1531 ("Digital development infrastructure plan and working group")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to develop a plan for establishing AI-related information technology infrastructure, and to create a related working group.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to develop a plan for establishing AI-related information technology infrastructure, including a technical plan and guidance, a governance structure with relevant guidance and policies, and prototype development and platform environments.

Instructs the Secretary to harmonize the required plan with various existing plans and strategies. Establishes a plan working group comprised of senior DOD officials.

Instructs the Secretary to assemble enterprise data sets in various AI application domains.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 226 ("Review of artificial intelligence applications and establishment of performance metrics")
Casual name: FY2022 NDAA, Section 226 ("Review of artificial intelligence applications and establishment of performance metrics")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to review, and establish metrics and objectives for, the potential integration of artificial intelligence into Department of Defense platforms, processes, and operations.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to study potential applications of artificial intelligence to Department of Defense platforms, processes, and operations, and to establish related metrics and objectives.

Specifies study and metric requirements related to AI-related skill gaps; modernization activities; exercises, wargames, and experimentation; logistics and sustainment; and business operations.

Requires the Secretary to report to Congress within 120 days after completion of the required study.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 227 ("Modification of the joint common foundation program")
Casual name: FY2022 NDAA, Section 227 ("Modification of the joint common foundation program")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to modify the Joint Common Foundation Program. This is to ensure greater support to Department of Defense (DoD) components by increasing the number of AI companies eligible to provide support, and making it easier for DoD components to more easily contract with commercial AI companies.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to modify the Joint Common Foundation Program and to ensure that the Department of Defense (DoD) can more easily contract with commercial AI companies for better support in efficiently developing new capabilities and applications. 

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to facilitate an increase in the number of eligible commercial AI companies to support DoD components, including cybersecurity processes.

Casual name: FY2022 NDAA, Section 232 ("Pilot program on data repositories to facilitate the development of artificial intelligence capabilities for the Department of Defense")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Allows the Secretary of Defense to establish repositories of Department of Defense datasets relevant to AI development.
Long summary:
Allows the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program under which the Secretary establishes repositories of Department of Defense datasets relevant to AI development.

Requires data in the potential repositories to be accessible to appropriate public and private organizations for purposes of software and AI technology development for DoD procurement.

Requires repositories to include tools for correcting errors and gaps in data and evaluate model performance.

Requires the Secretary to report to Congress within 270 days after enactment whether the Secretary will, will not, or already has carried out the program.

Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 1513 ("Establishing projects for data management, artificial intelligence, and digital solutions")

Long summary:
Instructs the Deputy Secretary of Defense to establish projects for data management, artificial intelligence, and digital solutions for business efficiency and war-fighting capabilities intended to accelerate decision advantage.

Instructs the Deputy Secretary to task senior DOD officials with developing an actionable plan to integrate various AI applications into government operational environments, and to boost the population of government personnel with AI expertise.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 1554 ("Roadmap and implementation plan for cyber adoption of artificial intelligence")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 1554 ("Roadmap and implementation plan for cyber adoption of artificial intelligence")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Commander of the United States Cyber Command and the Chief Information Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a five-year implementation plan for rapidly adopting and acquiring artificial intelligence systems to support the Department of Defense.
Long summary:
Requires the Commander of the United States Cyber Command and the Chief Information Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a five-year implementation plan for rapidly adopting artificial intelligence systems to support the Department of Defense. 

The plan shall: 

(a) Identify and prioritize AI systems and data that currently affect, or may benefit in the future, the Department's cybersecurity and cyber operations. 

(b) Lay out a plan to acquire AI systems and data identified in part (a).

(c) Identify relevant skill deficiencies.

(d) Identify opportunities to solicit AI system operator feedback.

(e) Identify and address long term technology gaps for the Department's cyber war fighting mission.

(f) Evaluate the risks posed by adversary AI-based attacks.

(g) Furnish a timeline with target milestones, investments, and required expenditures.
 
(h) Incorporate metrics to evaluate AI adoption.

(i) Identify further funding, authorities, and policies that may be necessary.

(j) Define a maturity model describing desired cyber capabilities independent of specific technology solutions.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6702 ("Additional responsibilities of Director of National Intelligence for artificial intelligence policies, standards, and guidance for the intelligence community")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6702 ("Additional responsibilities of Director of National Intelligence for artificial intelligence policies, standards, and guidance for the intelligence community")

Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence and intelligence heads, to review and establish AI-related policies, aiming to boost AI adoption in the intelligence community.
Long summary:
Creates a new institution to govern, investigate, advise, produce, or otherwise act in relation to AI.

Requires the Director of National Intelligence and intelligence heads, to review and establish AI-related policies, aiming to boost AI adoption in the intelligence community.

Requires the heads of the elements of the Intelligence Community to ensure established or updated policies are consistent with the principles outlined in the guidance of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

Avails budget guidance to the heads of the intelligence community for developing the National Intelligence Program budget to facilitate the acquisition, development, use, and maintenance of element-specific artificial intelligence capabilities.

Instructs each lead and the Director of National Intelligence to identify a senior official within the element to serve as the designated element lead responsible for coordinating AI efforts.

Addresses government support for AI-related development activities.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6717 ("Policy on required user adoption metrics in certain contracts for artificial intelligence and emerging technology software products")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6717 ("Policy on required user adoption metrics in certain contracts for artificial intelligence and emerging technology software products")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to establish a policy regarding user adoption metrics for contracts and other agreements for the procurement of AI and emerging technology software products.
Long summary:
Authorizes government support for AI-related activities

Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to establish a policy regarding user adoption metrics for contracts and other agreements for the procurement AI and emerging technology software products.

Requires an evaluation of AI systems, or of broader systems or processes that involve AI.

Requires each contract or agreement to include an understanding of the anticipated use of the covered AI or emerging technology product with a clear metric for success, for collecting user adoption metrics and for assessing the adoption of the covered product by such users.

Requires that prior to the procurement of, or the continuation of the use of, any AI and emerging technology product procured by the head of an element of the intelligence community, the head must determine a method for assessing the success of the covered product from user adoption metrics.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6721 ("Reports on integration of artificial intelligence within intelligence community")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6721 ("Reports on integration of artificial intelligence within intelligence community")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires all designated element lead in the intelligence community to submit a report detailing their efforts in developing, acquiring, adopting, and maintaining artificial intelligence for enhancing intelligence collection, analysis, and internal workflows.
Long summary:
Addresses government support for AI-related research and development activities, the development of the AI workforce, including education and training in AI-related disciplines.

Requires a description of all authorities related to artificial intelligence use.

Requires a stipulation of element’s roles, responsibilities, and authorities for accelerating AI adoption.

Requires an evaluation of efforts to enhance intelligence capabilities through AI.

Requires a progress of each intelligence element in AI adoption.

Requires details of contracts with small or medium-sized emerging tech companies for AI products.

Requires details of positions established or filled within the element.

Requires a description of Intelligence community policies related to AI adoption and compliance assessments by elements.

Necessitates recommendations for efficient AI adoption in the intelligence community, considering technological advances.

Requires an overview of foreign adversaries' AI advances and steps to ensure U.S. outpaces them.

Requires an identification of resource or authority gaps and administrative or technical barriers to AI adoption.
require

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6723 ("Requirements and report on workforce needs of intelligence community relating to science, technology, engineering, and math, and related areas")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6723 ("Requirements and report on workforce needs of intelligence community relating to science, technology, engineering, and math, and related areas")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence, in coordination with the heads of human capital from each element of the intelligence community, to develop a plan for the recruitment and retention of personnel to integrate, maintain or use artificial intelligence and other emerging technology solutions
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to submit a single report on the workforce needs of each element of the intelligence community relating to emerging technologies, with a specific focus on artificial intelligence.
        
Requires a list of personnel in work roles whose primary official duties include artificial intelligence responsibilities.
          
Requires an assessment of the quality and sustainability of the talent pipeline of the intelligence community with respect to talent in emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence. 

Requires a description of the education, recruitment, and retention programs personnel of the intelligence community.

Requires an assessment of any gaps in authorities, resources, recruitment or retention incentives, skills-based training, or educational programs, that may negatively affect the quality or sustainability of such talent pipeline.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6731 ("Report on establishment of technology acquisition cadre")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6731 ("Report on establishment of technology acquisition cadre")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Mandates the Director of National Intelligence to submit a feasibility report which establishes a cadre of experts in emerging technologies and software development, including systems to improve the adoption of commercial solutions for emerging technologies, particularly relating to artificial intelligence.
Long summary:
Mandates the Director of National Intelligence to submit a feasibility report on establishing a cadre of experts in emerging technologies.

Requires such cadre to accelerate the adoption of emerging technologies.

Requires such cadre to assist with software development and develop training requirements for acquisition professionals.

Requires an assessment of whether the establishment of the cadre would necessitate additional statutory authorities or resources, including to recruit, hire, and retain the talent and expertise needed to establish the cadre; and the benefits, risks, and costs of establishing a cadre.

Addresses the acquisition of a plan for implementation of the cadre, including the proposed size of the cadre, its management, and organization.

Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6742 ("Code-free artificial intelligence enablement tools policy")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the heads of the elements of the intelligence community to draft a potential policy to promote the intelligence community-wide use of code-free artificial intelligence enablement tools.
Long summary:
Instructs the heads of the elements of the intelligence community to draft a policy to promote the intelligence community-wide use of code-free artificial intelligence enablement tools.

Requires the given policy to include the objectives and a set of incentives for using code-free artificial intelligence enablement tools.

Instructs the intelligence community to devise a plan to ensure coordination and consideration in designating an official of each element of the intelligence community to oversee implementation of the policy.

Requires an assessment of the personnel and funding requirements, and any other resource requirements, that would be necessary to implement the draft policy in the given timeline.

Official name: Advancing American Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: Advancing American Artificial Intelligence Act
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Encourages AI-related programs and initiatives to enhance US competitiveness and to promote greater AI adoption across the Federal Government.
Long summary:
Encourages AI-related programs and initiatives to enhance the competitiveness of the US based on innovation and entrepreneurialism. 

Promotes modernized business practices and advanced technologies aligned with US values, including protection of privacy, civil rights and civil liberties across the Federal Government.

Defines the term "artificial intelligence system".

Instructs the Secretary of Homeland Security, Chief Procurement Officer, Chief Information Officer, Chief Privacy Officer, and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties of the Department to work together on policies for acquiring AI and considering the risks of AI.

Instructs the Inspector General to identify training and investments to enable the employees of the Office of the Inspector General to advance their understanding of AI and its usage.

Instructs Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop guidance for policies for AI use in government, with inputs from both government agencies and non-governmental actors. 

Requests the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to brief congressional committees on the activities carried out under this Act.

Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11226 ("Artificial intelligence strategy")

Short summary: Requires the Commandant of the Coast Guard to coordinate AI-related activities, designate an senior Coast Guard official responsible for AI, and (through the designated official) develop a strategic plan for AI
Long summary:
Requires the Commandant of the Coast Guard to coordinate activities and data related to identifying, demonstrating and deploying AI technology.

Requires the Commandant to designate a senior Coast Guard official responsible for identifying, demonstrating and deploying AI technology and for convening other Coast Guard officials for AI-related purposes.

Requires the designated official to develop, and submit within two years, a strategic plan for identifying, demonstrating and deploying AI technology.

Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11227 ("Review of artificial intelligence applications and establishment of performance metrics")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Commandant of the Coast Guard to review, identify necessary resources for, and establish metrics and objectives for the potential integration of artificial intelligence into Coast Guard platforms, processes, and operations.
Long summary:
Directs the Commandant of the Coast Guard to study potential applications of artificial intelligence and to identify resources necessary to improve the use of artificial intelligence in Coast Guard platforms, processes, and operations; instructs the Commandant to establish related metrics and objectives.

Requires that the Commandant assess AI-related skill gaps and civilian and military personnel qualification and establish related metrics.

Requires that the Commandant establish performance objectives and accompanying metrics of specified AI-related modernization activities.
 
Requires the Commandant to report to Congress within 180 days after completion of the required review.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 162 ("Assessment and strategy for fielding capabilities to counter threats posed by unmanned aerial system swarms")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 162 ("Assessment and strategy for fielding capabilities to counter threats posed by unmanned aerial system swarms")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Defense to assess the threats and national security implications of unmanned aerial system swarms and review the capabilities of the Defense Department to counter these threats. Directs the Secretary of Defense to develop a strategy to field capabilities to counter threats posed by unmanned aerial system swarms and report the assessment findings and strategy to the congressional defense committees.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to assess threats posed by unmanned aerial system swarms to installations and deployed Armed Forces, the use of these swarms by adversaries and their national security implications such as autonomous intelligence and machine learning, current capabilities of the Defense Department and their effectiveness in countering these threats, and efforts by the Defense Department to develop and field technology that can counter swarms.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to develop and implement a strategy to field capabilities to counter threats from unmanned aerial system swarms. The strategy should define "unmanned aerial system swarm," outline plans for developing, testing, fielding, and acquiring capabilities to counter swarms, estimate resources needed by each Armed Force to implement the strategy, and determine the legislative action necessary for the Defense Department to counter swarm threats.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to consider incorporating the strategy into a comprehensive strategy to defend against unmanned aerial systems and to report the assessment findings and strategy to the congressional defense committees within 270 days.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title VII, Section 808 ("Acquisition authority of the Director of the Joint Artificial Intelligence Center")

Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to delegate acquisition authority to the Director of the Joint Artificial Intelligence Center; allocates personnel and funding to support outlined responsibilities of the Center, including overseeing the transition of artificial intelligence capabilities into appropriate acquisition programs.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to delegate acquisition authority to the Director of the Joint Artificial Intelligence Center, and outlines responsibilities of an acquisition executive in the execution, supervision, discussion, and coordination of relevant acquisition activities.

Allocates personnel and funding to support Center missions and the transition of artificial intelligence capabilities into appropriate acquisition programs or into operational use. 

Requires the Secretary of Defense to provide to congressional defense committees a demonstration of operational capability and an implementation plan that describes relevant acquisition activities, plans the oversight of an acquisition executive, and assesses the acquisition workforce, tools, and infrastructure needs of the Center.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XVII, Section 1751 ("Guidance and direction on use of direct hiring processes for artificial intelligence professionals and other data science and software development personnel")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to review existing guidance and create new guidance on the direct hiring processes for AI professionals and to submit a report on the guidance issued; lists the minimum requirements for the guidance.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to review existing guidance and create new guidance for secretaries of military departments and heads of defense on the direct hiring processes for AI professionals and other software and data science personnel.

Requires that the guidance instructs HR to utilize direct hiring authorities.

Instructs hiring authorities to use a panel of subject matter experts to review qualifications, authorizes the use of ePortfolio reviews, and encourages the use of referral bonuses for recruitment.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to submit a report of the guidance issues to Congress within one year of the issuance of the guidance and highlights the requirements of the report.

Long summary: Amends Section 41001(6)(A) of the FAST Act to include semiconductors, artificial intelligence, machine learning, cybersecurity, and various related technology-powered infrastructure to the FAST Act permitting program.

Long summary:

Short summary: Directs the Director of the National Science Foundation to support research on outputs generated by generative adversarial networks, such as deepfakes, and other comparable techniques.
Long summary:
Directs the Director of the National Science Foundation to support research on manipulated or synthesized content and information authenticity.

Directs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to support research for the development of measurements and standards on generative adversarial networks and other technologies that synthesize or manipulate content.

Requires the Directors to submit a report within a year to Congress of research findings and policy recommendations.

Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Energy to develop a national plan for the development and deployment of "smart manufacturing" technologies, including relevant AI technologies, and outlines the requirements of the plan.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Energy to develop a national plan for the development and deployment of "smart manufacturing" technologies, including relevant AI technologies. Defines representative functions of "smart manufacturing" technology including manufacturing simulation, energy efficiency modeling, digital prototyping, and networking.

Requires that the plan includes an assessment of previous actions of the Department, an establishment of performance standards, actions to increase cybersecurity, and a consideration of the impact on manufacturing jobs.

Requires that the plan be submitted within 3 years and revised every two years after initial submission.

Casual name: Information Technology Modernization Centers of Excellence Program Act
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Establishes a program to facilitate the adoption of modern technology in Artificial Intelligence, cloud computing and cybersecurity by executive agencies.
Long summary:
Instructs the administrator of general services to establish the Information Technology Modernization Centers of Excellence Program.

Requires this program to assist executive agencies with planning and adoption of technology in Artificial Intelligence, cybersecurity and cloud computing.

Promotes modernization of information technology and consumer interactions with executive agencies.

Official name: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to automated employment decision tools
Casual name: NYC Local Law 144
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires AI-powered tools used in employment decisions to undergo bias audits; requires related public disclosures and notices to affected employees and job candidates.
Long summary:
Defines "automated employment decision tools" as computational processes used in discretionary employment decision making, including AI- and machine learning-derived processes.

Requires businesses using automated employment decision tools in New York City to obtain impartial bias audits of the tools from independent auditors, and to disclose the results of the audits to the public online.

Requires businesses using automated employment decision tools in New York City to notify and disclose specified information to job candidates for whom such tools are used.

Establishes civil penalties for violations of the law and empowers the city corporation counsel to enforce the law.

Long summary:
Requires devices that used advanced algorithms to help detect gastrointestinal lesions ("gastrointestinal lesion software detection systems") to undergo specified clinical and non-clinical performance tests and to demonstrate reliability and safety.

Requires gastrointestinal lesion software detection systems to be labeled with use instructions, warnings, and summaries of testing.

Short summary: Instructs the Office of Science and Technology Policy to support the development of artificial intelligence tools aimed at using relevant databases to facilitate research and innovation in the field of engineering biology.
Long summary: Instructs the President, acting through the Office of Science and Technology Policy, to support the development of artificial intelligence tools aimed at facilitating research and innovation in the field of engineering biology. Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title II, Subtitle C ("Artificial Intelligence and Emerging Technology")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Subtitle C ("Artificial Intelligence and Emerging Technology")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Addresses the research and development of artificial intelligence technologies in the Department of Defense. Establishes a board of advisors for the Joint Artificial Intelligence Center to provide strategic advice and technical expertise on matters relating to the development and use of artificial intelligence. Supports the implementation of ethical and responsible artificial intelligence systems and standards for artificial intelligence.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to assign roles and responsibilities relating to the research, development, testing, procurement of, requirements for, and operational use of artificial intelligence technologies to appropriate officials within the Department of Defense.

Supports the incorporation of standards for artificial intelligence into the strategies and doctrine of the Department.

Stipulates the roles of the Director of the joint Artificial Intelligence center.

Encourages the systematic evaluation of AI systems.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish a board of advisors for the Joint Artificial Intelligence Center with responsibilities like providing strategic advice and expertise to the Secretary and the Director on matters relating to the development and use of artificial intelligence.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to identify a set of no fewer than five use cases of the application of existing artificial intelligence enabled systems to support improved management of enterprise acquisition, personnel, audit, or financial management functions.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to conduct an assessment to determine how the Department can most effectively implement ethically and responsibly developed artificial intelligence.

Requires the secretary to pilot technology development and prototyping activities that leverage commercially available technologies and systems to demonstrate new artificial intelligence enabled capabilities to support the use cases.

Permits the secretary of Defense to establish a steering committee on emerging technology and national security threats, which committee shall develop a strategy for the organizational change, capability development, and technology investments in emerging technologies needed to maintain the technological superiority of the United States military.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title I, Section 152 ("Transfer of responsibilities and functions relating to electromagnetic spectrum operations")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title I, Section 152 ("Transfer of responsibilities and functions relating to electromagnetic spectrum operations")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to transfer all the responsibilities of the Commander of the US strategic command that are germane to electromagnetic spectrum operations (EMSO) including; advocacy for joint electronic warfare capabilities; providing contingency electronic warfare support to other combatant commands; and supporting combatant command joint training and planning related to electromagnetic spectrum operations; requires an evaluation of the need for automated and machine learning- or artificial intelligence-assisted electronic warfare capabilities.
Long summary:
Authorizes a plan to be prepared by government agencies.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to transfer all the responsibilities of the Commander of the US strategic command that are germane to electromagnetic spectrum operations (EMSO)

Instructs the Secretary to develop the transfer plan with consideration of all appropriate entities including the department of defense agencies and the functional and geographic combatant commands.

Requires the Secretary to develop the transfer plan while considering whether the receiving electromagnetic spectrum operations organization should have a unitary structure or hybrid structure.

Requires the Secretary to develop the transfer plan while considering the resources required by the receiving electromagnetic spectrum operations organization to fulfill the responsibilities and functions as well as the results of the evaluations carried out.

Requires an evaluation and accessment of the need for automated and machine learning- or artificial intelligence-assisted electronic warfare capabilities.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title II, Section 241 ("Measuring and incentivizing programming proficiency")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 241 ("Measuring and incentivizing programming proficiency")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to measure, track and reward programming, coding and artificial intelligence proficiency amongst armed forces and civilian employees of the Department of Defense.
Long summary:
Authorizes resources for managing government support for AI-related education and proficiency

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to leverage existing civilian software development and architecture certification programmes to implement DOD coding language proficiency and AI competency tests.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to update record keeping systems to track artificial intelligence and programming certification testing results just like the foreign language competency system.

Instructs the secretary of Defense to share information with the heads of other intelligence agencies about the coding language proficiency and artificial intelligence competency tests and encourages them to implement tracking and reward systems. 

Requires the Secretary of Defense to implement a system of rewards for Department of Defense employees who perform successfully on specific language coding proficiency and artificial intelligence competency tests.

Advocates for special pay for a Department of Defense employee who is certified and proficient in a computer or digital programming language but may not exceed 20% of basic pay.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title II, Section 247 ("Pilot program on the use of electronic portfolios to evaluate certain applicants for technical positions")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 247 ("Pilot program on the use of electronic portfolios to evaluate certain applicants for technical positions")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program where certain applicants for technical positions within the Department of Defense will be evaluated based partly on each applicant’s electronic portfolio.
Long summary:
Defines the term "technical position" as a Department of Defense position that (1) requires expertise in artificial intelligence, data science, or software development and (2) is eligible for direct hire authority under section 9905 of title 5, United States Code, or section 2358a of title 10, United States Code. 

Instructs the human resources manager of each Department of Defense participating organization to identify a subset of technical positions for which electronic portfolios should be evaluated during the hiring process.

Requires the Human Resources manager to evaluate applicants for such positions by reviewing their best electronic portfolios, as chosen by the applicant.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to submit a report to the congressional defense committee on the results of the program that describes how electronic portfolios affected the timeliness of technical position hiring, the level of satisfaction with new hires based on electronic portfolio evaluations, and recommends expanding the use of electronic portfolios in the hiring process or making it permanent.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 248 ("Pilot program on self-directed training in advanced technologies")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to offer online courses related to advanced technologies for civilian employees of the Department of Defense and members of the Armed Forces.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to execute a pilot program that offers online courses related to advanced technologies for civilian employees of the Department of Defense and members of the Armed Forces.

Requires the Secretary to develop procedures to document course completion, incentivize course completion, and evaluate course quality and effectiveness.

Requires the Secretary to carry out the program within a year after enactment, and decrees that the program terminate on October 1, 2024.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 249 ("Part-time and term employment of university faculty and students in the Defense science and technology enterprise")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish a program to offer Defense science and technology research employment opportunities for faculty and students of higher education institutions.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish a program to offer Defense science and technology employment opportunities to selected faculty and students of higher education institutions to carry out research projects. 

Specifies that no fewer than five positions must be given to faculty who conduct research in artificial intelligence and machine learning.

Requires the Secretary to carry out the program within 180 days of enactment and submit three annual reports of program results to Congress.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title II, Section 513 ("Grants to support STEM education in the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 513 ("Grants to support STEM education in the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary:
Instructs the Secretary along with the Secretary of Education to create and support grants to fund STEM education programs to students in the Junior Reserve Corps.
Outlines specific disciplines and STEM subjects which the grants will apply to.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary and Secretary of Education to create and support grants to fund STEM education programs for students specifically in the Junior Reserve Corps. 
Instructs different departments of the government, such as the National Science foundation, as well as local governments to carry out programs that are supported by said grants.
Outlines what activities are allowed under the grants, and what specific area of studies and subjects that they would work under. 
Details subjects that are eligible for said grants, which include science, technology, engineering, mathematics, computer science, and more.
Allows for the Secretary of Defense to determine which additional subjects and areas of studies could be applicable to the grant.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XI, Section 1102 ("Enhancement of public-private talent exchange programs in the Department of Defense")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XI, Section 1102 ("Enhancement of public-private talent exchange programs in the Department of Defense")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to use their authority towards implementing personnel exchanges with private sector entities focusing on the Department of Defence modernization priorities including areas like Research and Engineering, Information System, and each Armed Force under the jurisdiction of a military department
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to use their authority for personnel exchanges with private sector entities focusing on Department of Defence modernization priorities.  Including exchanges in Research and Engineering, the Chief Information Officer, and each Armed Force under the jurisdiction of a military department.

Insructs the Secretary of Defense to develop a system to identify, mitigate, and manage public-private talent exchange conflicts of interest.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to brief the Senate and House Armed Services Committees on Public-Private Exchange programmes. This briefing should highlight seeking opportunities for exchanges with private sector entities working on Department of Defense modernization priorities, including Artificial Intelligence.

Requires such briefing to explain barriers preventing supervisors from nominating staff for and encouraging participation in public-private exchange programmes; ways to incentivize senior leaders for programme encouragement, and the Department's conflict of interest requirements.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XV, Section 6505 ("GAO studies on trafficking")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XV, Section 6505 ("GAO studies on trafficking")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Comptroller General of the United States to conduct a study on trafficking routes employed by transnational criminals. This emcompasses examining methods for laundering proceeds from trafficking, with a focus on the role of emerging technologies, including Artificial Intelligence, in facilitating the laundering of proceedings from trafficking.
Long summary:
Instructs the Comptroller General of the United States to carry out a study in consultation with law enforcement, relevant federal agencies, private sector stakeholders (such as financial institutions, data and technology companies), to investigate major trafficking routes used by transnational criminal organizations and to what extent the trafficking routes are related.

Directs the study to include commonly used methods to launder and move the proceeds of trafficking; the types of suspicious financial activity that are associated with illicit trafficking networks, and how financial institutions identify and report such activity.

Directs the study to include steps financial institutions are taking to detect and prevent bad actors who are laundering the proceeds of illicit trafficking, including data analysis, policies, training procedures, rules, and guidance,

Necessitates the study to include the role those emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence, digital identity technologies, distributed ledger technologies, virtual assets and online marketplaces can play in enabling the laundering of proceeds from trafficking. 

Requires the Comptroller General of the United States to submit a report to the congres, summarizing the results of the study and any recommendations for regulatory action.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Applications: Security;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XCII, Section 9203 ("Spectrum information technology modernization efforts")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XCII, Section 9203 ("Spectrum information technology modernization efforts")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: A directive for covered agencies, including the Department of Defense, to employ updated algorithms, data, and AI tools in modernizing their infrastructure for managing Federal spectrum. This involves enhancing efficiency, validation, accuracy, modeling, and monitoring, with a specific emphasis on automated adjustments, collaborative spectrum sharing, and interoperability, while also mandating comprehensive plans, reviews, and oversight to ensure effective implementation and integration of these AI-driven advancements.
Long summary:
Use updated algorithms, data, AI tools, and algorithms to modernize infrastructure. Ways to improve infrastructure include efficiency, validation, accuracy, modeling, and monitoring. The directive aims to enhance covered agencies' capacity to meet mission requirements in congested Federal spectrum environments through the implementation of automated adjustments, the creation of a time-based mechanism for collaborative spectrum sharing among agencies, and fostering collaboration to ensure interoperability. 

Within 240 days of the enactment of this Act, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information is required to submit to Congress a report outlining a plan for the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to modernize and automate its infrastructure for managing the use of Federal spectrum by covered agencies, with the goal of improving efficiency in spectrum management in ways such as a timeline for implementation, plans for security enhancement, data model improvement, and workflow automation. 

Within one year of the enactment of this Act, the head of each covered agency is required to submit a report to the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information and the Policy and Plans Steering Group outlining a plan to modernize the agency's infrastructure. Each submitted report must include an assessment of their current capabilities, a timeline for completion, management capabilities, agency requirements or restrictions, existing infrastructure, and a plan for safe integration of government data.

The Comptroller General of the United States is mandated to conduct a review of covered agencies' infrastructure within 180 days of the Act's enactment and subsequently oversee the implementation of modernization plans submitted by the Assistant Secretary and covered agencies, providing regular reports and briefings to relevant congressional committees until December 31, 2030. The term "covered agency" includes any Federal entity, as determined by the Assistant Secretary, encompassing the Department of Defense, and "infrastructure" is defined as information technology systems and related tools and databases.
