Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XC, Section 9004 ("Department of Homeland Security reports on digital content forgery technology")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XC, Section 9004 ("Department of Homeland Security reports on digital content forgery technology")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to submit annually, for a period of 5 years, a report to Congress on the state of digital content forgery technology.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to submit annually, for a period of 5 years, a report to Congress on the state of digital content forgery technology. 

Requires the report to include an assessment of the underlying technologies used to create or propagate digital content forgeries, including the evolution of such technologies and patterns of dissemination of such technologies. 

Requires the report to include a description of the types of digital content forgeries, including those used to commit fraud, cause harm, harass, coerce, or silence vulnerable groups or individuals, or violate civil rights.

Requires the report to include an assessment of how foreign governments, proxies and networks thereof, and non-governmental entities use, or could use, digital content forgeries to harm national security. 

Requires the report to include an assessment of the uses, applications, dangers, benefits, and impact on individuals of deep learning or digital content forgery technologies used to generate realistic depictions of events that did not occur. 

Requires the report to include a description of the methods and technological countermeasures that are, or could be, used to identify forgeries and address concerns with digital content forgery technology.
Tags: Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XCIV, Section 9414 ("Study on Chinese policies and influence in the development of international standards for emerging technologies")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XCIV, Section 9414 ("Study on Chinese policies and influence in the development of international standards for emerging technologies")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to work with an entity with relevant expertise to conduct a study on PRC policies and influence in the development of emerging technology international standards.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to work with an entity with relevant expertise to conduct a study on PRC policies and influence in the development of emerging technology international standards, and make recommendations on how the U.S. can mitigate PRC influence and bolster U.S. participation in international standards-setting bodies.

Identifies potential areas of study, including examining previous PRC practices in international standards setting organizations to predict future international standardization engagement in critical technologies like artificial intelligence and quantum information science. 

Requires the entity conducting the study to submit a report on its findings to the Committees on Science, Space, and Technology, on Foreign Affairs, on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, and on Foreign Relations.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title V, Section 589F ("Study on cyberexploitation and online deception of members of the Armed Forces and their families")

Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to complete a study on the cyberexploitation and deceptive online targeting of members of the Armed Forces and their families.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to assess threats posed by foreign actors with malicious intent that use machine learning techniques to generate or modify media featuring members of the Armed Forces and their families.

Instructs the Secretary to assess the maturity of the machine learning technology used and how the media could be used to conduct information warfare.

Instructs the Secretary to present policy recommendations to reduce individuals' vulnerability to cyberexploitation and deception.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title I, Section 164 ("Acceleration of development and fielding of counter unmanned aircraft systems across the joint force")

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 218 ("Executive agent for autonomy")

Long summary:

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title II, Section 227 ("Limitation on contract awards for certain unmanned vessels")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title II, Section 227 ("Limitation on contract awards for certain unmanned vessels")

Short summary: Mandates that the Secretary of the Navy must report to the congressional defense committees before the purchase or use of unmanned vessels and vehicles.
Long summary:
Mandates that the Secretary of the Navy must submit a report of risk and performance to the congressional defense committees 30 days before the purchase of unmanned surface vessels or vehicles.

Mandates that the Secretary cannot integrate offensive weapons systems into unmanned surface vessels or vehicles until 30 days after certifying that the vessel will comply with legal and performance requirements.

Requires that the Secretary submit an analysis of alternatives related to the offensive military use of unmanned surface vessels or vehicles within a year of enactment.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XVI, Section 1601 ("Space Development Agency development requirements and transfer to Space Force")

Short summary: Instructs the Director of the Space Development Agency of the Department of Defense to lead the integration of next-generation space capabilities, including novel sensors and autonomous battle management features.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of the Space Development Agency of the Department of Defense to lead the development of a resilient military space-based sensing, tracking, and data transport architecture.

Instructs the Director to lead the integration of next-generation space capabilities, including novel sensors and autonomous battle features.

Instructs the Director to lead the procurement of relevant commercial capabilities and services, including low-Earth orbit or innovative capabilities. 

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to transfer the Space Development Agency from the Office of the Secretary of Defense to the Space Force by October 1, 2022.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XXXV, Section 3521 ("Maritime security and domain awareness")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions

Long summary:

Requires the Secretary of the Navy to submit the report to the specified congressional Committees.

Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title LVXXXIV, Section 8411 ("Unmanned maritime systems and satellite vessel tracking technologies")

Short summary: Mandates that the Commandant biennially assess unmanned maritime systems and satellite vessel tracking technologies for potential use by the Coast Guard and report to Congress.
Long summary:

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title XCIV, Section 9407 ("National cybersecurity challenges")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title XCIV, Section 9407 ("National cybersecurity challenges")

Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish national cybersecurity challenges by 2028 through building more resilient cyber systems, increasing American digital literacy, and advancing efforts to develop emerging technologies.

Directs the Secretary of Commerce to coordinate with other agencies to address these challenges through competitions and soliciting funds from both government and non-government entities.

Official name: Copyright Registration Guidance: Works Containing Material Generated by Artificial Intelligence
Casual name: Copyright Registration Guidance: Works Containing Material Generated by Artificial Intelligence
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Clarifies that content generated by artificial intelligence without significant creative contribution from a human is ineligible for U.S. copyright protection.
Long summary:
Clarifies that content generated by artificial intelligence without significant creative contribution from a human is ineligible for U.S. copyright protection.

Also clarifies that contributions made by a human to content that was created with the assistance of AI remain eligible for copyright protection.

Describes various situations in which content generated with the assistance of AI would, and would not, qualify for copyright protection. 

Instructs copyright applicants on how to apply for copyright protection for content generated with the assistance of AI.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 346 ("Pilot program on optimization of aerial refueling and fuel management in contested logistics environments through use of artificial intelligence")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 346 ("Pilot program on optimization of aerial refueling and fuel management in contested logistics environments through use of artificial intelligence")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Mandates the Department of Defense, in partnership with the Air Force, to launch a pilot program to optimize the logistics of aerial refueling and fuel management using  artificial intelligence and advanced digital technologies.
Long summary:
Mandates the Department of Defense and the Air Force to work together in launching a pilot program that optimizes aerial refueling and fuel management using artificial intelligence and advanced digital technologies.

Directs the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer to (a) coordinate with the Commander of the United States Transportation Command and the Commander of the United States Indo-Pacific Command to align the pilot program with existing operational requirements and (b) consult relevant experts in AI.

Requires the pilot program to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of artificial intelligence-driven approaches and evaluate the interoperability and compatibility of artificial intelligence-enabled systems with the existing logistics infrastructure of the Department of Defense.

Requires an assessment of potential challenges and risks associated with the integration of artificial intelligence and other advanced digital technologies, including those related to cybersecurity.

Requires the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer to submit a report on the pilot program's design, progress, and results to the Committees on Armed Services of the House of Representatives and the Senate within one year.

Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 350 ("Strategy and assessment on use of automation and artificial intelligence for shipyard optimization")

Short summary: Requires the Secretary of the Navy to (a) develop a strategy for using artificial intelligence to better predict maintenance needs at U.S. Navy shipyards, and (b) evaluate the potential maintenance cost savings of doing so.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Navy, in coordination with the Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Program of the Department of the Navy, to develop a strategy for using artificial intelligence to better predict maintenance needs at U.S. Navy shipyards.

Requires the Secretary of the Navy to evaluate the potential cost savings of adopting artificial intelligence predictive maintenance technologies.

Requires the Secretary of the Navy to brief congressional defense committees on the strategy and evaluation described above.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 811 ("Modernizing the Department of Defense requirements process")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 811 ("Modernizing the Department of Defense requirements process")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to develop a streamlined requirements development process for the Department of Defense; requires  processes for software, artificial intelligence, data, and related capability areas to be more rapid and iterative than the requirements processes for traditional hardware systems. Requires the Secretary of Defense to cooperate  with other military leaders.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense in coordination with military leaders to develop streamlined requirements of development processes for the Department of Defense, in order to modernize war fighting technology and reduce the time needed to deliver capabilities to warfighters.

Requires revisions to requirements management practices that maximizes the use of commercial products or services and allow for a broader range of new or alternative technological opportunities to be incorporated without the requirement being validated again.

Establishes a process to rapidly validate the ability of commercial products and services to meet capability needs or opportunities.

Requires retiring and replacing the Department of Defense Architecture Framework with a new structure focused on enabling interoperability  through application program interfaces, enterprise architectures and platforms, and government and commercial standards.

Requires the secretary to develop a formal career path, training, and structure for requirements managers.

Establishes the required processes for software, artificial intelligence, data, and related capability areas to be more rapid and iterative than the requirements processes for traditional hardware systems.

Requires the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to collaborate with industry partners, contractors, and Department of Defense science and technology reinvention laboratories in designing the new requirements development process.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit to the congressional defense committees an interim report and a final report on the development and implementation of the new requirements development process.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Access to business opportunities;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 856 ("Pilot program to analyze and monitor certain supply chains")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 856 ("Pilot program to analyze and monitor certain supply chains")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Directs the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment to establish a pilot program for analyzing supply chains for covered weapons platforms using artificial intelligence and machine learning tools.
Long summary:
Directs the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment to establish a pilot program enhancing the analysis, mapping, and monitoring of supply chains for covered weapons platforms using artificial intelligence and machine learning tools.

Requires the Under Secretary to submit an annual report (until 2028) that specifies the vulnerabilities of the supply chains and the efficiencies achieved through using the new tools.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Strategies: Performance requirements;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Title XIII, Subtitle B ("Other Matters Relating to Foreign Nations: Matters Relating to the AUKUS Partnership")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Title XIII, Subtitle B ("Other Matters Relating to Foreign Nations: Matters Relating to the AUKUS Partnership")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of State to (a) submit to Congress a biennial report on efforts to enhance AUKUS collaboration on artificial intelligence and (b) create an expedited technology transfer process for sharing artificial intelligence systems and other defense technologies with AUKUS partners.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other agency heads, to submit to Congress a biennial report on the AUKUS partnership, including an assessment of efforts to enhance AUKUS collaboration on artificial intelligence.

Requires the Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, to create an expedited technology transfer approval process for transferring artificial intelligence systems and other defense technologies to AUKUS partners.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Licensing, registration, and certification;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 1507 ("Review and plan relating to cyber red teams of Department of Defense")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 1507 ("Review and plan relating to cyber red teams of Department of Defense")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Department of Defense to submit to Congress a plan for ensuring that the Department's cyber red teams possess the capabilities necessary to execute their duties, including with respect to threats stemming from artificial intelligence systems abroad.
Long summary:
Requires officials from the Department of Defense -- namely the Principal Cyber Advisor to the Secretary of Defense, the Chief Information Officer of the Department of Defense, the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation, and the Commander of the United States Cyber Command -- to assess the status of the implementation of recommendations made by the Secretary of Defense to enhance the capabilities of the Department of Defense's cyber red teams.

Requires the same officials listed above to submit to Congress a plan for ensuring that the Department's cyber red teams possess the capabilities necessary to execute their duties, including with respect to threats stemming from artificial intelligence systems abroad.

Requires the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation to evaluate annually, from 2025 through 2031, the status of the implementation of the plan described in the paragraph above.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Adversarial testing;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 1521 ("Control and management of Department of Defense data; establishment of Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 1521 ("Control and management of Department of Defense data; establishment of Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Grants the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer authority to access and control data on behalf of the Secretary of Defense and establishes a council to oversee the responsible deployment of AI across Department of Defense operations.
Long summary:
Grants the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of Defense the authority to access and control data on behalf of the Secretary of Defense.

Requires the Secretary to establish the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council, which will provide policy oversight to ensure the responsible, coordinated, and ethical deployment of AI across Department of Defense missions and operations.

Requires the Council to submit a report on its activities in the past period to the Secretary and Congress at least once every 18 months.
Tags: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Dissemination;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Performance requirements;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Title XV, Subtitle C ("Cyberspace-Related Matters: Information Technology and Data Management")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Title XV, Subtitle C ("Cyberspace-Related Matters: Information Technology and Data Management")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish a council known as the ‘Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council’ to provide policy oversight in order to ensure the responsible, and ethical employment of data and artificial intelligence capabilities across Department of Defense missions; requires any data collection, use, or retention measure to be compliant with applicable laws; establishes a pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of implementing industry open technical standards.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish the 'Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer Governing Council' to oversee policy ensuring responsible and ethical use of data and AI in Department of Defense missions.

Requires  The council, led by the Chief Digital and AI Officer, to develop, implement, and oversee AI, coordinating governance, and providing ethical guidance. 

Instructs the council to identify, monitor, and update recommendations for AI use, review program funding,  and ensure compliance with AI policies. 

Instructs the council to issue guidance on access and distribution restrictions relating to data, models, tool sets, testing or validation infrastructure.

Instructs the council to implement and oversee an educational program on data and artificial intelligence, to familiarize personnel department on the applications of artificial intelligence.

Mandates all data collection, use, or retention measures  to comply with relevant laws and regulations, including those concerning data related to US persons.

Requires an establishment of a course of education at the Defense Information School, the purpose of which shall be to provide instruction on the practical concepts and skills.

Instructs the Director of the Defense Media Activity to carry out a pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of implementing industry open technical standards for digital content provenance for official photographs and videos of the Department of Defense
Tags: Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Business services and analytics;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Title XV, Subtitle E ("Artificial Intelligence")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Title XV, Subtitle E ("Artificial Intelligence")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Directs Secretary of Defense to implement a bug bounty program on DoD AI use and a competition on AI detection and watermarking. Instructs Secretary of Defense to develop guidance on various aspects of AI use within DoD, including bias mitigation, security, and human oversight of autonomous systems, and mandates a study on vulnerabilities of AI in the military.
Long summary:
Updates and extends the DoD's AI and ML acquisition framework and requires a plan for acquisition authority delegation and a demonstration of acquisition authority capabilities.

Mandates the creation of a bug bounty program for foundational AI models within the DoD, promoting collaboration with federal entities and cybersecurity experts. Requires briefing the congressional defense committees on the program within one year.

Instructs the Secretary of Defense to establish a competition to advance technologies for detecting and watermarking generative AI content. Requires annual briefing to the congressional defense committees.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to issue DoD-wide guidance and policy on AI, including with regard to ethical AI use, bias mitigation, cybersecurity, technical workforce assessments, AI literacy needs and related training programs, protection against adversarial AI, protecting the intellectual property of DoD AI system suppliers, AI's potential role in developing offensive actions, availability of inputs for AI, verification and evaluation frameworks, potential vulnerabilities of AI models and human oversight of autonomous systems. Requires briefing the congressional defense committees within 150 days.

Requires a study on the vulnerabilities of AI-enabled military applications, focusing on explainability, security risks, and the integration of decision support systems, with a final report for the congressional defense committees detailing findings and research gaps.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 1682 ("Electromagnetic Warfare")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 1682 ("Electromagnetic Warfare")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires several US military branches to assess their electromagnetic spectrum operation abilities, including the need for AI-assisted operations.
Long summary: Requires leaders of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Space Operations to evaluate their ability to conduct electromagnetic spectrum operations. The evaluation should include the need for AI-assisted operations.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 6303 ("Establishment of the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of State")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 6303 ("Establishment of the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of State")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Creates the position of Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer within the Department of State.
Long summary:
Creates the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer position, who will be responsible for (a) the evaluation and facilitation of responsible AI and machine learning usage and (b) advising the Secretary of State on ethical AI and analytics usage in diplomacy.

Instructs the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer to partner with the Chief Information Officer on scaling AI use cases.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 7356 ("Analysis of commercial cloud initiatives of intelligence community")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 7356 ("Analysis of commercial cloud initiatives of intelligence community")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to (a) analyze the intelligence community's commercial cloud initiatives -- including their ability to support artificial intelligence capabilities -- and (b) brief the congressional intelligence and appropriations committees on the findings of that analysis.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to produce a comprehensive analysis of the intelligence community's cloud initiatives relating to the Commercial Cloud Enterprise contract entered into by the Director of the Central Intelligence Agency in November of 2020. 

Requires the above analysis to include projected cloud computing costs, plans for the termination of legacy data storage mechanisms, an assessment of the value and efficacy of cloud computing tools and analytics, and the suitability of existing computing arrangements to service artificial intelligence systems for the intelligence community. 

Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief the congressional intelligence and appropriations committees on the findings of the analysis detailed above.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 7507 ("Programs for next-generation microelectronics in support of artificial intelligence")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 7507 ("Programs for next-generation microelectronics in support of artificial intelligence")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to establish or oversee a program to advance microelectronics research, focused on applications in artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence, acting through the Director of the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity, to establish or oversee a program to advance microelectronics research. 

Requires the program described above to focus on applications in artificial intelligence, advanced computing, advanced computing materials, optical communication networks, quantum technologies, or other emerging technologies. 

Requires the Director of National Intelligence to consider a variety of factors when crafting the research program, including input from the Secretary of Commerce and from an array of stakeholders including representatives of industry and academia.

Requires the Director of the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity to brief the congressional intelligence, appropriations, and commerce committees on the progress of the research program described above and recommendations for future research priorities.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 7510 ("Requirement to ensure intelligence community directives appropriately account for artificial intelligence and machine learning tools in intelligence products")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 7510 ("Requirement to ensure intelligence community directives appropriately account for artificial intelligence and machine learning tools in intelligence products")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief Congress on whether existing directives provide sufficient guidance on the use of AI in intelligence and, if necessary, on a plan to update the guidance.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to brief the congressional appropriations and intelligence committees on whether intelligence community directives provide sufficient guidance on how to use, document, and disclose AI and machine learning tools in intelligence. 

Requires the Director to either (a) justify the assertion that existing intelligence community directives do sufficiently provide such guidance or (b) provide a plan and timeline for updating the directives as necessary.
Tags: Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 7511 ("Expanded annual assessment of economic and technological capabilities of the People's Republic of China and related briefing")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 7511 ("Expanded annual assessment of economic and technological capabilities of the People's Republic of China and related briefing")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to provide a briefing and recommendations to the congressional intelligence committees on the working groups regarding the People's Republic of China's investments in artificial intelligence.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to provide a briefing to the congressional intelligence committees on the status and implementation of working groups on the People's Republic of China's activities regarding certain technologies, including artificial intelligence. 

Instructs working groups to assess the investments made by the People's Republic of China in AI, the competitive practices of the People's Republic of China relating to AI, opportunities to counter those practices, and US vulnerabilities in the supply chain of AI.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Energy and utilities

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 7513 ("Policies established by Director of National Intelligence for artificial intelligence capabilities")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 7513 ("Policies established by Director of National Intelligence for artificial intelligence capabilities")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to implement policies for the third-party acquisition, development, and use of artificial intelligence capabilities.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget and other intelligence officials to maintain, develop, and annually revise various AI policies.

Requires the establishment of a lexicon relating to machine learning and AI use by the intelligence community.

Requires the establishment of guidelines for evaluating model performance by specifying conditions for AI capability monitoring, documenting performance objectives, specifying model auditing processes, and specifying conditions for vulnerability testing and privacy evaluations.

Requires the establishment of guidelines for tracking dependencies in related systems, documentation requirements for capabilities procured from third-party and training data usage, and guidance on the usage of third-party-trained models.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 253 ("Annual review of status of implementation plan for digital engineering career tracks")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 253 ("Annual review of status of implementation plan for digital engineering career tracks")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires an annual report on the Department of Defense's digital engineer career track plan by the Secretary of Defense to Congress, including an assessment of how advances in machine learning affect the plan.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to conduct annually, through 2029, an internal review of the Department of Defense's plan for the digital engineer career track. The review shall include consideration of how the rapid rate of technological change in data science and machine learning may affect the implementation of the plan.

Requires the Secretary to submit annually, through 2029, a report to the congressional defense committees on the findings of that internal review. The report shall include the Secretary's plan for addressing the digital engineer personnel needs of the Department.
Tags: Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 112 ("Strategy for Army tactical wheeled vehicle program")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 112 ("Strategy for Army tactical wheeled vehicle program")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Army to submit to Congress a report on the strategy 
of the Army for tactical wheeled vehicles -- including autonomous vehicles -- for FY 2025, 2030, and 2035. The report shall include a description of the force structure and funding necessary for the tactical wheeled vehicle program to support the U.S.'s national security strategy.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Army to submit to Congress a report on the strategy of the Army for tactical wheeled vehicles, including autonomous vehicles. The report shall be submitted with the budget justification materials submitted in support of the budget of the Department of Defense for each of FY 2025, 2030, and 2035.

Requires the report to include a description of the force structure and funding necessary for the tactical wheeled vehicle program to support the U.S.'s national security strategy, along with detailed rundown of a program for the construction of tactical wheeled vehicles and the estimated cost of such a program. 

Requires the Secretary of the Army to, within 15 days of the budget materials submission described above, brief the congressional defense committees on the investment needed for each platform of tactical wheeled vehicle.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 251 ("Congressional notification of changes to Department of Defense policy on autonomy in weapon systems")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 251 ("Congressional notification of changes to Department of Defense policy on autonomy in weapon systems")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to brief the congressional defense committees on the nature and purpose of any modifications to Department of Defense Directive 300.09, which relates to autonomy in weapons systems.
Long summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to brief the congressional defense committees on the nature and purpose of any modifications to Department of Defense Directive 300.09, which relates to autonomy in weapons systems, within 30 days of making the modifications.

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 903 ("Establishment of Office of Strategic Capital")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 903 ("Establishment of Office of Strategic Capital")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Creates a new Office of Strategic Capital in the Department of Defense to invest in companies developing advanced technologies, including autonomous robots, that may benefit the Department of Defense.
Long summary:
Creates a new Office of Strategic Capital in the Department of Defense.

Directs the new Office to invest in companies developing critical technologies, including autonomous robots, that may benefit the Department of Defense. 

Permits the Office to launch a pilot program for providing capital assistance that supports the defense industrial base. 

Requires the Office's investments to meet certain criteria, including restrictions on interest rates and loan repayment periods as well as requirements for non-Federal investments in selected companies, subject to various exceptions. 

Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit to the congressional defense committees an annual report on the Office's activities, in addition to notifying the congressional defense committees whenever it provides capital assistance.

Official name: An act to add Section 11546.45.5 to the Government Code, relating to automated decision systems
Casual name: California AB 302 (2023)
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires the California Department of Technology to analyze the benefits and risks of all high-risk automated decision systems that are in use by, or have been proposed for use by, state agencies.
Long summary:
Requires the California Department of Technology, in coordination with other agencies, to analyze the benefits and risks of all high-risk automated decision systems that have been proposed for use, development, or procurement by, or are being used, developed, or procured by, state agencies. 

Requires the analysis to include a description of, among other things, the categories of data and personal information the automated decision system uses to make its decisions. 

Requires the Department of Technology to submit an annual report on the above-described comprehensive analysis to specified committees of the California Legislature.

Casual name: North Dakota HB 1361 (2023)
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Clarifies that artificial intelligence cannot qualify as a "person" for the purpose of North Dakota state law.
Long summary: Clarifies that artificial intelligence cannot qualify as a "person" for the purpose of North Dakota state law.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title VIII, Section 801 ("Report on acquisition risk assessment and mitigation as part of Adaptive Acquisition Framework implementation")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title VIII, Section 801 ("Report on acquisition risk assessment and mitigation as part of Adaptive Acquisition Framework implementation")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires each Department of Defense service acquisition executive to submit to Department leadership a report on how they are addressing a series of risks in acquisition programs, including potential complications posed by Department system changes created by artificial intelligence.
Long summary:
Requires each Department of Defense service acquisition executive to submit to the Secretary of Defense, the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment, the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, and the Chief Information Officer a report on how they are assessing, mitigating, and reporting risks in acquisition programs.

Requires the reports described above to cover, among other risk categories, technical risks in engineering, software, manufacturing and testing; integration and interoperability risks posed by changes to Department systems created by artificial intelligence; and supply chain risks, including those related to cybersecurity and the defense industrial base's potential inability to produce technology and systems as needed.

Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment to submit to the congressional defense committees a report on their own views, and the views of the service acquisition executives, with regard to the risk mitigation measures covered herein.
Tags: Risk factors: Reliability;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division A, Title LXII, Section 6211 ("Financial crimes tech symposium")
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA, Division A, Title LXII, Section 6211 ("Financial crimes tech symposium")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to periodically convene a global anti-money laundering and financial crime symposium focused on how new technology can be used to more effectively combat financial crimes; requires the Treasury Department to brief appropriate congressional committees on the use of artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies in combating financial crimes.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to periodically convene a global anti-money laundering and financial crime symposium -- attended by domestic and international financial regulators, senior executives from regulated firms, technology providers, representatives from law enforcement and national security agencies, and experts -- focused on how new technology can be used to more effectively combat financial crimes and other illicit activities.

Requires the Director of the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network -- a bureau of the Treasury Department -- to brief the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives on the current and potential future use of artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies in its work, along with policy recommendations for enhancing the efficacy of utilizing such technologies in combating financial crimes.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 557 ("Study and report on professional military education")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 557 ("Study and report on professional military education")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to evaluate and include in the Professional Military Education (PME) curriculum special focus areas related to innovation, with AI being one of them.
Long summary: Mandates the Secretary of Defense to conduct a thorough evaluation of the curricula at Professional Military Education (PME) institutions, specifically demanding an assessment of how these curricula align with innovative technological and strategic areas, including AI. Requires report to Congress by Dec 2025.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 835 ("Curricula on software acquisitions and cybersecurity software or hardware acquisitions for covered individuals")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 835 ("Curricula on software acquisitions and cybersecurity software or hardware acquisitions for covered individuals")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Defense Acquisition University President to enhance curricula with information on several technologies, including AI, and report to Congress.
Long summary:
Requires the Defense Acquisition University President to enhance curricula on software, cybersecurity, and hardware acquisition with information on various digital technologies, including AI and machine learning.

Requires the Secretary of Defense and the Defense Acquisition University President to submit a plan for the implementation of the new curricula within 180 days. The new curricula must be offered within one year of the submission.

Requires said roles to submit a cost-benefit assessment to Congress one year after the first report.

Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 861 ("Strategy for increasing competitive opportunities for certain critical technologies")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy for implementing critical technologies, including AI, into defense programs.
Long summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy to increase competitive opportunities for U.S. companies in transitioning critical technologies into major weapon systems and defense programs. AI and machine learning are mentioned as one of the 13 critical technologies and several other technologies mentioned may relate to AI.

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 911 ("Updates to management reform framework")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 911 ("Updates to management reform framework")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Updates the DoD Management Reform Framework by adding AI tools for management decision-making as one of eight elements of reform.
Long summary: Updates the DoD Management Reform Framework that mandates the Secretary of Defense to introduce reforms within DoD that enhance its efficiency and efficacy. Adds AI tools for management decision-making as one of eight elements of reform.
