Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 916 ("Strategic management dashboard demonstration")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 916 ("Strategic management dashboard demonstration")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to demonstrate a strategic management dashboard within one year of the Act's enactment. This dashboard will automate data collection and data visualization of the Department of Defense's primary management goals, and will incorporate artificial intelligence and machine learning tools to improve data analytic capabilities and decision making.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to demonstrate a strategic management dashboard within one year of the Act's enactment. This dashboard will automate data collection and data visualization of the Department of Defense's primary management goals, enabling real-time monitoring of DoD's performance in achieving its management goals.

It will use artificial intelligence and machine learning tools to improve data analytic capabilities and decision making. The development of the dashboard will leverage commercial best practices and leading research in management and data science.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Strategies: Performance requirements;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 1092 ("National Commission on the Future of the Navy")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 1092 ("National Commission on the Future of the Navy")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Establishes an independent  Commission on the Future of the Navy within the legislative branch, whose duties include studying opportunities to incorporate advanced technologies, including artificial intelligence, in the fleet.
Long summary:
Establishes an independent Commission on the Future of the Navy within the legislative branch, whose duties include studying opportunities to incorporate advanced technologies, including artificial intelligence, in the fleet.

Requires the Commission to consider specific changes to the Navy's Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Program and ship depot maintenance program, in order to expand the use of advanced technologies in shipyard infrastructure and ship operations.

Requires the Commission to submit to the congressional armed services committees an unclassified report on the findings of its study.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 1535 ("Department of Defense Cyber and Digital Service Academy")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 1535 ("Department of Defense Cyber and Digital Service Academy")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to establish the Department of Defense Cyber and Digital Service Academy, a scholarship to fund students in critically needed digital technology areas such as AI in return for a commitment to work at the Department of Defense.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to establish a new program that provides financial support to individuals studying digital technology-related areas critical to the Department of Defense, including AI. The program shall be called "Department of Defense Cyber and Digital Service Academy" and have a board of directors consisting of representatives from federal departments and agencies.

Eligible individuals need to be enrolled in a relevant program at an institution of higher education and commit to work for the Department of Defense in an area relevant to the program for a duration equivalent to the duration of the scholarship.

Requires a report to Congress on the success of the program every two years.
Tags: Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6504 ("Annual report on concentrated reeducation camps in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6504 ("Annual report on concentrated reeducation camps in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to create an annual report to Congress that includes a list of Chinese AI businesses that are involved with or are supporting concentrated reeducation camps in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of China.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to create an annual report to Congress for five years that includes a list of Chinese AI businesses that are involved with or are supporting concentrated reeducation camps in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of China.

Directs the Director of National Intelligence to work in consultation with the heads of elements of the intelligence community to create the list of Chinese AI businesses for the report.
Tags: Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Discrimination;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6505 ("Assessments of production of semiconductors by the People's Republic of China")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6505 ("Assessments of production of semiconductors by the People's Republic of China")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: After this act is passed, the Director of National Intelligence must submit a detailed report about the production of semiconductors in China. The Director must also meet with federal agencies' heads to discuss the report and other findings related to the Chinese production of semiconductors.
Long summary:
Begins discussing the phrase “appropriate committees of Congress” and what organizations are actually a part of this phrase when benign referred. Also defines the term “legacy semiconductor” in terms of the definition given in another legislation document.

Annually for 3 years after this act is passed, the Director of National Intelligence must submit an unclassified assessment report regarding China’s production of semiconductors through China’s firms and business sectors to the appropriate committees of Congress.

The Director of National Intelligence must meet with the heads of federal agencies to discuss the elements of the assessment. They must discuss the self-sufficiency of China in the fields of artificial intelligence, cloud computing, autonomous vehicles, and other newer-technological areas. They must discuss China’s access to intellectual property related to leading edge process nodes, including electronic design automation technology. They must discuss Chinese firms’s production of semiconductors that are not legacy conductors and stockpiling efforts of semiconductor manufacturing equipment. They must discuss the relative market share and its trends of Chinese semiconductor manufacturers at different process nodes. They must discuss the outside recruitment activity into Chinese semiconductors firms and the capability of the Chinese workforce in developing semiconductors that are not legacy semiconductors and relevant equipment.
Tags: Risk factors: Reliability;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation;Applications: Energy and utilities

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6812 ("Increased intelligence-related engineering, research, and development capabilities of minority institutions")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6812 ("Increased intelligence-related engineering, research, and development capabilities of minority institutions")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan to promote intelligence-related engineering, research, and development activities at institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence to develop and submit to Congress a report and a plan to promote intelligence-related engineering, research, and development activities at institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities. 

Requires the plan described above to include an analysis of (a) the opportunities for advancing engineering, research, and development in computer sciences, including artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and machine learning, and synthetic biology, and (b) the investments necessary to do so.

Requires the plan to include metrics of success and actionable recommendations for the Director, Congress, and higher education institutions, and permits the Director to award contracts, grants, or other agreements to support the institutions.

Instructs the Director to establish goals and incentives to encourage the 
Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity to develop partnerships between itself, its partner institutions, and institutes of higher education whose students are predominantly of minority ethnicities.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 9218 ("Report on changes to the Foreign Service Officer Test")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 9218 ("Report on changes to the Foreign Service Officer Test")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of State to submit to Congress a report on recent changes made to the Foreign Service entry process, including the use of artificial intelligence and its impact on recruitment.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of State to submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report that describes and justifies any changes made during FY 2022 and 2023 to the Foreign Service entry process.

Includes the use of artificial intelligence, including deep textual analysis, and its impact on recruitment in the scope of the report.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Business services and analytics;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 9506 ("Cybersecurity recruitment and retention")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 9506 ("Cybersecurity recruitment and retention")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of State to establish Department of State positions that are solely dedicated to the recruitment and retention of personnel with backgrounds in artificial intelligence and other critical technology fields; authorizes $750,000 for each of the fiscal years 2023 through 2027 to do so.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of State to establish positions within the Bureau of Global Talent Management that are solely dedicated to the recruitment and retention of Department personnel with backgrounds in cybersecurity, engineering, data science, application development, artificial intelligence, critical and emerging technology, and technology and digital policy.

Requires the Secretary to submit a plan to the appropriate congressional committees that describes how the initiative described above will be implemented. 

Authorizes the appropriation of $750,000 for each of the fiscal years 2023 through 2027 to carry out this initiative.

Requires the Secretary to submit to the appropriate congressional committees an annual report, for a period of 5 years, on the implementation of the initiative, including the hiring authorities used to implement it, the number of employees hired through it, and recommendations to enhance the efficacy of the initiative.

Requires the Secretary to include computer programming languages within the Recruitment Language Program and provide appropriate language incentive pay.

Requires the Secretary to provide a list to the appropriate 
congressional committees that identifies (a) the computer programming languages included within the Recruitment Language Program and the language incentive pay 
rate and (b) the number of individuals benefitting from the inclusion of such computer programming languages in the Recruitment Language Program and language incentive pay.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 11504 ("At-sea recovery operations pilot program")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11504 ("At-sea recovery operations pilot program")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a pilot program to assess the potential for the autonomous, or remotely controlled, operation and monitoring of certain Coast Guard vessels.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a pilot program to assess the potential for the autonomous, or remotely controlled, operation and monitoring of certain Coast Guard vessels.

Requires the pilot program described above to assess the complexities and risks of autonomous or remotely controlled vessel operation, gather data on the practice, and assess the regulatory environment necessary to facilitate the practice going forward. 

Permits the pilot program to include operations relating to the launch and recovery of unmanned spaceflight vessels and components.

Permits the Secretary to modify or waive applicable regulations or guidance that would otherwise interfere with the pilot program.

Requires the Secretary to provide the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives with a quarterly briefing on the pilot program.

Requires the Secretary to submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and 
Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and 
Infrastructure and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of 
the House of Representatives a final report assessing the execution of the pilot program and its implications for preserving safety and environmental quality. 

Requires the Comptroller General of the United States to consult with stakeholders and then submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a report on the commercial availability, barriers to use, safety and security risks, use abroad, and impact on labor of autonomous and remote technologies used in the operation of shipboard equipment.
Tags: Risk factors: Reliability;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Harm to property;Harms: Ecological harm;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 862 ("Key advanced system development industry days")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 862 ("Key advanced system development industry days")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires each Secretary of a military department to hold an event every 180 days designed to collaborate with the private sector on, and raise awareness of, innovation in autonomous systems with military applications.
Long summary:
Requires each Secretary of a military department to hold an event every 180 days designed to collaborate with the private sector on, and raise awareness of, innovation in autonomous systems with military applications. 

For each such event, requires the Service Chief concerned to identify military requirements, capability gaps, and opportunities for experimentation or exercises related to the autonomous systems covered at the event. 

For each such event, requires the service acquisition executive of the involved military department to identify acquisition strategies and potential acquisition funding mechanisms for the autonomous systems covered at the event.

Requires Department of Defense officials to draft reviews of each such event, analyze the reviews to identify trends and key takeaways, and distribute the reviews within the Department.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 6513 ("Lead intelligence community coordinator for countering and neutralizing proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 6513 ("Lead intelligence community coordinator for countering and neutralizing proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to appoint a lead coordinator to address the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems, develop a comprehensive action plan, and report findings to Congress. Encourages collaboration among members of the Five Eyes Partnership and Israel in countering these threats.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to designate an official from the intelligence community to serve as the lead coordinator for countering and neutralizing the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems.

Requires this Coordinator to develop a comprehensive plan of action, driven by intelligence information, for countering and neutralizing the threats posed by the proliferation of Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems and submit a briefing of such plans to the Congress.

Requires the Director of National Intelligence to submit a final report on the activities and findings of the Coordinator to the appropriate committees of Congress.

Mandates the report to include an assessment of the threats posed by Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems and a detailed description of intelligence sharing efforts, as well as other joint efforts driven by intelligence information, with allies and partners of the United States, to assist in countering and neutralizing such threats. 

Mandates the report to include recommendations for any changes in United States policy designed to improve the capacity of the intelligence community to assist in countering such threats.

Encourages collaboration and the expansion of existing cooperative efforts among members of the Five Eyes Partnership and Israel for the purpose of countering Iran-origin unmanned aircraft systems.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 10305 ("Modifications to the ocean exploration program of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 10305 ("Modifications to the ocean exploration program of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to promote the development and use of emerging technologies for research, communication, navigation, and data collection in marine science as part of the Administration's national ocean exploration program.
Long summary:
Instructs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to promote the development and use of emerging technologies (e.g., sensors and autonomous vehicles) for research, communication, navigation, and data collection in marine science as part of the Administration's national ocean exploration program. 

Otherwise adjusts the precise parameters of the national ocean exploration program, including with regard to data collection and data sharing practices.
Tags: Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D

Official name: James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023, Section 11225 ("Establishment of unmanned system program and autonomous control and computer vision technology project")
Casual name: FY2023 NDAA, Section 11225 ("Establishment of unmanned system program and autonomous control and computer vision technology project")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Requires the Coast Guard to implement, and brief Congress on, a program for using unmanned vehicles to improve mission execution.
Long summary:
Requires the U.S. Coast Guard to establish a program for using unmanned vehicles -- designed to operate in the air, on the water, and/or below the water's surface --  to improve mission execution. 

Requires the Commandant of the Coast Guard to conduct a project that retrofits at least two small boats with the sensors, communication systems, computer vision systems, and autonomous control technology necessary to conduct unmanned search and rescue, surveillance, and interdiction missions. Requires the Commandant to collect and analyze operational data from this project to inform future requirements. 

Requires the Commandant to submit a project briefing including analysis of operational data and projected costs to the congressional transportation committees.

Requires the Commandant to submit to the congressional transportation committees a detailed description of the Coast Guard's strategy for integrating unmanned systems across mission areas, including an estimate of the resources needed to achieve such integration.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 224 ("Next Generation Air Dominance family of systems development program accountability matrices")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 224 ("Next Generation Air Dominance family of systems development program accountability matrices")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary:
Submit matrices that detail engineering, manufacturing, and development for Next Generation Air Dominance and Collaborative Combat Aircraft programs to congressional defense committees as well as the Comptroller General. 

Provide updates on progress and cost estimates every 6 months.

Develops key performance parameters for the program and its objectives to make sure there is transparency and oversight within the system.
Long summary:
Submit goals for Next Generation Air Dominance and Collaborative Combat Aircraft programs to congressional defense committees and the Comptroller General concurrent with the President's budget submission. Include key milestones, testing events, and performance goals, subdivided into six-month increments. 

Provide information on technology readiness levels, design maturity, software maturity, integration maturity, manufacturing readiness levels, reliability, availability for flight operations, and maintainability.

Provide updates on progress and cost estimates for the program every 6 months. It details progress made toward the goals identified in the matrices and provides updated cost estimates for air vehicles, propulsion, mission systems, software, program management, system test and evaluation, support and training systems, and more.

Develop key performance parameters (cost KPPs) for cost thresholds and objectives for the programs. Specify threshold and objective values for categories such as unit recurring flyaway cost, average procurement unit cost, gross/weapon system unit cost, aircraft cost-per-tail-per-year, and aircraft cost-per-flight-hour. 

Ensure that each Secretary concerned works on these parameters for the respective programs and includes them in the related documents.

Ensure assessment of the sufficiency of matrices by the Comptroller General, who will review them and submit assessments to congressional defense committees, identifying any cost, schedule, or performance trends.
Tags: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, Section 1090 ("Conduct of weather reconnaissance in the United States")
Casual name: FY2024 NDAA, Section 1090 ("Conduct of weather reconnaissance in the United States")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions
Short summary: Instructs the 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron of the Air Force Reserve Command to use autonomous platform observations to improve water management decision-making and flood forecasting, if the Squadron uses certain available resources.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Commerce to submit to the congressional science committees a report on the resources necessary for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to invest in emerging technologies that improve weather forecasting.

Permits the 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron of the Air Force Reserve Command and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to use aircraft, personnel, and equipment necessary to improve the accuracy and efficacy of weather monitoring and water management, including through advanced technological methods.

Instructs the Squadron to use autonomous platform observations to improve water management decision-making and flood forecasting, if it uses the resources named in the above paragraph.

Requires the Secretary of the Air Force to submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the resources used and required by the Air Force and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to improve weather monitoring and water management.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Performance requirements;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: An Act Concerning Artificial Intelligence, Automated Decision-Making and Personal Data Privacy
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence, Automated Decision-Making and Personal Data Privacy Act
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires the state government to establish a public inventory of its use of artificial intelligence systems and to mandate impact assessments of its AI systems to prevent unlawful discrimination; establishes a working group to make recommendations on the state government's use of AI systems
Long summary:
Requires the Department of Administrative Services to establish a public inventory of state agencies' existing use of AI systems; this inventory should include whether the system was employed to independently make or inform decisions, and whether it undergone an impact assessment before implementation

Requires the Office of Policy and Management to develop policies to govern state agencies' procurement and use of AI systems; this includes requiring state agencies to conduct impact assessments for these systems and to ensure systems do not unlawfully discriminate against individuals or groups

Bans state agencies from implementing any AI system unless it had performed an impact assessment to prevent unlawful discrimination, effective February 1 2024

Requires the Judicial Department to establish a public inventory of its systems that employ AI, including whether the AI system had undergone impact assessments and was used to make or support conclusions; also requires the department to introduce policies to govern the use of AI, and to prevent unlawful discrimination

Establishes a working group comprising industry representatives and academics to engage stakeholders and experts and make recommendations on the state government's use of AI; this includes recommendations on the adoption of a Connecticut artificial intelligence bill of rights based on the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy's 'Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights'
Tags: Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Discrimination;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified

Official name: Platform Accountability and Transparency Act, Section 9 ("Rulemaking authority")
Casual name: Platform Accountability and Transparency Act, Section 9 ("Rulemaking authority")
Short summary: Mandates regulations for data provision, public content repositories, and ad disclosure. Compels algorithm reporting and content moderation transparency.
Long summary:
Requires platforms to make available public repositories of highly disseminated content and major public accounts, including content samples and metadata.

Obligates platforms to disclose advertising information, including ad content, targeting parameters, and dissemination metrics, while protecting user privacy.

Requires disclosure of the use of platform algorithms in the recommendation, amplification, or restriction of content and advertising

Compels platforms to report on recommender and ranking algorithms, detailing inputs, objectives, and significant changes, without revealing trade secrets.

Demands transparency in content moderation, with statistics on policy violations, identification methods (including artificial intelligence), and government orders.
Tags: Applications: Sales, retail, and customer relations;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Risk factors: Privacy;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs

Official name: Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act of 2024
Casual name: Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to establish a program to create and maintain testing standards for computational forensic software, including AI-enabled software for evidence analysis.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish a program (“Testing Standards”) to create and maintain testing standards for computational forensic software, which includes software that relies on AI-enabled automated or semiautomated computational processes to analyze or interpret evidence.

Requires Testing Standards to solicit public input, address the potential for disparate impacts on protected groups, and specify requirements for publicly available documentation by developers, validation processes by those using computational forensic software, reports provided to defendants regarding software used, and how to test software and report results. 

Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to establish a program (“Testing Program”) that tests computational forensic algorithms according to the testing standards, using realistic and representative sample data and adversarial examples, and publishing results. Requires software to be re-tested after significant changes. 

Requires Federal law enforcement agencies only to use computational forensic software tested by NIST’s Testing Program and only after conducting an internal validation and making results publicly available. 

Requires evidence from computational forensic software to be admissible only if it has been submitted to NIST’s Testing Program and the developers waive legal claims against the defense analyzing or testing it. Requires information about the software (e.g., source code) and results from analyses by the software to be shared with the defendant.
