Official name: Investing in Tomorrow's Workforce Act of 2023
Casual name: Investing in Tomorrow's Workforce Act of 2023

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Accountability Act
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence Accountability Act
Short summary: Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to conduct a study on accountability mechanisms to provide assurances that an artificial intelligence (AI) system is trustworthy and hold public meetings to gather feedback on the disclosure of information about AI systems.
Long summary:
Requires the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to study accountability mechanisms (e.g., audits, certifications, and assessments) that provide assurances that an AI system is trustworthy. This includes defining terms around AI “trustworthiness,” examining how mechanisms are incorporated into AI systems, and assessing their ability to reduce risks related to AI systems, such as cybersecurity threats. 

Requires the Assistant Secretary to solicit stakeholder feedback through public meetings while carrying out the study above and to report the study’s findings to Congress, including recommendations on effective accountability measures for AI systems. 

Requires the Assistant Secretary to consult with stakeholders through public meetings and report to Congress on what information should be disclosed to those who interact with, are affected by, or study AI systems, and the most effective methods for doing so.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Applications: Networking and telecommunications;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Licensing, registration, and certification;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Risk factors: Reliability;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: Federal Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Act of 2023
Casual name: Federal Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance on how federal agencies can use NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework to reduce risks.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on how federal agencies can use NIST’s AI Risk Management Framework (RMF) to reduce risks, covering cybersecurity for AI systems, requirements for AI suppliers, and training for agencies.

Requires the Comptroller General of the United States to assess the impact of NIST's AI RMF on agencies' AI use within a year, and requires the Director of OMB to report to Congress on agency implementation and adherence to NIST’s AI RMF within a year, and subsequently, at least once every three years.

Excludes national security systems from the requirements above to adhere to NIST’s AI RMF.

Requires the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council to issue guidance on agency AI procurement within a year, to ensure compliance with NIST’s AI RMF.

Requires the Director of OMB to establish an initiative to build agencies’ AI expertise, focusing on hiring interdisciplinary experts and incorporating best practices from existing initiatives.

Requires the Director of NIST to conduct a study on and convene stakeholders to develop voluntary consensus standards to test and evaluate AI acquisitions, develop methods and conduct evaluations, monitor evaluations and adjust methods, and make recommendations to each agency on risks from relevant AI acquisitions.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Governance development;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: External auditing;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development;Risk factors: Safety;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Environmental Impacts Act of 2024
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence Environmental Impacts Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to submit a report to Congress on the environmental impacts of artificial intelligence
Long summary:
Requires the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to study  the environmental impacts of artificial intelligence, with a report on its findings submitted to Congress within two years of the Act's enactment.

Mandates that the EPA study examine the energy, water consumption, and pollution throughout the full lifecycle of AI models, hardware, and data centers, considering the effects of location, power sources, and AI model design on these environmental impacts.

Requires that the EPA study assess the positive environmental impacts associated with the use of AI, such as optimizing systems for energy efficiency or automatically monitoring environmental changes.

Directs the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to work with other government officials to form a consortium comprising academic, civil society, and industry representatives to assess and report on AI's environmental impacts, including the feasibility of open-source tools for measurement and recommendations to mitigate negative environmental effects.

Instructs the Director of NIST to work with other government officials and the consortium to establish a voluntary reporting system for entities to report on their AI systems' environmental impact.

Requires the Administrator of EPA, Secretary of Energy and Director of NIST to submit a joint report on the consortium's findings and its proposed voluntary reporting system within four years of the Act's enactment.
Tags: Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs;Harms: Ecological harm;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Harms: Ecological harm;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Harms: Ecological harm;Harms: Ecological harm;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report

Official name: Closing Loopholes for the Overseas Use and Development of Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: CLOUD AI Act
Short summary: Prohibits US persons and subsidiaries from supporting the use of remote or cloud integrated circuits by entities in China.
Long summary: Grants authority to the Secretary of Commerce to prohibit US persons and subsidiaries from supporting the use of remote or cloud integrated circuits listed under Export Control Classification Number 3A090 and 4A090 of the Export Administration Regulations by entities located in the People’s Republic of China or Macau.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Security;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: Creating Resources for Every American To Experiment with Artificial Intelligence Act of 2023
Casual name: CREATE AI Act of 2023

Official name: Eliminating Bias in Algorithmic Systems Act of 2023
Casual name: Eliminating Bias in Algorithmic Systems Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires agencies that use, fund, or oversee algorithms to establish civil rights offices with bias experts. Mandates biennial reports to Congress on algorithmic bias, risks and actions taken to mitigate them.
Long summary:
Requires agencies which use or oversee a covered algorithm to have an office of civil rights employing experts and technologists on bias, discrimination, and algorithmic harms.

Mandates these offices to submit biennial reports to Congress detailing risks from use of algorithms using artificial intelligence techniques within the agency's jurisdiction, mitigation steps, actions taken to engage stakeholders, and recommendations for further mitigation of algorithmic bias and discrimination.

Establishes an interagency working group on covered algorithms and civil rights, led by the Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division.
Tags: Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Risk factors: Bias;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Strategies: New institution;Risk factors: Bias;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: New institution

Official name: To establish a Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, and for other purposes.
Casual name: HR3168, 2023, Joint Autonomy Office Establishment
Short summary: Establishes the Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, responsible for coordinating and accelerating the adoption of all-domain autonomous systems for operational users, and for developing a Department-wide classification framework for autonomous capabilities.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Defense to establish the Joint Autonomy Office in the Department of Defense, responsible for coordinating and accelerating the adoption of all-domain autonomous systems for operational users, including through the adoption of commercial and defense best practices

Requires the Office to implement an all-domain enterprise autonomous systems software development and testing platform across DoD's classification levels, including an all-domain data acquisition and curation process to build and manage datasets; these datasets and platforms should be released to various services and acquisition programs as they mature.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to ensure that the Office has unlimited access to existing datasets regardless of classification level, and to introduce security protocols to protect data shared with or maintained by the Office.

Requires the Director of the Office must establish a Department-wide classification framework for autonomous capabilities, considering the complexity of autonomous systems, the necessity of human supervision or control, their applicability to various warfighting domains, and costs; the Director must submit this framework along with an explanation of its criteria and requirements to Congress, with updates released no less frequently than once every two years.

Requires the Director to develop and implement plans to standardize planning, resource and integration of autonomous capabilities across the Department; this includes a report assessing the Department's current efforts which identifies acquisition, training and evaluation gaps, as well as recommendations to address these.

Official name: Basic Allowance for Housing Calculation Improvement Act of 2023
Casual name: Basic Allowance for Housing Calculation Improvement Act of 2023
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Defense to conduct a pilot program to use AI for calculating monthly rates of basic allowance for housing.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Defense to conduct a pilot program to outsource the calculation of monthly Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) rates using machine learning and artificial intelligence algorithms by engaging a covered entity.

Mandates the submission of a report to the Senate and House Armed Services Committees evaluating the AI-calculated rates.
Tags: Strategies: Pilots and testbeds;Applications: Government: benefits and welfare;Strategies: Government study or report

Official name: Healthy Technology Act of 2023
Casual name: Healthy Technology Act of 2023
Short summary: Authorizes artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies to prescribe pharmaceutical drugs if approved by the State involved and the Food and Drug Administration
Long summary:
Amends the definition of 'practitioner licensed by law to administer such a drug' in Section 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, to include artificial intelligence and machine learning technology

Authorizes AI and ML technology to prescribe pharmaceutical drugs if approved by the State in question, and if approved by the Food and Drug Administration 

Requires such AI and ML technology to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration through conventional channels, including having to provide 90 days' premarket notification if this is deemed a new device
Tags: Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Strategies: Evaluation

Official name: Preventing Deep Fake Scams Act
Casual name: Preventing Deep Fake Scams Act
Short summary: Establishes a task force to help formulate appropriate AI regulations in the financial services industry and requires the task force to produce a report for Congress with these recommendations within one year.
Long summary:
Establishes a task force examining the fraudulent use of artificial intelligence in the financial services sector.

Instruct the task force to solicit public feedback from industry and expert stakeholders, including depository institutions, credit unions, third-party vendors, and AI experts.

Directs the task force to produce a report for Congress within one year that identifies potential risks from AI misuse, and proposes AI fraud detection measures, among other legislative recommendations.

Terminates the task force 90 days after the final report's issue.
Tags: Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Business services and analytics;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Business services and analytics;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Business services and analytics;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Harms: Financial loss;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified

Official name: AI for National Security Act
Casual name: AI for National Security Act
Short summary: Amends Section 1521 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 to expand the Department of Defense's procurement of cyber data products and services to include AI-driven endpoint security and to strengthen software supply chain security.
Long summary:
Amends Section 1521 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 to expand the Department of Defense's procurement of cyber data products and services to include AI-driven endpoint security and to strengthen software supply chain security.

Inserts a provision to enhance the security of the software supply chain of the Department of Defense using AI.
Tags: Applications: Government: military and public safety;Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Government support

Official name: FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023
Casual name: FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023
Short summary: Cites the Act as the "FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023." Requires FinCEN to establish research and information-sharing programs on technological advances. Mandates exploration of beneficial innovations. Obligates adoption of necessary technologies. Enables information exchange. Authorizes non-standard transactions. Compels annual reporting to Congress.
Long summary:
Cites the Act as the "FinCEN Modernization Act of 2023."

Requires FinCEN to establish research, development, and information-sharing programs focusing on technological advances like machine learning and data analytics.

Mandates FinCEN to explore and evaluate technological innovations beneficial for financial systems and detect illicit activities.

Obligates FinCEN to adopt necessary technologies for monitoring cryptocurrencies and addressing money laundering and cyber threats.

Enables FinCEN to exchange information with other Treasury offices and federal departments.

Authorizes FinCEN to enter into non-standard transactions and accept contributions, gifts, or donations to support technological advancements.

Compels FinCEN to submit an annual report detailing transactions, contributions, and their justifications and purposes to relevant Congressional committees.
Tags: Strategies: Government support: For R&D

Official name: Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act
Casual name: Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act
Short summary: Prohibits knowingly distributing materially deceptive AI-generated media related to Federal elections.
Long summary:
Prohibits knowingly distributing materially deceptive AI-generated audio or visual media related to Federal election activities or candidates. Exempts broadcasters, streaming services, and periodicals if they disclose authenticity concerns and covers bona fide news or satire. 

Allows affected candidates to seek injunctive relief or damages, including attorney's fees, for violations. Requires plaintiffs to prove violations with clear and convincing evidence.
Tags: Harms: Detrimental content;Risk factors: Reliability;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Applications: Broadcasting and media production;Incentives: Civil liability;Incentives: Fines

Official name: Disincentivizing Internet Service Censorship of Online Users and Restrictions on Speech and Expression Act
Casual name: DISCOURSE Act
Short summary: Amends Section 230 to limit liability protections for dominant service providers. Deems providers as content creators if they manage content or use targeted algorithms with a discernible viewpoint. Excludes protections for actions against religious material. Mandates public disclosure of content management practices. Reclassifies immunity as an affirmative defense.
Long summary:
Amends Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 to limit liability protections for dominant interactive computer service providers based on their content management practices.

Deems providers as content creators if they engage in content moderation or use targeted algorithmic amplification that expresses, promotes, or suppresses a discernible viewpoint.

Excludes liability protections for actions against religious material that burden the exercise of religion.

Mandates public disclosure of content management mechanisms and practices by providers to enable informed consumer choices and entrepreneurial activities.

Reclassifies immunity under Section 230 as an affirmative defense, requiring providers or users to prove they are not information content providers in legal actions.
Tags: Incentives: Civil liability

Official name: Tornado Observations Research and Notification Assessment for Development of Operations Act
Casual name: TORNADO Act
Short summary: Requires the Under Secretary of Commerce to improve NOAA's communication system for hazardous events using methods such data analysis supported by artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.
Long summary:
Requires the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere to improve the communication system of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for hazardous weather and water events to prevent loss of life and property.

Mandates the establishment of a hazard risk communication office to simplify and improve communication, using the latest social, behavioral, risk, and communication science research, including AI and machine learning technologies.

Instructs the Under Secretary to create a research program to modernize risk-based hazard communication and establish a pilot program for tornado hazard communication.
Tags: Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government support

Official name: Protecting the Information of our Vulnerable Adolescents, Children, and Youth Act
Casual name: Kids PRIVACY Act
Short summary: Defines "process" as an operation, potentially automated, performed on "covered information" including collecting, disclosing, inferring, etc. Mandates "verifiable consent" before processing of data, data minimization, data access transparency, security measures, and limits to harmful practices.
Long summary:
Defines "process" as an operation, potentially automated, performed on "covered information" including collecting, disclosing, inferring, etc.

Mandates obtaining "verifiable consent" from teenagers or parents before processing their data.

Requires operators to minimize data collection and retain data only as necessary.

Obligates transparency and the provision of a clear privacy policy detailing data practices.

Prohibits targeted advertising and harmful data processing practices.

Establishes rights for teenagers and parents to access, correct, and delete data.

Imposes strict security measures for processing children's and teenagers' data.

Official name: Stop Fentanyl at the Border Act
Casual name: Stop Fentanyl at the Border Act
Short summary:
Appropriates $1,090,000,000 to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for technology improvements to enhance fentanyl interdiction.

Appropriates $223,000,000 to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to expand fentanyl interdiction and disrupt transnational criminal networks.

Mandates submission of reports by March 31, 2028, on impacts of Border Patrol Processing Coordinator positions and equipment needs.

Creates penalties for damaging or evading border controls, with fines and imprisonment up to 5 years for violations aimed at financial gain or furthering criminal organizations.
Long summary:
Appropriates $1,090,000,000 to U.S. Customs and Border Protection for technology improvements, including non-intrusive inspection scanning systems and anomaly detection algorithms, to enhance fentanyl interdiction at land borders.

Appropriates $223,000,000 to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to expand efforts to interdict fentanyl and disrupt transnational criminal networks, including funds for additional special agents and joint surge operations.

Mandates submission of reports by March 31, 2028, detailing impacts of Border Patrol Processing Coordinator positions, equipment needs for outbound inspections, and summaries of non-intrusive inspection technology at land ports of entry.

Creates penalties for knowingly damaging or evading border controls, with fines and imprisonment up to 5 years for violations aimed at securing financial gain or furthering criminal organizations.
Tags: Applications: Government: judicial and law enforcement;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Strategies: Government support;Incentives: Fines;Incentives: Imprisonment

Official name: No ICBMs or Drones for Iran Act of 2023
Casual name: No ICBMs or Drones for Iran Act of 2023
Short summary: Expands and incorporates sanctions related to Iranian unmanned aerial systems (UAS). Mandates a strategy against, and reports on support for, Iran’s UAS program.
Long summary:
Expands sanctions under the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability, and Divestment Act of 2010 to include unmanned aerial systems (UAS).

Incorporates UAS under arms embargos of the Countering America’s Adversaries Through Sanctions Act and Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992.

Requires the President to submit a strategy to counter Iran's UAS program including export controls of US materials, identification of actors supporting Iran's UAS program, assessment of compliance with such restrictions, and coordination with US allies in furtherance of these actions

Mandates a report on support for Iran’s UAS program from domestic industries, individuals, or entities in Iran and related technology transfers to foreign actors, to be updated as necessary.
Tags: Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Evaluation;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: Government study or report

Official name: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Meta)
Casual name: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Meta)
Short summary: Commits to responsible AI development through safety, security, privacy, and transparency; following White House Commitments to ensure AI guardrails. Conducted extensive model evaluations, red teaming, and information sharing.
Long summary:
Commits Meta to responsible AI development, prioritizing safety and transparency in AI systems, including the Llama 2 model.

Demonstrates actions taken in furtherance of the White House Commitments to establish AI guardrails, focusing on safety, security, and trust.

Conducted extensive model evaluations and red teaming, including external testing at DEFCON, to identify and mitigate risks in AI models including adversarial inputs like unqualified advice.

Requires information sharing and reporting on AI vulnerabilities with established feedback mechanisms for continuous improvement.

Implemented robust security controls for AI model weights to ensure model relliability, treating them as core intellectual property.

Participated in industry initiatives like the Synthetic Media Framework to ensure identification and disclosure of AI-generated content.

Invested in research on AI societal, safety, and security risks, and collaborates with policymakers through the Open Loop program.

Conducted privacy reviews for AI data inputs, excluding private user data, and offers users control over data shared with generative AI features.

Official name: OpenAI's Approach to Frontier Risk (An Update for the UK AI Safety Summit)
Casual name: OpenAI's Approach to Frontier Risk (An Update for the UK AI Safety Summit)
Short summary: Describes OpenAI's progress on realizing the company's voluntary commitments to promote safety, security, and trust in AI, initially made in July 2023. Details OpenAI's approach to mitigating frontier risks, which are the focus of the UK AI Safety Summit, and the development of a Preparedness Framework.
Long summary:
States that OpenAI's is establishing a Preparedness Framework to manage risks from frontier AI models, focusing on a development process governance structure and preemption of catastrophic outcomes; this work will complement existing risk mitigation work and includes a joint Deployment Safety Board with Microsoft. 

States that OpenAI is creating Superalignment and Preparedness teams within the company to align AI systems with human intent and track and prepare for frontier risks, including cybersecurity, CBRN, persuasion, and autonomous replication and adaptation. Notes that OpenAI is also increasing investment into cybersecurity and insider threat safeguards.

States that OpenAI implemened red-teaming and evaluations to assess new models for safety, including GPT-4 and DALL-E 3, focusing on dual-use capabilities, cybersecurity vulnerabilities, and self-replication.

States that OpenAI will include the publication of a system card in every new AI system, which informs users of key factors impacting system behavior.

States that OpenAI has initiated a reporting mechanism for responsible disclosure of dangerous capabilities among AI labs, focusing on national security-related risks.

Details OpenAI's emphasis post-deployment monitoring for misuse, security controls to protect intellectual property and data, and the development progress provenance techniques to identify AI-generated content.

States that OpenAI implemented data input controls and provides mechanisms for users to opt-out of their data being used for AI training.

Official name: OpenAI Charter
Casual name: OpenAI Charter
Short summary: Summarizes OpenAI's Charter, the company's principles for building safe and beneficial artificial general intelligence.
Long summary:
Establishes that OpenAI commits to using influence over AGI deployment to ensure it benefits all of humanity and avoids harm or power concentration.

Establishes that OpenAI pledges to assist other safety-conscious AGI projects nearing completion, rather than compete, under specific conditions.

Establishes that OpenAI strives for technical leadership alongside policy and safety advocacy and will cooperate with other research and policy institutions.

Establishes that OpenAI is committed to providing public goods and will publish the majority of its research while acknowledging potential safety and security constraints on traditional AI research publishing.
Tags: Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Convening

Official name: Frontier AI Safety Commitments, AI Seoul Summit 2024
Casual name: Frontier AI Safety Commitments, AI Seoul Summit 2024
Short summary: Announces on behalf of the UK and Republic of Korea governments companies that have committed to the Frontier AI Safety Commitments. Outlines three outcomes related to frontier AI safety that companies are expected to realize.
Long summary:
Announces on behalf of the UK and Republic of Korea governments companies, including Amazon, Google, and OpenAI, that have committed to the Frontier AI Safety Commitments. Mandates that companies publish a safety framework, requires transparency on evolving safety approaches, and implement various best practices.

Defines outcome one as organizations identifying, assessing, and managing risks when developing and deploying frontier AI systems. Defines five sub-outcomes, including internal and external evaluations, establishment of risk thresholds and response processes for violations, and investment in risk mitigation effectiveness.

Defines outcome two as organizational accountability established through the development and review of governance frameworks. 

Defines outcome three as established transparency about organizational approaches to frontier AI safety for external actors, including governments. Mandates provision of information about best practice implementation to the public and explanation of how external actors are involved in risk assessment and framework adherence.

Official name: Black Maternal Health Omnibus Act, Sec. 904 (Report on the Use of Technology in Maternity Care)
Casual name: Black Maternal Health Omnibus Act, Sec. 904 (Report on the Use of Technology in Maternity Care)
Short summary: Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to commission a study on technology in maternity care. Requires examination of AI's impact on racial and ethnic biases. Includes patient monitoring devices. Specifies identification of bias reduction practices. Directs completion within 24 months.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to enter an agreement with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to study the use of technology in maternity care.

Requires the study to examine the use of innovative technology, including artificial intelligence, and its impact on racial or ethnic biases in maternal health care.

Includes patient monitoring devices, such as pulse oximeters, in the scope of the study, with a focus on their effect on racial or ethnic biases.

Outlines identification of best practices for reducing and preventing biases in the use of technology and monitoring devices in maternity care.

Requires the study to recommend best practices for using technology and monitoring devices for pregnant and postpartum individuals from minority groups.

Mandates the inclusion of best practices regarding privacy and security safeguards in the use of such technologies.

Directs the National Academies to complete the study and submit a report to Congress within 24 months of the Act's enactment.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Harms: Discrimination;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Safety;Applications: Medicine, life sciences and public health;Applications: Security;Strategies: Government study or report

Official name: Federal Improvement in Technology Procurement Act
Casual name: FIT Procurement Act
Short summary: Requires the Federal Acquisition Institute to incorporate experiential learning into certification programs within 18 months. Mandates a cross-functional ICT acquisition training program. Encourages off-the-shelf technologies and innovative procurement techniques. Reassigns AI training responsibility to GSA. Expands Commercial Solutions Opening Authority. Increases simplified acquisition threshold to $500,000. Requires Administrator to issue past performance guidance. Establishes a working group to address Federal vendor base issues.
Long summary:
Requires the Federal Acquisition Institute to incorporate experiential learning into key acquisition certification programs within 18 months.

Mandates the development and implementation of a cross-functional ICT acquisition training program, emphasizing market research, cloud computing, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity.

Encourages the use of commercially available off-the-shelf technologies and innovative procurement techniques like oral presentations and product demonstrations.

Reassigns the responsibility for AI training requirements from the Office of Management and Budget to the General Services Administration.

Expands the Commercial Solutions Opening Authority to include commercial services and mandates public reporting and data collection on its use.

Increases the simplified acquisition threshold from $250,000 to $500,000.

Requires the Administrator to issue guidance on using past performance from a broader range of projects to increase competition.

Establishes a working group to address the shrinking Federal vendor base and recommends actions to remove barriers to qualified vendors.
Tags: Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: New institution

Official name: Protecting Consumers from Deceptive AI Act
Casual name: Protecting Consumers from Deceptive AI Act
Short summary: Directs the NIST to establish task forces to develop standards for identifying AI-generated content. Mandates disclosures of AI origins through robust watermarks and content provenance metadata.
Long summary:
Directs the NIST to establish task forces focused on the development of technical guidelines for identifying and labeling AI-generated content, including metadata, watermarking, and digital fingerprinting.

Supports the development of standards to provide cryptographically verifiable content provenance metadata and robust watermarks. 

Requires providers of generative AI applications to ensure that content created or modified by such applications includes a disclosure of its AI origin, and to collaborate with providers of covered online platforms to provide these disclosures to users.

Prohibits online platforms from removing such disclosures and mandates clear display of AI origin information to users.

Enforces compliance under the Federal Trade Commission Act.

Defines self-regulatory guidelines approved by the FTC as compliance alternatives.

Official name: Living Wage for Musicians Act of 2024
Casual name: Living Wage for Musicians Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits AI entities from being classified as artists and requires the Federal Register to establish the Artist Compensation Royalty Fund.
Long summary:
Prohibits artificial intelligence entities from being classified as artists under this act.

Requires the establishment of the Artist Compensation Royalty Fund to help provide financial support to those whose employment was negatively impacted by AI.

Mandates service providers to collect and deposit a living wage royalty fee and a percentage of non-subscription revenue into the Fund.

Authorizes the Fund Administrator to impose penalties for violations and non-compliance by service providers.

Official name: Protect Victims of Digital Exploitation and Manipulation Act of 2024
Casual name: Protect Victims of Digital Exploitation and Manipulation Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits producing or distributing digital forgeries of intimate visuals without consent, with penalties up to 5 years imprisonment or fines. Exempts good faith distributions for specific purposes. Excludes service providers unless reckless. Defines digital forgery. Establishes extraterritorial jurisdiction. Ensures severability.
Long summary:
Prohibits the production or distribution of digital forgeries of intimate visual depictions of identifiable individuals without their consent, under penalty of fines or imprisonment up to 5 years.

Exempts distributions made in good faith to law enforcement, during legal proceedings, for medical purposes, or in reporting/investigating unlawful content or conduct.

Excludes communications service providers from liability unless they knowingly or recklessly distribute such content.

Defines "digital forgery" as intimate visual depictions created or altered using software, machine learning, AI, or other computer-generated means to appear authentic.

Establishes extraterritorial jurisdiction if the offender or victim is a U.S. national.

Ensures severability of the Act’s provisions if any part is found unconstitutional.

Official name: Eliminating Abusive and Rampant Neglect of Interactive Technologies Act of 2023 (National Commission on Online Child Sexual Exploitation Prevention)
Casual name: EARN IT Act of 2023, Sec. 3 (National Commission on Online Child Sexual Exploitation Prevention)
Short summary: Establishes a National Commission on Online Child Sexual Exploitation Prevention and tasks the Commission with developing best practices for interactive computer service providers.
Long summary:
Establishes a National Commission on Online Child Sexual Exploitation Prevention. Tasks the Commission with developing recommended best practices for interactive computer service providers to prevent, reduce, and respond to online child sexual exploitation. 

Composes the Commission of 19 members, including federal officials and appointees with specific expertise in law enforcement, prosecution, victim services, consumer protection, civil liberties, privacy, computer science, and industry representation. Requires two members to have experience in cryptography, data security, or artificial intelligence. Designates the Attorney General or their representative as the Chairperson.

Official name: Kids Online Safety Act, Title II (Filter Bubble Transparency)
Casual name: Kids Online Safety Act, Title II (Filter Bubble Transparency)
Short summary: Requires platforms using opaque algorithms to notify users about their use and data application and mandates the option to switch to input-transparent algorithms.
Long summary:
Requires online platforms using opaque algorithms to provide users with clear notice about the use of such algorithms and how user-specific data is utilized. 

Mandates platforms to allow users to easily switch between opaque algorithms and input-transparent algorithms. Prohibits differential pricing or service denial based on a user's choice to use an input-transparent algorithm.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to enforce these requirements as violations of unfair or deceptive practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act. 

Ensures that trade secrets, confidential business information, or privileged data are not required to be disclosed. Preserves the ability of platforms to allow users to personalize content restrictions and interactions.
Tags: Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: About inputs

Official name: A Stronger Workforce for America Act, Chapter 3 (Performance Accountability)
Casual name: A Stronger Workforce for America Act, Chapter 3 (Performance Accountability)
Short summary: Amends the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to allow states to use machine learning and advanced analytics in the improvement of state program operations and outcomes.
Long summary: Amends the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to allow states to use machine learning and advanced analytics in the improvement of state program operations and outcomes.
Tags: Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government support

Official name: Government Surveillance Reform Act of 2023, Title VII (Protection of Car Data from Warrantless Searches)
Casual name: Government Surveillance Reform Act of 2023, Title VII (Protection of Car Data from Warrantless Searches)
Short summary: Prohibits law enforcement from accessing vehicle data without a warrant, except with operator consent or in emergencies.
Long summary:
Prohibits law enforcement from accessing vehicle data without a warrant, except with operator consent or in emergencies. 

Defines "covered vehicle data" to include all onboard and telematics data in noncommercial vehicles, excluding certain data types like automotive software and geolocation data for traffic enforcement.
Prohibits the use of any vehicle data obtained in violation of these provisions as evidence in any legal proceedings. Amends the Driver Privacy Act of 2015 to align with these new restrictions on accessing vehicle data.

Official name: Securing Elections From AI Deception Act
Casual name: Securing Elections From AI Deception Act
Short summary: Prohibits the use of AI to interfere with elections and deprive individuals of the right to vote. Mandates disclaimers on election-related AI-generated content.
Long summary:
Prohibits developers and deployers from using AI to intentionally deceive or defraud individuals of their voting rights in federal, state, or local elections.

Requires election-related AI-generated content to include disclaimers, informing the public that the content was created using AI.

Mandates developers to provide mechanisms ensuring such disclaimers are permanent or difficult to remove.

Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to issue regulations on disclaimer requirements and enforce compliance.

Obliges developers and deployers to ensure their algorithms meet safety and efficiency standards as outlined.
Tags: Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Detrimental content;Incentives: Fines;Incentives: Imprisonment;Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: In deployment;Strategies: Disclosure: In standard form;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Civil liability;Strategies: Government study or report;Risk factors: Safety;Risk factors: Reliability;Incentives: Civil liability;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring

Official name: Social Media and AI Resiliency Toolkits in Schools Act
Casual name: SMART in Schools Act
Short summary: Mandates development and updates of AI and social media impact toolkits on youth. Requires stakeholder consultation. Specifies evidence-based content on digital resilience. Directs tailored guidance inclusion. Instructs dissemination through institutions. Authorizes $2,000,000 for implementation.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretaries of Education and Health & Human Services to develop educational toolkits about artificial intelligence (AI) and social media's impact on youth.

Requires consultation with various relevant stakeholders, including students, parents & guardians, educators, administrators, and healthcare professionals, to develop the toolkits.

Specifies guidelines for each different type of toolkit, to be appropriately targeted to their multiple intended audiences: students, parents & guardians, educators, administrators, and healthcare professionals.

Directs the Secretaries to develop toolkit dissemination strategies, so that the resources reach their intended audiences.

Authorizes $2,000,000 for facilitating the dissemination of the toolkits.
Tags: Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Detrimental content;Applications: Education;Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Education;Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Tiering;Applications: Education;Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Risk factors: Transparency;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Tiering;Applications: Education;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Education

Official name: Tools to Address Known Exploitation by Immobilizing Technological Deepfakes on Websites and Networks Act
Casual name: TAKE IT DOWN Act
Short summary:
Amends the Communications Act to criminalize nonconsensual intimate deepfakes and requires platforms to remove deepfakes within 48 hours.

Grants the Federal Trade Commission enforcement authority over this act.
Long summary:
Amends the Communications Act to criminalize the non-consensual production and dissemination of pornography, especially when intended to cause harm or when involving minors.

Requires covered platforms to establish a takedown process for such depictions, and mandates them to remove the content within 48 hours upon valid request.

Levels criminal punishments, including imprisonment, on violators of this law.

Grants enforcement authority to the Federal Trade Commission.

Defines key terms relevant to the instrument, including "covered platform," "deepfake," and "intimate visual depiction."
Tags: Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Detrimental content;Harms: Financial loss;Strategies: Governance development;Incentives: Criminal liability;Incentives: Imprisonment;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Safety;Harms: Harm to health/safety;Harms: Financial loss;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Harms: Detrimental content;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: AI Leadership To Enable Accountable Deployment Act
Casual name: AI LEAD Act
Short summary: Establishes the Chief AI Officers Council to promote and coordinate AI innovation and risk management. Requires each agency to appoint a CAIO responsible for developing and implementing AI strategies.
Long summary:
Establishes the Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council to promote AI innovation, oversee compliance, and advise on best practices for AI technologies.

Requires each agency to designate a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer responsible for promoting AI use, managing risks, and ensuring transparency and privacy.

Mandates the creation of Artificial Intelligence Coordination Boards within agencies to address AI issues and publish guiding principles and goals.

Directs agencies to develop an AI strategy focused on responsible and trustworthy adoption, public trust, risk mitigation, and interagency coordination.

Requires the Comptroller General to report on the effectiveness of AI Coordination Boards, evaluate Chief AI Officers, and assess AI costs, benefits, and risks, including job impacts.

Directs the Office of Management and Budget Director to issue updated AI governance guidance within five years.
Tags: Applications: Government: benefits and welfare;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Security;Risk factors: Reliability: Robustness;Risk factors: Reliability;Harms: Violation of civil or human rights, including privacy;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Transparency;Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Reliability;Risk factors: Interpretability and explainability;Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Strategies: Governance development;Strategies: New institution;Risk factors: Privacy;Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Reliability;Strategies: Convening;Strategies: Government support;Applications: Government: military and public safety;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Evaluation: Conformity assessment;Strategies: Evaluation: Post-market monitoring;Risk factors: Bias;Risk factors: Reliability;Risk factors: Privacy;Strategies: Disclosure;Strategies: Disclosure: About evaluation;Harms: Financial loss;Strategies: Governance development

Official name: Promoting Responsible Evaluation and Procurement to Advance Readiness for Enterprise-wide Deployment for Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: PREPARED for AI Act
Short summary: Establishes a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council. Mandates risk classification for AI use. Prohibits specific AI activities, including emotion detection. Directs procurement updates. Requires AI risk evaluation and monitoring. Stipulates documentation and transparency. Establishes annual reporting. Prohibits high-risk AI uses.
Long summary:
Requires the establishment of a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officers Council to coordinate AI use in federal agencies.

Mandates agencies to develop risk classification systems for AI use cases, categorizing them as unacceptable, high, medium, or low risk.

Prohibits AI use for certain activities, such as mapping facial features for emotion detection or categorizing individuals based on biometric data for sensitive traits.

Directs updates to the Federal Acquisition Regulation to ensure AI procurement includes risk and impact assessments.

Requires agencies to implement processes for evaluating AI risks and to conduct ongoing monitoring, especially for high-risk use cases.

Stipulates comprehensive documentation and transparency requirements for AI models and data.

Establishes annual reporting protocols for obstacles in AI testing and evaluation, promoting interagency collaboration to address challenges.

Prohibits the use of AI for certain high-risk applications and mandates public disclosure of AI inventories and risk classifications.

Official name: Technology in the Parks Act of 2024
Casual name: Technology in the Parks Act of 2024
Short summary:
Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to extend E-rate support to local parks. 

Authorizes the Secretary of Labor to establish a grant program for technology training programs directed towards needy families in local parks.
Long summary:
Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to extend E-rate support to local parks, allowing them to access discounted telecommunications services for technology training programs.

Requires the creation of internet safety regulations for parks receiving such services to ensure cybersecurity standards similar to those for schools and libraries.

Mandates the Secretary of Labor to initiate a grant program for technology training directed towards needy families in local parks, focusing on topics like artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and web development.

Limits grant coverage to 10% of the training programs' operating costs and to a duration of no longer than two years.
Tags: Risk factors: Security: Cybersecurity;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Government: other applications/unspecified;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: AI workforce-related;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Education;Applications: Government: benefits and welfare

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Bug Bounty Act of 2023
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence Bug Bounty Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires the Department of Defense to develop a bug bounty program for AI products within 180 days. Authorizes program implementation and mandates contract compatibility. Directs briefing to Congress on program development and future plans within one year.
Long summary:
Mandates the Chief Data and Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of Defense to develop a bug bounty program for AI products within 180 days of enactment.

Allows collaboration with other government agencies possessing cybersecurity and AI expertise during program development.

Authorizes the implementation of the developed bug bounty program.

Ensures that Department of Defense contracts permit participation in the bug bounty program.

Clarifies that the use of foundational AI products or the implementation of the program is not mandatory for incorporating such products.

Requires the Chief to brief congressional defense committees within one year on the development, implementation, and long-term plans of relevant bug bounty programs.

Official name: Preventing Algorithmic Collusion Act of 2024
Casual name: Preventing Algorithmic Collusion Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits using pricing algorithms trained with nonpublic competitor data. Requires detailed reporting and certification of pricing algorithms used in commerce. Mandates transparency in algorithmic pricing for entities with over $5 million revenue. Establishes penalties for violations. Directs FTC to study pricing algorithms' impact.
Long summary:
Prohibits the use of pricing algorithms incorporating nonpublic competitor data.

Requires entities using or distributing pricing algorithms to submit detailed reports to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or Attorney General upon request, detailing development, data usage, and algorithmic rules.

Mandates certification of report accuracy by a high-level corporate officer.

Ensures confidentiality of submitted reports, allowing information sharing only between the Department of Justice, FTC, and National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Imposes civil penalties for violations, including fines and injunctive relief.

Presumes collusive behavior in antitrust cases involving certain uses of pricing algorithms, allowing for rebuttal and assigning joint liability.

Obligates disclosure to customers and employees when prices or terms are set by algorithms, including specifics on price discrimination and third-party algorithm developers.

Directs the FTC to study and report on the impact and prevalence of pricing algorithms within two years, including potential consumer harm and benefits.

Official name: AI Leadership Training Act
Casual name: AI Leadership Training Act
Short summary: Establishes an AI leadership training program for executive agencies. Requires annual training on AI capabilities, risks, and ethics. Mandates topics cover AI basics, risks, and constitutional issues. Obligates updates biennially. Demands participation metrics. Permits Congressional oversight. Sets a 10-year sunset clause.
Long summary:
Establishes an AI leadership training program for management officials, supervisors, and other designated employees in executive agencies, to be developed and implemented within 18 months.

Requires annual training to cover AI capabilities, risks, safety, ethics, Federal Government requirements, and best practices related to AI procurement, use, testing, evaluation, and auditing.

Mandates program topics include AI basics, benefits, risks, data significance, AI system failures, continuous refinement, risk mitigation, organizational considerations, and constitutional risks related to AI use.

Obligates updates to the program every two years to incorporate new AI information and ensure compliance with training requirements.

Demands metrics to measure participation and feedback for program improvements.

Permits Congress to request detailed information about the program materials and responsible personnel.

Encourages interaction with experts from various sectors as part of the training.

Sets a sunset clause for the program 10 years after enactment.

Official name: Supply Chain Mapping and Monitoring Act
Casual name: Supply Chain Mapping and Monitoring Act
Short summary: Establishes the Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office to monitor and enhance supply chain resilience. Includes AI, machine learning, and robotics as key technology areas. Coordinates with international partners and private sectors to identify vulnerabilities and ensure critical industry sustainability.
Long summary:
Establishes the Supply Chain Resiliency and Crisis Response Office within 180 days to monitor and enhance supply chain resilience, especially for critical industries and goods.

Mandates the Under Secretary to map, monitor, and model supply chains, identifying gaps and vulnerabilities.

Requires collaboration with federal agencies, private sector, labor organizations, and international partners to strengthen supply chains and prepare for shocks.

Involves continuous monitoring of supply chain resilience, diversity, and security, and mandates quadrennial reports on supply chain resiliency and domestic manufacturing.

Authorizes $500 million for fiscal years 2024-2028 to fund these activities, ensuring up to 2% per fiscal year for administrative costs.

Official name: Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act/AV Accessibility Act
Casual name: Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act/AV Accessibility Act
Short summary: Prohibits states from issuing licenses for Level 4 or 5 ADS-equipped vehicle operation that discriminate against individuals with disabilities. Requires the Secretary to study infrastructure improvements for accessible ride-hail ADS-equipped vehicles. Authorizes $5 million for this study.
Long summary:
Cites the Act as the “Autonomous Vehicle Accessibility Act” or the “AV Accessibility Act”.

Defines key terms including “disability,” “public transportation,” and “ride-hail ADS-equipped vehicle.”

Prohibits states from issuing licenses for Level 4 or Level 5 ADS-equipped vehicles in a manner that discriminates against individuals with disabilities, in accordance with the ADA.

Mandates the Secretary of Transportation to commission a study through the National Academies to identify changes needed in public transportation infrastructure to improve accessibility for individuals with disabilities using ride-hail ADS-equipped vehicles.

Authorizes $5,000,000 for the completion of the accessibility infrastructure study, available until expended.

Official name: Sensible Classification Act of 2023
Casual name: Sensible Classification Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires research and recommendation of AI and machine learning solutions for efficient classification and declassification. Mandates agency studies on security clearance necessity, aiming to reduce numbers. Emphasizes sensible classification and AI integration in information management.
Long summary:
Mandates the research and recommendation of AI and machine learning solutions for efficient classification and declassification systems, to be interoperable across the Federal Government.

Requires the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government to consult with key defense and intelligence agencies for technology implementation and submit a report on the recommended solution.

Obliges agencies granting security clearances to study and report on the necessity of such clearances, aiming to minimize personnel with access to classified information.

Instructs agency heads to ensure classification training promotes sensible classification and discourages over-classification.

Calls for the Public Interest Declassification Board to improve its operations, including staff expansion, to enhance declassification processes.

Demands independent reviews of agency studies and reports on security clearances by the Information Security Oversight Office, the Director of National Intelligence, and the Public Interest Declassification Board.

Official name: Computer Science for All Act of 2023
Casual name: Computer Science for All Act of 2023
Short summary: Establishes grants for States, local educational agencies, and Tribal schools to expand computer science education, emphasizing AI and STEAM. Requires training, materials, and equity in access, with a $250 million budget. Mandates detailed reporting on demographic impacts.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Education to award grants to states, local educational agencies, and eligible Tribal schools for expanding computer science education.

Mandates grant recipients to provide every high school student with access to computer science education within five years and ensure a progression of computer science education from prekindergarten through middle school.

Requires the use of grant funds for teacher training, expanding access to learning materials, and reducing equity gaps in STEAM education for underrepresented groups.

Permits grant funds to be used for building regional collaborations, hiring instructional personnel, and disseminating effective practices.

Limits use of grant funds for equipment purchases to 15%.

Authorizes $250 million for fiscal year 2024 and the following four fiscal years.

Requires grant recipients to report biannually on the use of funds and student demographics.

Mandates the Secretary to report to Congress within five years on program expansion recommendations.

Official name: Deceptive Experiences To Online Users Reduction Act
Casual name: DETOUR Act
Short summary: Prohibits large online operators from designing user interfaces that impair user autonomy or encourage compulsive usage. Requires affirmative express consent for certain research and mandates disclosure of such research. Establishes independent review boards and empowers the FTC to enforce compliance.
Long summary:
Prohibits large online operators from manipulating user interfaces to obscure, subvert, or impair user autonomy, decision making, or consent.

Requires affirmative express consent from users for covered research and prohibits manipulation aimed at children or teens to encourage compulsive usage.

Mandates large online operators to disclose the purpose of covered research to users every 90 days and ensure transparency.

Obligates large online operators to establish independent review boards to oversee user interface design and research, ensuring compliance and preventing exploitative practices.

Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop resources for user interface design promoting user autonomy, choice, and decision making.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission to enforce compliance, establish regulations for independent review boards, and define acceptable conduct for large online operators.

Provides safe harbor for operators acting in good faith per established guidelines.

Official name: Protect Working Musicians Act of 2023
Casual name: Protect Working Musicians Act of 2023
Short summary: Limits liability under antitrust laws for Individual Music Creator Owners who collectively negotiate or refuse licensing to Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms or generative AI companies. Specifies conditions for collective negotiations, ensuring consistency with antitrust operations.
Long summary:
Grants Independent Music Creator Owners immunity from antitrust liability for collectively negotiating music licensing terms with Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms or companies using generative AI.

Defines "Dominant Online Music Distribution Platform" as entities with over $100 million in annual music-related revenue and specifies exclusions.

Defines "generative artificial intelligence" as AI systems generating novel media based on prompts.

Requires that collective negotiations among Independent Music Creator Owners be nondiscriminatory, not limited to price, and directly related to negotiations with Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms.

Ensures that collective negotiations do not involve parties other than Independent Music Creator Owners or Dominant Online Music Distribution Platforms.

Stipulates that the Act does not modify, impair, or supersede existing antitrust laws beyond the specified provisions.

Official name: Cooper Davis Act
Casual name: Cooper Davis Act
Short summary: Amends the Controlled Substances Act to require electronic communication and remote computing service providers to report suspected illegal activities involving controlled substances to the DEA. Permits algorithmic content moderation, imposes penalties for noncompliance, and mandates annual reporting by the DEA.
Long summary:
Requires electronic communication service providers and remote computing services to report to the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) any knowledge of crimes involving fentanyl, methamphetamine, or counterfeit substances.

Mandates the report to be filed within 60 days of obtaining such knowledge, including detailed contact and relevant information about the involved accounts.

Allows reports based on reasonable belief and includes optional additional information like geographic location and complete communication data.

Subjects providers to criminal and civil penalties for failing to report or submitting false reports.

States that providers are not required to monitor users or the content of communications proactively.

Obliges DEA to review and potentially investigate reports, sharing them with other law enforcement agencies as needed.

Mandates the Attorney General to enforce these requirements and take measures for data minimization.

Requires DEA to publish annual reports on the number and outcomes of reports received.

Exempts broadband internet access service providers from these reporting requirements.

Official name: Countering Adversarial and Malicious Partnerships at Universities and Schools Act of 2023
Casual name: CAMPUS Act
Short summary: Prohibits Department of Defense funding to entities contracting with Chinese institutions supporting the People's Liberation Army. Denies visas to individuals from these institutions. Limits educational funding and strengthens U.S.-Taiwan partnerships for Mandarin instruction. Lowers foreign gift disclosure threshold.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of National Intelligence, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, to identify Chinese institutions of higher education supporting the People's Liberation Army and Military-Civil Fusion strategy.

Mandates submission of an annual list of these identified entities to Congress.

Prohibits Department of Defense funding for research, development, testing, and evaluation to entities contracting with identified Chinese institutions.

Restricts facilities from hosting or storing classified information unless they certify no active research partnership with identified institutions.

Allows the Secretary of State to deny visas to students or employees of identified institutions.

Prohibits Department of Education funds for K-12 schools contracting with entities domiciled in China.

Authorizes grants to U.S. schools to support Mandarin language instruction and Chinese cultural programming in partnership with Taiwan.

Prohibits federal research funds for entities contracting with listed Chinese entities.

Lowers the reporting threshold for foreign gifts to institutions of higher education from $250,000 to $50,000.

Official name: Deploying American Blockchains Act of 2023
Casual name: Deploying American Blockchains Act of 2023
Short summary: Designates the Secretary of Commerce as principal advisor on blockchain and AI policy. Requires development of policies addressing AI-related risks in blockchain. Promotes U.S. leadership and competitiveness in blockchain and AI integration. Establishes advisory committees and reports to Congress.
Long summary:
Designates the Secretary of Commerce as the principal advisor to the President on blockchain technology and related applications.

Requires the Secretary to develop policies and recommendations addressing issues such as decentralized identity, cybersecurity, AI, regulatory compliance, and fraud reduction.

Instructs the Secretary to promote U.S. leadership and competitiveness in blockchain technology through a Blockchain Deployment Program.

Mandates the establishment of advisory committees with diverse stakeholders to support blockchain adoption.

Directs the Secretary to facilitate the development and dissemination of best practices for blockchain technology.

Obligates the Secretary to consult with private sector stakeholders and disseminate research on blockchain technology.

Requires annual reports to Congress on activities, recommendations for legislation, and emerging risks and trends in blockchain technology.

Terminates the Blockchain Deployment Program seven years after enactment.

Official name: National Mesonet Authorization Act
Casual name: National Mesonet Authorization Act
Short summary: Establishes the National Mesonet Program to improve weather observations using non-Federal data sources. Prioritizes collaboration with commercial, academic, and other sectors. Provides financial support for enhancing data collection capabilities. Mandates regular reporting and sets funding allocations through 2028.
Long summary:
Establishes the National Mesonet Program within the National Weather Service to improve weather observation and forecasting.

Requires the program to leverage commercial, academic, and other non-Federal weather data to enhance coordination across sectors.

Targets improved environmental observations to support baseline forecasts and warnings, and to enhance numerical weather prediction performance.

Mandates integration of greater density and types of weather observations, including local and regional networks and satellite constellations.

Provides financial and technical assistance for State, Tribal, private, and academic entities to build or upgrade mesonet systems, contingent on agreements to share data.

Forms an advisory committee to recommend improvements and expansions of available data.

Obligates regular briefings to relevant Congressional committees on program activities and progress.

Allocates specified funding amounts for fiscal years 2024 through 2028 to support the program's implementation and expansion.

Official name: Food and Agriculture Industry Cybersecurity Support Act
Casual name: Food and Agriculture Industry Cybersecurity Support Act
Short summary: Establishes a cybersecurity clearinghouse for the food and agriculture industry. Requires consolidation of cybersecurity recommendations and consultations with various stakeholders. Mandates a study on federal efforts to improve industry cybersecurity. Sets a sunset clause after seven years.
Long summary:
Establishes a food and agriculture cybersecurity clearinghouse within the NTIA to provide publicly available online resources focused on cybersecurity for the food and agriculture industry.

Requires the clearinghouse to offer in-person or virtual support, updated FAQs, and materials for small businesses on critical cybersecurity protections and ransomware response.

Mandates the consolidation of public and private sector best practices into voluntary cybersecurity recommendations for the food and agriculture industry, including continuous monitoring and ransomware attack responses.

Instructs the Assistant Secretary to consult with private sector, federal agencies, trade groups, and civil society organizations in implementing the clearinghouse.

Directs the Comptroller General to study and report on federal efforts to improve cybersecurity in the food and agriculture industry, evaluating effectiveness, resources, coordination, and potential risks of coordinated attacks.

Sunsets the section seven years after enactment.

Official name: Know Your App Act
Casual name: Know Your App Act
Short summary: Requires application stores to prominently display the primary country of origin for each application. Allows users to filter or receive disclaimers for apps from concerning countries. Mandates annual developer certification of information accuracy. Enables anonymous reporting of violations.
Long summary:
Requires covered companies to publicly list the primary country of origin of each application on the app store page with prominent display.

Mandates that covered companies provide an option to filter out apps from countries of concern and display disclaimers if data could be accessed by a foreign government.

Obligates developers to notify covered companies of changes in country of origin or beneficial ownership and certify the accuracy of displayed information annually.

Enforces a series of warnings and potential removal of apps for non-compliance by developers.

Establishes a reporting mechanism for potential violations and provides an appeals process for app removals.

Directs the Treasury and Commerce Secretaries to annually list countries with laws enabling government control over applications, making the list publicly available.

Limits enforcement and regulatory authority to provisions explicitly stated in the Act.

Authorizes the Attorney General to enforce compliance through civil action.

Official name: Combating Cartels on Social Media Act of 2023
Casual name: Combating Cartels on Social Media Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to assess and combat the use of social media by transnational criminal organizations for illicit recruitment. Establishes a strategy to improve coordination and intelligence-sharing with government and operators, focusing on preemptive actions and youth outreach.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to assess the use of social media and online platforms by transnational criminal organizations for recruitment and illicit activities within 180 days.

Mandates submission of a National Strategy to Combat Illicit Recruitment Activity by Transnational Criminal Organizations on Social Media and Online Platforms within one year.

Proposes improvements in cooperation between government entities and social media operators, enhanced intelligence analysis, and proactive law enforcement efforts.

Requires establishment of a centralized mechanism for reporting recruitment efforts by transnational criminal organizations to the Department of Homeland Security.

Instructs the Secretary to consult with various federal, state, and local entities, as well as social media companies and experts during strategy development and implementation.

Mandates semiannual reporting on the implementation of the strategy and its progress to appropriate congressional committees for five years.

Designates a specific official within U.S. Customs and Border Protection to manage intelligence related to recruitment activities and to facilitate voluntary information reporting from social media operators.

Official name: Advanced Aviation Integration Act
Casual name: Advanced Aviation Integration Act
Short summary: Designates the FAA Deputy Administrator to lead advanced aviation integration. Establishes the Office of Advanced Integration. Forms the Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit to enhance integration and certification processes for advanced aviation systems, including unmanned aircraft and emerging technologies, within the national airspace.
Long summary:
Designates the Deputy Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) as the executive responsible for advanced aviation integration.

Requires coordination across FAA offices to ensure safe operation and integration of advanced aviation systems, including policy, rulemaking, and workforce planning.

Mandates the Deputy Administrator to report biannually on workforce requirements and recommend staffing and budget resources.

Establishes the Office of Advanced Integration, headed by a Director, to oversee advanced aviation system responsibilities.

Creates the Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit to promote safe integration, improve certification processes, and develop standards for advanced aviation systems.

Forms working groups on unmanned aircraft systems, advanced air mobility, and safety technology integration within the Coordination Unit.

Defines "advanced aviation system" broadly to include unmanned aircraft, powered lift aircraft, and various advanced aviation technologies.

Authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to facilitate interagency coordination to support advanced aviation integration.

Official name: Solving the Border Crisis Act
Casual name: Solving the Border Crisis Act
Short summary: Resumes border wall construction and requires compliance with DNA collection laws. Disapproves rule change on asylum claims. Amends treatment for aliens from contiguous territories to ensure return or detention. Sets minimum staffing levels for immigration enforcement and detention facilities funding.
Long summary:
Resumes border wall system construction, requiring the Secretary of Homeland Security to restart halted projects and honor previous agreements.

Prohibits the cancellation of contracts related to border wall construction entered into before January 20, 2021.

Requires the lifting of COVID-19 related suspension of entries and imports not earlier than 120 days after the termination of the public health emergency.

Mandates submission of plans to manage possible influxes related to the termination of COVID-19 suspensions.

Disapproves the rule allowing asylum officers to adjudicate credible fear claims, maintaining exclusive authority for immigration judges.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require the return of aliens to contiguous territory or detain them for further asylum consideration.

Establishes minimum staffing levels for various immigration and border enforcement offices, including 25,000 U.S. Border Patrol agents.

Ensures funding for sufficient detention facilities to comply with mandatory detention requirements.

Mandates a report within 60 days on how the Department of Homeland Security is mitigating border encounters.

Official name: Air Tour and Sport Parachuting Safety Improvement Act of 2023
