Casual name: Air Tour and Sport Parachuting Safety Improvement Act of 2023
Short summary: Requires the Federal Aviation Administration to implement safety management systems for certain operators, conduct safety reforms for commercial air tours, establish a rulemaking committee for flight data monitoring, and improve the certification process. Prioritizes safety and data monitoring in AI systems.
Long summary:
Requires the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Administrator to issue a final rule within 24 months mandating safety management systems for certain operators under part 135 of title 14.

Prohibits, beginning three years after enactment, commercial air tours without a certificate under part 119 of title 14, unless meeting specific temporary exceptions.

Mandates new or revised regulations within three years to incorporate controlled flight into terrain and in-flight loss of control avoidance training for certificated commercial air tour operators.

Convenes an aviation rulemaking committee to develop standards for flight data monitoring, terrain awareness, and traffic avoidance for commercial air tour operators.

Directs the Administrator to submit reports and issue proposed rulemakings and final rules based on the aviation rulemaking committee's recommendations within specified timelines.

Requires the FAA to improve the process for obtaining operating certificates and report on the efficiency and resource needs of this process.

Authorizes appropriations as necessary to implement the Act.

Official name: Advanced Aviation Act
Casual name: Advanced Aviation Act
Short summary: Establishes the Office of Advanced Aviation, headed by an Associate Administrator, to oversee rulemaking, certification, and integration of advanced aviation systems, including AI-driven technologies, into national airspace. Requires interagency coordination and stakeholder engagement for safe and timely integration.
Long summary:
Redesignates the Office of NextGen as the Office of Advanced Aviation within 1 year.

Appoints an Associate Administrator to oversee the Office of Advanced Aviation.

Coordinates rulemaking and approval processes for advanced aviation systems' standardization, certification, safety, and integration into national airspace.

Establishes an Office of Advanced Integration to manage responsibilities related to advanced aviation systems.

Forms an Advanced Aviation Coordination Unit to promote safe integration and certification of advanced aviation systems.

Redesignates the William J. Hughes Technical Center as the William J. Hughes Technical Center for Advanced Aviation, responsible for research, development, and integration of new aviation technologies.

Establishes an Aviation Innovation Program to evaluate and integrate new aviation-related technologies into the national airspace system.

Defines "advanced aviation systems" to include unmanned aircraft systems, counter-UAS systems, powered lift aircraft, and related technologies.

Official name: AI Safety Summit - Enhancing Frontier AI Safety (Amazon)
Casual name: AI Safety Summit - Enhancing Frontier AI Safety (Amazon)
Short summary: Describes Amazon's AI initiatives, emphasizing AWS's role in providing AI services, including model evaluation and risk assessments. Outlines security measures, responsible AI documentation, and vulnerability reporting for AI products. Highlights Amazon's research, partnerships, and policies to address societal AI risks, privacy, and bias.
Long summary:
Facilitates AI development and deployment through Amazon Web Services (AWS), offering a comprehensive suite of AI and ML services, including Amazon Bedrock and Amazon Titan Foundation Models, which support generative AI applications.

Implements risk management and safety protocols, including systematic model evaluation, red teaming, and ongoing security assessments, to mitigate potential AI risks.

Protects AI models and data using robust logical and physical security measures, such as encryption, access controls, and least privilege principles.

Shares AI service information transparently through AI Service Cards, detailing intended use cases, limitations, and responsible AI design considerations.

Encourages responsible AI use and prohibits misuse through the AWS Responsible AI Policy, which addresses concerns like disinformation and privacy violations.

Invests in research and academic partnerships to advance responsible AI practices and develop tools for bias mitigation and human oversight.

Monitors AI misuse post-release, employing classifier guardrails and automated abuse detection to identify and address harmful content and misuse patterns.

Official name: Our Policy on Frontier Safety (Inflection)
Casual name: Our Policy on Frontier Safety (Inflection)
Short summary: Implements a phased, responsible scaling of AI models, emphasizing pre-deployment safety, post-launch monitoring, and global governance. Requires rigorous model evaluations, data input controls, and security measures. Encourages research on AI risks and standardization of AI-generated content identification.
Long summary:
Commits Inflection to a disciplined, phased approach to scaling AI models, emphasizing pre-deployment safety, post-launch monitoring, and global governance.

Requires robust evaluations and third-party red-teaming before public launch to ensure models do not provide harmful information or engage in discriminatory conduct.

Implements strict data input controls and audits, involving executive review and legal evaluations of training data for compliance with legal and ethical standards.

Ensures high-level security controls to prevent unauthorized access and misuse of AI models, including internal restrictions and a bug bounty program.

Maintains around-the-clock monitoring to detect and mitigate model misuse, employing frontier AI to enhance situational awareness.

Publishes model capabilities and limitations, supporting transparency and enabling risk assessment by users and regulators.

Advocates for standardized vulnerability reporting structures and participates in a pilot bug bounty program to encourage third-party disclosures.

Prioritizes research on AI risks and supports the creation of an International Panel on AI Safety.

Promotes cross-industry collaboration for identifying AI-generated material, focusing on child safety and standardized watermarking.

Official name: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Microsoft)
Casual name: 2023 UK AI Safety Summit Response (Microsoft)
Short summary: Commits Microsoft to responsible AI development and deployment with multi-layered governance, collaboration with OpenAI, and robust risk management through AI red teaming and evaluations. Establishes a joint Deployment Safety Board for model review, transparency, and security controls.
Long summary:
Commits Microsoft to the responsible development and deployment of AI technologies, emphasizing collaboration with OpenAI and adherence to the National Institute of Standards and Technology AI Risk Management Framework.

Establishes a joint Microsoft-OpenAI Deployment Safety Board for pre-release AI model review, focusing on safety and capability thresholds.

Implements multi-layered AI governance and continuous risk evaluation, including red teaming for security and misuse detection.

Advances transparency through documentation and stakeholder engagement, informing on AI system capabilities and limitations.

Invests in AI safety research and collaborates globally on best practices for AI governance.

Supports a coordinated licensing regime for frontier models to enhance oversight and risk management.

Introduces initiatives like watermarking and metadata-based provenance for identifying AI-generated content.

Provides a framework for vulnerability disclosure and mitigation, offering rewards through bug bounty programs.

Official name: Research and Development Program on New Approaches to Data Analysis for Aviation Safety
Casual name: Research and Development Program on New Approaches to Data Analysis for Aviation Safety
Short summary: Establishes a research program using AI and machine learning for aviation safety data analysis. Requires collaboration among FAA, NEXTOR III, NASA, and industry partners. Prioritizes understanding human factors and improving automated aircraft design. Authorizes $20 million annually through 2029.
Long summary:
Establishes a new research and development program by the FAA’s NEXTOR III to develop new data analysis approaches for aviation safety.

Includes use of new algorithms and AI methods for analyzing various data sets such as weather, equipment performance, flight delays, safety incidents, and communications.

Requires collaboration among Consortium member institutions, aviation industry partners, FAA units, and NASA’s Aviation Safety Reporting System for data sharing and testing.

Prioritizes understanding human factors contributing to aviation safety risk, including fatigue, distraction, workload, organizational culture, communication, and adherence to safety procedures.

Seeks to improve the design of highly automated aircraft to reduce mode confusion and increase awareness of flight parameters.

Authorizes $20,000,000 annually from 2024 to 2029 for program execution, including grants to participating institutions and FAA units.

Terminates the program 6 years after establishment.

Official name: TORPEDO Act of 2023, Sec. 6 (Reporting requirements on efforts of the Department of State to implement the AUKUS partnership)
Casual name: TORPEDO Act of 2023, Sec. 6 (Reporting requirements on efforts of the Department of State to implement the AUKUS partnership)
Short summary: Requires submission of reports detailing interagency actions and progress in implementing advanced capabilities under the AUKUS agreement, including AI and autonomy. Assesses export control changes and collaboration efforts among AUKUS partners on AI and other technologies.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretaries of Defense, Commerce, and Energy, to report on the Department of State's implementation of the AUKUS partnership within 90 days of enactment.

Requires the report to detail Australia's progress on various submarine-related goals, including infrastructure, workforce training, and basing support.

Instructs the report to assess Australia's submarine contributions to U.S. defense objectives and provide a strategy for integrating AUKUS and U.S. submarines.

Mandates reporting on U.S. export control processes and recommendations for improvements to facilitate the AUKUS partnership.

Demands an interagency report on changes to ITAR and export control regimes to enable defense item exchanges among AUKUS members and Canada.

Requires an assessment of efforts to enhance collaboration in AI, quantum technologies, cyber capabilities, and other advanced defense areas.

Obligates the President to brief Congress annually for seven years on AUKUS implementation progress.

Official name: TORPEDO Act of 2023,  Sec. 12 (Expedited release of advanced technologies to Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom through the foreign military sales program)
Casual name: TORPEDO Act of 2023,  Sec. 12 (Expedited release of advanced technologies to Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom through the foreign military sales program)
Short summary: Expedites the release of AI and other advanced technologies to Australia, Canada, and the UK through the Foreign Military Sales program. Establishes a fast-track decision-making process for AI capabilities, with a presumption of approval, and anticipatory release policy.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, to compile a list of pre-cleared military technologies and platforms for sale to Australia, Canada, and the UK within 90 days of enactment and annually thereafter.

Expedites the processing of Foreign Military Sales requests from Australia, Canada, and the UK.

Mandates the creation of an anticipatory release policy for key Foreign Military Sales capabilities, including AI, hypersonic missiles, cyber capabilities, and quantum technologies, with a presumption of approval.

Requires the review and update of interagency policies to incorporate these anticipatory release provisions.

Official name: Rail Worker and Community Safety Act, Sec. 13 (Equipment Inspections)
Casual name: Rail Worker and Community Safety Act, Sec. 13 (Equipment Inspections)
Short summary: Require AI-based inspection technologies for rail inspections to be verified by a Qualified Mechanical Inspector.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations within 12 months of enactment.

Prohibits the movement of trains from switchyards before completing all required brake inspections.

Allows only Qualified Mechanical Inspectors to sign off on inspection forms for locomotives and rail cars.

Ensures that inspections using AI or camera-based systems under part 215 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, require verification by a Qualified Mechanical Inspector.

Official name: HOME Act of 2024, Sec. 7 (Identification of Unfair Screening Practices)
Casual name: HOME Act of 2024, Sec. 7 (Identification of Unfair Screening Practices)
Short summary: Establishes a program to identify unfair rental housing screening practices using algorithms. Requires annual reporting to Congress on collected information regarding these practices, including background checks and tenant income evaluations.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to jointly collect information on unfair practices in tenant and applicant screenings, including the use of algorithms.

Requires the identification of practices that prevent access to or retention of rental housing, focusing on tenant background checks, adverse action notices, and tenant income sources.

Obliges the submission of an annual report to Congress detailing the information collected under the program.

Official name: PAID Act, Sec. 3 (Requirements for Private Passenger Automobile Insurers)
Casual name: PAID Act, Sec. 3 (Requirements for Private Passenger Automobile Insurers)
Short summary: Prohibits insurers from using specific personal factors, including gender and credit score, to determine car insurance rates. Requires submission to FTC to ensure no disparate impacts from algorithms. Mandates public access to underwriting rules.
Long summary:
Prohibits private passenger automobile insurers from considering certain factors, such as gender, education level, and ZIP Code, in determining insurance eligibility or rates.

Requires insurers to submit information to the FTC within one year of enactment and biennially thereafter to demonstrate that their practices and algorithms do not disproportionately impact any customer group based on protected characteristics.

Mandates public availability of underwriting rules and rate filings, disallowing them from being proprietary trade secrets.

Exempts individuals from liability if they prove they maintained reasonable compliance procedures.

Clarifies that using prohibited factors to influence insurance premiums constitutes a violation, affecting eligibility, rebates, discounts, and other policy terms.

Preserves the authority of Federal and State agencies to enforce prohibitions against unfair or deceptive practices.

Official name: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
Casual name: Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
Short summary: Requires the Election Assistance Commission to issue voluntary guidelines addressing AI use and risks in election administration. Includes guidelines on AI benefits, cybersecurity risks, accurate information sharing, and combating election disinformation impacting public trust.
Long summary:
Cites the Act as the “Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act”.

Requires the Election Assistance Commission to submit a report with voluntary guidelines to Congress, State and local election offices, and the public within 60 days of enactment.

Includes guidelines addressing the risks and benefits of using AI in election administration.

Addresses the cybersecurity risks posed by AI technologies in elections.

Guides on managing AI-generated information to ensure the sharing of accurate election information.

Provides strategies for countering AI-driven election disinformation that undermines public trust.

Official name: Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Securing AI Task Force Act
Casual name: CISA Securing AI Task Force Act
Short summary: Establishes a CISA Task Force to coordinate AI safety and security efforts, assess initiatives, address workforce gaps, and promote secure AI adoption. Requires biannual briefings to Congress. Ceases effect five years post-enactment.
Long summary:
Establishes a Task Force within the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to coordinate efforts related to AI safety and security.

Requires coordination of Agency efforts to improve the safe and secure design, development, adoption, and deployment of AI.

Ensures Agency collaboration in interagency and nongovernment AI-related initiatives.

Mandates assessment and evaluation of Agency safety initiatives to address AI challenges.

Leverages expertise to use AI in defending against cyber threats.

Coordinates efforts to advise stakeholders on AI-related cyber risks.

Identifies AI workforce gaps and proposes solutions.

Promotes secure adoption of AI-based software.

Recommends new initiatives for AI safety and security.

Ensures AI efforts meet privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties standards.

Supports publication and accuracy of the Agency’s AI use inventory.

Mandates biannual briefings to Congress on Task Force activities.

Sunsets the Act 5 years after enactment.

Official name: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to award prizes for AI research in sectors like health and cybersecurity. Requires public input, sets eligibility criteria, and mandates reports on winning submissions. Awards start at $1 million, with potential for larger prizes.
Long summary:
Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to incentivize AI research, development, and commercialization through prize competitions.

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation to coordinate with federal agencies and stakeholders, consulting public input, to identify and select AI grand challenges.

Requires the program to address categories such as national security, health, energy, and AI-specific issues like bias mitigation.

Designates a specific grand challenge for AI-enabled cancer breakthroughs, mandating a minimum $10 million prize.

Sets eligibility for participants as U.S.-based entities or citizens/permanent residents, with prize amounts starting at $1 million and potentially exceeding $50 million.

Allows the Director to fund the program through contributions from various governmental and private entities, ensuring funds do not influence prize decisions.

Obligates regular reporting to Congress on the program’s progress and results, ensuring public accessibility of reports and competition information via Challenge.gov.

Official name: Free Credit Scores for Consumers Act of 2024
Casual name: Free Credit Scores for Consumers Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires consumer reporting agencies to provide free credit scores with annual reports upon request. Mandates clear disclosures about differences between credit scores and educational scores. Obligates lenders to provide free credit reports and scores used for underwriting before loan agreements.
Long summary:
Expands the definitions of "credit score" and "educational credit score" under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA).

Requires consumer reporting agencies (CRAs) to provide consumers with detailed explanations of credit score calculations, including key factors affecting scores.

Mandates CRAs to disclose prominently the differences and limitations of credit scores and educational credit scores on their websites and in related materials.

Provides consumers with free credit score disclosures along with their free annual consumer reports upon request.

Requires private educational lenders, motor vehicle lenders, and residential mortgage lenders to provide consumers with free copies of any consumer reports and credit scores used for underwriting before signing loan agreements.

Mandates the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to issue final rules to implement these amendments within two years of enactment.

Official name: Examining Educational Redlining in Lending Act
Casual name: Examining Educational Redlining in Lending Act
Short summary: Requires the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to annually assess the use of educational data and automated processes in creditworthiness determinations. Mandates reporting to Congress and public disclosure of findings and involved entities to prevent disparate impacts on protected classes.
Long summary:
Requires the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to assess the use of educational data and automated processes in creditworthiness determinations annually.

Mandates coordination with executive agencies and civil rights stakeholders for these assessments.

Examines the risks and disparate impacts of using automated or algorithmic underwriting processes.

Obligates the Bureau to report findings and recommendations to Congress 60 days post-assessment.

Requires public disclosure of assessment findings, lists of covered persons using educational data, and those employing automated or algorithmic processes.

Defines key terms, including "certain educational data" and "covered person," with references to existing legislation.

Official name: Future of Artificial Intelligence Innovation Act of 2024
Casual name: Future of Artificial Intelligence Innovation Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the "Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute" to assist sectors in AI best practices and innovation. Requires AI research and standards development and mandates an international coalition for AI standards. Directs reporting on regulatory barriers and orders prioritized AI training data and Federal AI challenges.
Long summary:
Establishes the "Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute" to assist private and public sectors in developing best practices for AI assessment, provide technical assistance, and promote AI innovation, with a director appointed by the Under Secretary of Commerce for Standards and Technology.
Requires the Institute to conduct AI research, develop standards, and create guidelines for safe AI development and deployment, including generative AI and foundation models.

Mandates the formation of an international coalition to harmonize AI standards and support bilateral and multilateral AI research collaborations. Directs the Comptroller General to report on regulatory barriers affecting AI innovation and recommend legislative or administrative actions to enhance AI development.
Orders the development of prioritized public data sets for AI training and evaluation, and the establishment of Federal grand challenges in AI to stimulate research and commercialization in key areas.

Official name: Lummis-Gillibrand Payment Stablecoin Act (Sec. 1-3)
Casual name: Lummis-Gillibrand Payment Stablecoin Act (Sec. 1-3)
Short summary: Prohibits issuing algorithmic payment stablecoins. Requires registration or authorization for issuing payment stablecoins in the U.S. Limits issuance by non-depository trust companies to $10 billion. Establishes safe harbors for limited issuance and foreign regulatory equivalence. Adjusts thresholds for inflation.
Long summary:
Prohibits any person from issuing, creating, or originating an algorithmic payment stablecoin in the United States.

Mandates that payment stablecoins can only be issued by a registered non-depository trust company with a limit on nominal value or an authorized depository institution as a national payment stablecoin issuer.

Prohibits the offer or sale of payment stablecoins in the United States except by a U.S. person living in the U.S.

Requires the Board to adjust the issuance threshold for inflation every four years.

Directs the Board to establish safe harbor regulations, allowing limited issuance of payment stablecoins under specific conditions and fostering innovation and competition.

Allows safe harbor status for issuers regulated by equivalent foreign authorities.

Intends the section to have extraterritorial effect, extending its reach beyond U.S. borders.

Official name: Veterans Appeals Efficiency Act of 2024
Casual name: Veterans Appeals Efficiency Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the Secretary to track and maintain information on certain veterans' benefits claims using technology. Permits the Board of Veterans' Appeals to aggregate appeals with similar legal or factual questions. Allows AI use in studying common legal questions.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit an annual report on the average length of time remanded claims are pending.

Mandates the use of technology to track and maintain information on specific claims for benefits, including those continuously pursued, in the National Work Queue, or pending a hearing.

Ensures claimants can view reasons for claim deferrals or suspense dates in the National Work Queue.

Authorizes the Chairman of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals to aggregate appeals with similar questions of law or fact.

Obliges the Board to ensure substantial compliance with its remand decisions, allowing waivers if sufficient evidence resolves underlying issues.

Grants the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims supplemental jurisdiction to review eligible claims and remand matters for addressing unaddressed issues or inadequate decisions by the Board.

Directs a study, potentially using AI, on common legal or factual questions before the Board and mandates a report on the findings.

Requires the Secretary to develop a plan for timely assignment of claims and submit it to Congress.

Official name: Contraband Awareness Technology Catches Harmful Fentanyl Act
Casual name: CATCH Fentanyl Act
Short summary: Establishes pilot projects for testing AI and other technology enhancements to improve contraband detection at U.S. land ports of entry. Requires assessments of technology effectiveness, integration, and cost. Involves private sector input and mandates reporting to Congress on outcomes and recommendations.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security, through the CBP Innovation Team, to establish pilot projects within one year to test and assess technologies enhancing nonintrusive inspection systems at land ports of entry.

Requires testing of at least five technology types, including artificial intelligence, machine learning, and quantum information sciences, to detect contraband, illegal drugs, and threats.

Identifies effective enhancements based on detection accuracy, efficiency, integration capability, cost, safety, and mobility.

Allows private sector input on commercially viable technologies.

Sets termination of pilot projects five years post-enactment.

Requires reporting to Congress within three years and after project termination, detailing effectiveness, recommendations, cost plans, and performance analysis of tested technologies.

Official name: No AI Audits Act
Casual name: No AI Audits Act
Short summary: Limits IRS use of AI for audits by requiring guidance as rule-making and adherence to NIST explainability principles. Requires Comptroller General to audit and report on IRS's AI use. Mandates IRS staff, not AI, initiate taxpayer investigations.
Long summary:
Titles the Act as the “No AI Audits Act”.

Limits the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) use of artificial intelligence (AI) for audits or investigations.

Requires any IRS guidance on AI for audits to follow rule-making procedures under Section 553 of Title 5, U.S. Code.

Prohibits the IRS from conducting audits or investigations initiated by AI unless the AI meets explainability principles set by the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Defines "artificial intelligence" according to the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020.

Mandates the Comptroller General to audit and report on the IRS's AI use, including a cost-benefit analysis and the impact on taxpayer rights.

Stipulates that IRS investigations or examinations must be initiated by a staff investigator, with documentation including the investigator's contact information.

Official name: Methane Emissions Mitigation Research and Development Act
Casual name: Methane Emissions Mitigation Research and Development Act
Short summary: Establishes a program for methane emissions detection, including AI-driven analytics and machine learning improvements. Forms a consortium to enhance leak detection and repair strategies through data sharing. Funds national facilities for advancing methane measurement standards and rapid technology testing.
Long summary:
Requires the Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the EPA and other federal agencies, to implement a program for methane emissions detection and mitigation research, development, and demonstration.

Mandates cooperative agreements with state/local governments, higher education institutions, and for-profit entities for technical assistance in preventing and responding to methane releases.

Establishes publicly accessible resources for best practices in pipeline systems, production wells, storage facilities, and emission reduction technologies.

Supports research into technologies for accurate methane emissions quantification, including improvements in data analytics, machine learning platforms, and Lidar detection technologies.

Forms a Methane Emissions Measurement and Mitigation Research Consortium to prioritize research, facilitate data sharing, and develop cooperative leak detection and repair strategies.

Requires annual reporting to Congress on the Consortium's activities, findings, and progress, and a merit review after five years.

Authorizes specific appropriations for the Secretary of Energy and Secretary of Commerce to support these initiatives through 2029.

Official name: National Patient Safety Board Act of 2024
Casual name: National Patient Safety Board Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the National Patient Safety Board (NPSB) to prevent patient safety events. Empowers NPSB to monitor, study, and propose solutions. Grants authority to request changes and review reports. Mandates annual audits. Forms Patient Safety Research Division. Requires privacy and AI compliance. Prohibits use in civil cases.
Long summary:
Establishes the National Patient Safety Board (NPSB) within the Office of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to prevent and reduce patient safety events.

Empowers the NPSB to support federal agencies in monitoring patient safety, studying causes of patient safety events, and formulating preventive solutions.

Grants the NPSB authority to request changes to patient safety measures, review reports, and make them publicly available within one year of study commencement.

Mandates annual audits and reports to Congress on progress, including detailed solutions and unaddressed needs.

Forms a Patient Safety Research and Development Division to aggregate and analyze patient-level data, identifying and anticipating safety events and disparities.

Requires compliance with privacy laws and AI governance frameworks, including NIST's AI Risk Management Framework and the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights.

Prohibits the use of NPSB reports as evidence in civil liability cases but allows their use in developing standards of care.

Official name: TAME Extreme Weather Act
Casual name: TAME Extreme Weather Act
Short summary: Mandates the use of AI by Federal agencies to improve weather forecasts, grid resilience, and resource deployment for extreme weather. Develops AI weather models, enhances emissions monitoring, and establishes a fire modeling program. Encourages public-private partnerships and addresses national security concerns.
Long summary:
Mandates federal agencies to use AI to adapt to extreme weather, improving weather forecasts, electrical grid resilience, resource deployment, and public-private partnerships.

Requires NOAA to develop and curate an Earth system reanalysis dataset, build on existing datasets, and develop AI weather models.

Directs NOAA to explore advanced AI applications for weather forecasting, including data assimilation and model emulation.

Tasks NOAA with providing technical assistance on AI weather models and developing best practices and public datasets.

Establishes programs using AI for wildfire detection, emissions monitoring, and illegal wood product tracking, requiring dataset curation and public access to AI code and data.

Instructs the Department of Energy to optimize energy grids using AI, develop environmental review documents, and ensure public access to AI models and training datasets, while protecting national security interests.

Official name: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require clear disclaimers on political ads using AI-generated content. Imposes penalties for non-compliance and considers failure to respond as admission. Mandates the Federal Election Commission to issue regulations and report compliance.
Long summary:
Requires the inclusion of disclaimers on political advertisements containing content substantially generated by AI.

Defines "covered communication" and "generative artificial intelligence" for the purpose of the Act.

Mandates that disclaimers must clearly state the use of AI in creating or materially altering the content.

Establishes safe harbor guidelines for what constitutes a "clear and conspicuous manner" in disclaimers for image, audio, and video communications.

Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to include penalties for violations of the disclaimer requirements, with fines up to $50,000.

Directs the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations within 90 days of enactment.

Applies the new requirements to communications made after the enactment date, regardless of FEC regulation status.

Requires the FEC to report on compliance and enforcement within two years and biannually thereafter to Congress.

Official name: Preserving Telehealth, Hospital, and Ambulance Access Act, Sec. 105 (Report on Wearable Medical Devices)
Casual name: Preserving Telehealth, Hospital, and Ambulance Access Act, Sec. 105 (Report on Wearable Medical Devices)
Short summary: Requires the Comptroller General to assess and report on wearable medical devices' capabilities and limitations in clinical decision-making, focusing on AI's benefits and challenges, and proposing policy options to enhance benefits and mitigate challenges.
Long summary:
Mandates the Comptroller General to conduct a technology assessment of wearable medical devices within 18 months of the Act's enactment.

Requires the report to include an analysis of the devices' potential to accurately prescribe treatments.

Examines the benefits and challenges of using artificial intelligence to augment wearable medical devices.

Proposes policy options to enhance benefits and mitigate challenges in developing or using such devices.

Official name: Richard L. Trumka Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2023, Sec. 309 (GAO Report)
Casual name: Richard L. Trumka Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2023, Sec. 309 (GAO Report)
Short summary: Analyze the impact of Sections 101(a) and 101(b) on technology and algorithm use. Require the Government Accountability Office to report findings to Congress. Allow the President to recommend legislative modifications based on these findings.
Long summary:
Mandates the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to study the impact of Sections 101(a) and 101(b) on employee coverage under the National Labor Relations Act, focusing on union formation and collective bargaining.

Requires the study to analyze impacts on employee flexibility, compensation, grievance resolution, and technology use, including AI and algorithms.

Directs the GAO to gather input from stakeholders, including business enterprises and labor organizations, consulting relevant congressional committees.

Obliges the GAO to report its findings to the House and Senate committees six months after the study begins and make the report public.

Instructs the President, after the report's release, to consider its findings and potentially recommend modifications to Sections 101(a) or 101(b) within 60 days.

Expresses the House's intent to evaluate any presidential recommendations regarding the modifications.

Official name: National Wildland Fire Risk Reduction Program Act, Sec. 7 (Responsibilities of Program Agencies)
Casual name: National Wildland Fire Risk Reduction Program Act, Sec. 7 (Responsibilities of Program Agencies)
Short summary: Assigns responsibilities to various U.S. agencies for wildland fire research, prediction, and mitigation, including AI-driven data analysis and modeling. Focuses on developing tools, improving fire-weather forecasts, enhancing coordination, and promoting fire-resistant infrastructure and practices.
Long summary:
Mandates NIST to conduct research on wildland fire impacts, firebrands, novel materials, and performance-based mitigation tools.

Requires NIST to coordinate federal wildland-urban interface fire investigations and develop methodologies for assessing fire impacts on communities.

Directs NSF to support research on wildland fire risks, tools, technologies, and the social and economic factors influencing fire risk reduction.

Instructs NOAA to improve wildland fire understanding through research, weather forecasting, data interoperability, and high-performance computing.

Tasks NOAA with establishing a Fire Weather Testbed and supporting extramural research on wildland fires.

Requires FEMA to support community risk assessment tools, public outreach, and best practices for fire-resistant construction and response.

Directs NASA to support wildland fire research, modeling, data systems, and the development of novel monitoring tools.

Instructs EPA to research wildland fire smoke characteristics, impacts on air and water quality, and communication of risk reduction strategies.

Mandates DOE to develop tools for energy sector resilience to wildland fires and coordinate data resources for improved fire understanding and prevention.

Official name: Community and Hydropower Improvement Act, Sec. 4 (Approach to Environmental Review)
Casual name: Community and Hydropower Improvement Act, Sec. 4 (Approach to Environmental Review)
Short summary: Amends the Energy Policy Act to require the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to collaborate with agencies and tribes for environmental assessments. Considers project effects and requires use of open-source models. Evaluates impacts on grid reliability and energy prices.
Long summary:
Amends Section 2403 of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to enhance environmental review procedures.

Requires the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to cooperate with federal, state, local agencies, and Indian Tribes in preparing environmental assessments or impact statements.

Mandates consideration of ongoing and reasonably foreseeable environmental effects of projects, excluding nonrecurring past effects.

Obliges FERC and cooperating entities to evaluate impacts on fish species and consider appropriate mitigation strategies.

Encourages the use of open-sourced technical models for environmental impact assessments, ensuring their validity and accessibility while protecting intellectual property and proprietary data.

Directs FERC to account for hydrologic alterations over the project license term and assess their impacts on public uses and regional benefits.

Necessitates consideration of innovative solutions and emerging technologies to meet regulatory responsibilities cost-effectively.

Requires periodic technical conferences to evaluate new methodologies and technologies for environmental impact quantification.

Stipulates precise citation of evidence in environmental review records to support findings on material facts.

Official name: Border Act of 2024, General Provisions Title
Casual name: Border Act of 2024, General Provisions Title
Short summary: Allocates $170 million for autonomous surveillance towers using AI for border security. Requires open competition for AI-enhanced non-intrusive inspection technology. Defines autonomous systems as those using AI to identify items of interest. Requires quarterly updates on AI technology impacts.
Long summary:
Allocates $170,000,000 for the procurement and deployment of autonomous surveillance tower systems using AI for border security.

Prohibits the use of funds for non-autonomous border security technology.

Defines "autonomous" systems as those utilizing sensors, onboard computing, and AI for identification.

Mandates quarterly reports on the performance and impact of border security technologies, including AI-driven non-intrusive inspection technology.

Requires acquisition of innovative technologies through open competition, integrating AI and machine learning to improve performance.

Obliges U.S. Customs and Border Protection to submit detailed expenditure plans for autonomous systems, including deployment timelines and sustainment costs.

Instructs the Secretary of Homeland Security to conduct cost-benefit analyses before requesting Department of Defense assistance for border operations, including AI technology impacts.

Official name: NSTC/OSTP Framework for Nucleic Acid Synthesis Screening
Casual name: NSTC/OSTP Framework for Nucleic Acid Synthesis Screening
Authority: Office of Science and Technology Policy
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Requires providers and manufacturers to implement screening for synthetic nucleic acids and equipment, identify sequences of concern, verify customer legitimacy, report suspicious orders, retain records, and enhance cybersecurity. Mandates adherence for federally funded research, with updates based on technological advances.
Long summary:
Mandates the federal government to mitigate misuse risks of synthetic nucleic acids by establishing a procurement screening framework.

Requires synthetic nucleic acid providers and equipment manufacturers to implement comprehensive screening measures for sequences of concern (SOCs) and verify customer legitimacy.

Directs the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to collaborate with industry to refine technical specifications for effective screening.

Obliges federal funding agencies to ensure compliance with the framework for research funded by federal life sciences grants.

Instructs providers and manufacturers to report suspicious purchase orders to relevant authorities and retain records for at least three years.

Imposes cybersecurity measures to protect sensitive data and customer information, following specific security guidelines.

Anticipates framework updates based on technological advancements and encourages the use of independent audits for compliance verification.

Official name: Inventorship Guidance for AI-Assisted Inventions
Casual name: Inventorship Guidance for AI-Assisted Inventions
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Requires inventors and joint inventors on U.S. patents to be natural persons, excluding AI systems as inventors. Allows AI-assisted inventions to be patented if natural persons significantly contribute. Emphasizes compliance with inventorship requirements under U.S. patent statutes.
Long summary:
Mandates that inventors named on U.S. patents and applications must be natural persons, reaffirming that AI systems cannot be recognized as inventors.

Clarifies that AI-assisted inventions are not unpatentable due to improper inventorship, provided a natural person significantly contributed to the invention's conception.

Requires that patent applications for AI-assisted inventions name natural persons who meet the Pannu factors as inventors, ensuring each claim has a human contributor.

Outlines the duty of disclosure and reasonable inquiry, emphasizing the importance of factual inventorship claims and compliance with regulations.

Establishes guidelines for correcting inventorship errors and emphasizes that AI systems cannot hold inventorship rights.

Applies guidance to design and plant patents, affirming that significant human contribution is necessary for patent eligibility.

Prohibits naming AI systems as inventors in priority claims for U.S. patents and applications, ensuring compliance with U.S. inventorship requirements.

Official name: USDA Framework for State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Use of Artificial Intelligence for Public Benefit Administration
Casual name: USDA Framework for State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Use of Artificial Intelligence for Public Benefit Administration
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Requires USDA to guide state, local, tribal, and territorial agencies on AI use in nutrition benefits, ensuring accessibility, compliance with merit systems, notification to USDA, human review options, auditability, and equitable outcomes. Encourages responsible AI innovation while protecting rights and safety.
Long summary:
The framework mandates the USDA to guide states, localities, tribes, and territories in the responsible use of AI for administering USDA nutrition benefits, as per Executive Order 14110.

Ensures AI systems maximize access for eligible recipients and comply with merit system requirements.

Requires notification to the Secretary in cases of reliance on AI, allowing appeals to human reviewers and ensuring auditability of AI decisions.

Mandates equitable outcomes from AI systems and prohibits AI from directly making adverse decisions in benefits administration.

Advocates for transparency and accountability, providing opt-out options from AI systems.

Encourages responsible innovation, requiring AI usage only with appropriate training and governance.

Requires SLTT agencies to report AI usage and its impact, with ongoing monitoring to mitigate risks and biases.

Stresses collaboration with tribes to respect data sovereignty.

Official name: HHS Public Benefits and AI
Casual name: HHS Public Benefits and AI
Authority: Department of Health and Human Services
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Encourages state and local governments to use AI responsibly in public benefits administration. Recommends risk assessment, fairness, transparency, human oversight, and privacy protection. Emphasizes equity, accountability, and civil rights compliance. Supports developing frameworks and resources for AI governance and innovation.
Long summary:
Requires the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to promote responsible AI use in public benefits administration by State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial Governments (STLTs).

Encourages STLTs to align with the principles of the National Institute of Standards and Technology AI Risk Management Framework and the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights.

Recommends STLTs assess AI systems for equitable outcomes, notify recipients about AI use, and ensure human oversight and appeal processes.

Supports STLTs in developing AI policies and practices through guidance, technical assistance, and resources.

Urges STLTs to focus on safeguarding privacy, civil rights, and safety, and to provide opt-out options for AI systems.

Emphasizes the need for transparency, public engagement, and governance to manage AI-associated risks.

Directs HHS to work with STLTs and other agencies to ensure AI systems in public benefits programs are safe, equitable, and efficient.

Official name: Guidance on Application of the Fair Housing Act to the Advertising of Housing, Credit, and Other Real Estate-Related Transactions through Digital Platforms
Casual name: Guidance on Application of the Fair Housing Act to the Advertising of Housing, Credit, and Other Real Estate-Related Transactions through Digital Platforms
Authority: Department of Housing and Urban Development
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Prohibits discriminatory use of AI in housing-related ads under the Fair Housing Act. Addresses potential violations via audience targeting, custom audiences, and algorithmic delivery. Recommends advertisers and platforms audit practices, avoid proxies for protected characteristics, and ensure equitable ad delivery.
Long summary:
Explains how the Fair Housing Act applies to housing-related advertising via AI and algorithmic systems on digital platforms.

Prohibits discriminatory advertising practices based on protected characteristics such as race, color, religion, sex, national origin, familial status, or disability.

Warns that audience categorization and algorithmic delivery tools can unintentionally lead to discrimination by excluding or targeting groups based on protected characteristics.

Requires advertisers and platforms to avoid using AI tools that segment audiences by protected characteristics or proxies like geographic location.

Urges ad platforms to disable certain targeting functions for housing ads and conduct regular audits to ensure compliance with the Act.

Recommends that advertisers and platforms manage discriminatory risks by utilizing separate processes for housing-related ads and monitoring ad delivery outcomes for bias.

Advises documenting and publicly sharing information on ad targeting functions to ensure transparency and accountability.

Official name: Increasing AI Capacity Across the Federal Government: AI Talent Surge Progress and Recommendations
Casual name: Increasing AI Capacity Across the Federal Government: AI Talent Surge Progress and Recommendations
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Implements Executive Order 14110, launching a National AI Talent Surge to recruit AI professionals for federal use, policy development, and R&D. Establishes expedited hiring authorities, training initiatives, and diverse recruitment efforts to strengthen the federal AI workforce and infrastructure.
Long summary:
Mandates Federal agencies strengthen AI safety, security, privacy, equity, civil rights, and innovation through Executive Order 14110, signed by President Biden.

Launches a National AI Talent Surge to recruit AI professionals into the Federal Government, enhancing AI regulatory and policy capacity, government use of AI, and AI R&D ecosystem.

Facilitates AI hiring with Direct Hire Authority and Excepted Service Appointments granted by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM).

Establishes Chief AI Officers and enhances AI competencies with training programs for the Federal workforce.

Recommends funding increases for AI talent, institutionalizing tech talent programs, improving USAJOBS, and piloting skills-based hiring.

Proposes an AI scholarship-for-service program and public service cultivation within the tech ecosystem.

Encourages global AI talent engagement and provides guidance for improving Federal hiring experiences.

Official name:
Government-wide Hiring Authorities for Advancing Federal Government
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)
Casual name:
Government-wide Hiring Authorities for Advancing Federal Government
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Authorizes government-wide direct hire authority for AI-related roles to enhance federal AI capabilities, effective until December 31, 2028. Allows temporary excepted service appointments for implementing AI directives under Executive Order 14110. Requires quarterly reporting of hires made under this authority.
Long summary:
Mandates the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to conduct an evidence-based review for hiring and workplace flexibility for AI and data-science roles within 60 days of the Executive Order (EO) 14110.

Authorizes government-wide direct hire authority for specific AI-related positions, effective immediately through December 31, 2028, to address critical hiring needs in AI capabilities.

Permits use of excepted service Schedule A appointments for temporary staffing to support the implementation of EO 14110, with appointments valid for up to two years.

Requires agencies to submit quarterly reports detailing hires made under this direct hire authority, including job announcements and number of hires.

Stipulates agencies must adhere to veterans’ preference and public notice requirements when filling positions under these authorities.

Allows OPM to request information and assess the continued need for these authorities, with the possibility of modification or termination.

Official name: Pay Flexibility, Incentive Pay, and Leave and Workforce Flexibility Programs for Artificial Intelligence (AI), AI-enabling, and Other Key Technical Employees (OPM)
Casual name: Pay Flexibility, Incentive Pay, and Leave and Workforce Flexibility Programs for Artificial Intelligence (AI), AI-enabling, and Other Key Technical Employees (OPM)
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Allows agencies to use various pay and workforce flexibilities to recruit and retain AI talent without OPM approval. Permits recruitment, relocation, and retention incentives, superior qualifications pay, and alternative work schedules. Authorizes telework, remote work, and student loan repayment.
Long summary:
Grants agencies discretionary authority to use various pay flexibilities, incentive pay, and leave and workforce flexibility programs to recruit, relocate, and retain AI and key technical employees.

Allows recruitment, relocation, and retention incentives up to 25% of basic pay, and provides for waivers to increase this limit to 50% based on critical needs.

Enables agencies to repay student loans as an incentive, with limits of $10,000 annually and $60,000 total per employee.

Permits setting higher pay rates for employees with superior qualifications or special needs, and requests OPM approval for special rates and critical position pay.

Authorizes alternative work schedules, telework, and remote work to enhance recruitment and retention.

Provides service credit for non-Federal work experience towards higher annual leave accrual rates.

Encourages collaboration with agency officials to design tailored recruitment and retention strategies utilizing available human resources tools.

Official name: Safe and Responsible AI in Australia Consultation, Interim Response
Casual name: Safe and Responsible AI in Australia Consultation, Interim Response
Short summary: Considers mandatory safety guardrails for high-risk AI applications. Plans to consult on regulatory frameworks, including testing and transparency. Collaborates internationally on AI safety. Focuses on balancing innovation with risk management, enhancing privacy laws, and addressing misinformation.
Long summary:
Proposes strengthening existing laws and considering new legislation to address AI-related risks, particularly in high-risk settings.

Considers mandatory safety guardrails for AI systems in high-risk contexts, focusing on testing, transparency, and accountability.

Plans to work with industry to develop a voluntary AI Safety Standard and explore options for voluntary labelling and watermarking of AI-generated materials.

Emphasizes a risk-based regulatory framework to ensure proportionality and avoid unnecessary burdens on low-risk AI applications.

Commits to collaborating with international partners, aligning with global standards, and contributing to initiatives like the Bletchley Declaration on AI safety.

Supports investments in AI capability development and aims to maximize AI benefits, including through initiatives funded by the 2023–24 Budget.

Establishes an interim expert advisory group to explore AI guardrail options and harmonizes efforts with state and territory governments.

Official name: Canada Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (Companion document)
Casual name: Canada Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (Companion document)
Short summary: Proposes AIDA to regulate high-impact AI systems, ensuring safety, accountability, and human rights protection. Empowers the Minister to enforce compliance and prohibits harmful AI uses. Establishes an AI and Data Commissioner. Aligns with international standards. Consults stakeholders for regulation development.
Long summary:
Proposes the Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA) to regulate AI in Canada, focusing on high-impact AI systems.

Empowers the Minister of Innovation, Science, and Industry to enforce AIDA, supported by a new AI and Data Commissioner.

Prohibits the reckless and malicious use of AI that causes harm, introducing new criminal law provisions.

Aligns with international norms, such as the EU AI Act, and integrates with existing Canadian laws.

Mandates businesses to identify, assess, and mitigate risks associated with high-impact AI systems.

Requires transparency, fairness, safety, and accountability in AI systems.

Introduces administrative penalties and criminal offences for non-compliance.

Plans a consultation process for the development of regulations, seeking input from stakeholders.

Establishes mechanisms for human oversight and monitoring of AI systems.

Targets AI systems impacting services, biometric identification, behavior influence, and health and safety.

Official name: Directive on Automated Decision-Making (Canada)
Casual name: Directive on Automated Decision-Making (Canada)
Short summary: Requires federal institutions to conduct Algorithmic Impact Assessments, ensure transparency, test for biases, and provide public access to data on automated systems. Mandates human intervention options, peer reviews, and compliance with legal and security standards.
Long summary:
Mandates compliance with the directive by April 1, 2020, for automated decision systems developed or procured post-April 1, 2020.

Requires Algorithmic Impact Assessments before production, with updates and public releases.

Demands transparency by notifying and explaining decisions made by automated systems.

Calls for testing and monitoring to prevent biases and ensure compliance with laws and directives.

Obligates data governance and quality assurance, including peer reviews and Gender-based Analysis Plus.

Ensures human intervention is possible in automated decision processes.

Provides recourse options for clients to challenge decisions.

Mandates publishing information on system effectiveness and efficiency.

Specifies consequences for non-compliance under the Financial Administration Act.

Designates the Chief Information Officer to provide guidance and maintain the Algorithmic Impact Assessment.

Excludes certain agencies and allows specific agreements for adopting directive requirements.

Official name: AI Liability Directive
Casual name: AI Liability Directive
Short summary: Establishes rules for disclosure of evidence and burden of proof in civil claims for damages caused by high-risk AI systems. Presumes fault and causal link under specific conditions. Allows national courts to order evidence disclosure and preservation. Requires Member States to implement compatible rules.
Long summary:
Establishes common rules for non-contractual fault-based civil claims related to damages caused by high-risk AI systems.

Requires disclosure of evidence from AI providers or users to substantiate claims, with courts empowered to order such disclosures.

Presumes non-compliance with duty of care if defendants fail to comply with evidence disclosure orders.

Presumes a causal link between defendant’s fault and AI system's output if certain conditions are met, allowing defendants to rebut the presumption.

Permits Member States to adopt more favorable rules for claimants, compatibility with Union law required.

Mandates evaluation and review by the European Commission within five years, considering the necessity of no-fault liability and insurance for AI operators.

Amends Directive (EU) 2020/1828 to include AI Liability Directive.

Obligates Member States to transpose the Directive into national law within two years and communicate relevant national legislative texts to the Commission.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence and the Information Privacy Principles
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence and the Information Privacy Principles
Short summary: Requires agencies using AI tools in New Zealand to conduct privacy impact assessments, ensure transparency, engage with MƒÅori communities, and implement human review of AI outputs. Emphasizes compliance with the Privacy Act 2020 and its Information Privacy Principles.
Long summary:
Requires organisations in New Zealand using AI tools to comply with the Privacy Act 2020 and the 13 information privacy principles (IPPs).

Mandates senior leadership approval for AI tool usage and a privacy impact assessment (PIA) to evaluate privacy risks.

Demands transparency about AI tool usage, including engaging with Māori on potential impacts.

Ensures human oversight to mitigate AI biases and inaccuracies.

Checks the necessity and proportionality of AI tools, considering privacy implications.

Prohibits retention or disclosure of personal information by AI tools.

Stresses the importance of training data provenance and reliability to ensure AI accuracy.

Advises on proactive privacy measures, including developing privacy policies and engaging with affected communities.

Highlights potential privacy issues with AI, such as automation blindness and overseas data disclosure risks.

Encourages organisations to secure personal information and comply with access, correction, and disclosure requirements.

Official name: Maintaining American Leadership in Artificial Intelligence (EO 13859)
Casual name: Maintaining American Leadership in Artificial Intelligence (EO 13859)
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Establishes the American AI Initiative to maintain U.S. leadership in AI, emphasizing R&D investment, workforce training, international collaboration, and public trust. Requires agencies to enhance data access, develop AI standards, and protect AI technologies from foreign threats.
Long summary:
Mandates the Federal Government to sustain U.S. leadership in AI through a coordinated strategy known as the American AI Initiative.

Requires agencies to prioritize AI R&D, enhance data accessibility, and reduce barriers for AI deployment, ensuring protection of civil liberties and privacy.

Obligates agencies to develop technical standards to minimize vulnerabilities and foster public trust in AI systems.

Directs the training of American workers in AI-related skills to prepare them for future job markets.

Instructs the development of international standards and promotes global collaboration while safeguarding critical AI technologies from foreign adversaries.

Tasks the Select Committee on Artificial Intelligence with coordinating AI R&D efforts across Federal agencies.

Instructs the issuance of guidance for AI regulation and emphasizes the development of trustworthy AI systems.

Develops an action plan to protect U.S. advantages in AI technology against strategic competitors and adversaries.

Official name: National Artificial Intelligence Research and Development Strategic Plan 2023 Update
Casual name: National Artificial Intelligence Research and Development Strategic Plan 2023 Update
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Updates the National AI R&D Strategic Plan to prioritize responsible AI research, human-AI collaboration, ethical considerations, AI safety, shared datasets, and workforce development. Expands public-private partnerships and international collaboration to advance equitable and trustworthy AI systems.
Long summary:
Requires the federal government to coordinate and focus R&D investments in AI to ensure U.S. leadership in trustworthy AI systems. 

Reaffirms eight strategies and adds a ninth to emphasize international collaboration in AI research.

Prioritizes investments in fundamental and responsible AI research, human-AI collaboration, and understanding ethical, legal, and societal implications.

Advances safety and security standards for AI systems, ensuring they are reliable and secure from vulnerabilities.

Develops shared public datasets and environments for AI training and testing to democratize access to AI resources.

Establishes benchmarks and standards for evaluating AI systems, including fairness, privacy, and bias considerations.

Addresses workforce needs by training and retraining a diverse AI-ready workforce.

Expands public-private partnerships to accelerate AI advances and facilitate global collaborations for responsible AI development.

Emphasizes the importance of AI governance and the development of international guidelines and standards for AI systems.

Official name: Bipartisan Framework for U.S. AI Act
Casual name: Bipartisan Framework for U.S. AI Act
Short summary: Establishes a licensing regime for AI developers, requiring risk management and compliance with oversight audits. Holds AI companies accountable for harms, including privacy violations and deepfake creation. Limits AI technology exports to adversaries. Demands transparency and consumer protection, especially for children.
Long summary:
Establishes a licensing regime requiring companies developing sophisticated A.I. models to register with an independent oversight body. 

Requires developers to maintain risk management, pre-deployment testing, and reporting programs as part of licensing conditions.

Grants the oversight body authority to audit companies and cooperate with state Attorneys General.

Mandates Congress to ensure A.I. companies are legally accountable for harms caused by their models, including privacy breaches and civil rights violations.

Urges Congress to use export controls and sanctions to limit A.I. technology transfers to adversary nations.

Promotes transparency by requiring companies to disclose A.I. model information and ensure users know they are interacting with A.I.

Requires A.I. system providers to label deepfakes and maintain a public database of A.I. information.

Obliges companies to implement consumer protections, including safety brakes and data usage control, especially concerning children.

Official name: Part 170: Health Data, Technology, and Interoperability: Certification Program Updates, Algorithm Transparency, and Information Sharing
Casual name: Part 170: Health Data, Technology, and Interoperability: Certification Program Updates, Algorithm Transparency, and Information Sharing
Authority: Department of Health and Human Services
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Adds definitions for "Predictive Decision Support Intervention" (Predictive DSI) involving AI algorithms for healthcare decision-making. Requires certification and configuration of AI-based decision support systems, ensuring fairness, transparency, risk management, and external validation processes. Establishes standards for data interoperability and API access.
Long summary:
Amends health IT certification criteria to include "Predictive Decision Support Intervention," addressing decision-making support based on algorithms for predictions, classifications, and recommendations.

Mandates that health IT systems enable recording of patient demographics, including race, ethnicity, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and pronouns, using specified standards.

Requires health IT modules to be updated to meet new certification criteria and provide updates to customers as per defined dates.

Outlines certification criteria for health IT, including decision support interventions that must be evidence-based and use specified data standards.

Establishes risk management practices for predictive decision support interventions, including risk analysis, mitigation, and governance.

Incorporates by reference various health information standards, including HL7, LOINC, and SNOMED CT, to ensure interoperability and accuracy in electronic health information exchange.

Official name: Section 106.11 Application: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance
Casual name: Section 106.11 Application: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Declines to expand examples of conduct under sex-based harassment regulations to include AI technologies, but reinforces responsibility for conduct within a recipient's disciplinary authority, including off-campus and online activities. Clarifies Title IX obligations for addressing hostile environments linked to education programs.
Long summary:
Requires recipients to address sex-based harassment within their education programs or activities, including off-campus and remote settings, aligning with recent court decisions.

Clarifies that institutions are responsible for discrimination within contexts they control, such as AI technologies used in educational settings.

Acknowledges requests for examples involving AI and other specific circumstances but declines to provide additional examples or exhaustive lists.

Confirms obligations for conduct during institution-sponsored events, online classes, and use of digital platforms, including AI technologies.

Deletes references to sex-based harassment occurring outside the U.S. but maintains the obligation to address contributing conduct external to the program or activity.

Official name: Train Crew Size Safety Requirements (New Technology and Automated Operations)
Casual name: Train Crew Size Safety Requirements (New Technology and Automated Operations)
Collections: U.S. regulations, executive orders, and agency policies
Short summary: Allows railroads to petition for rulemaking or waivers to use non-compliant rail automation technology. Requires safety justification for autonomous operations with fewer crew members. Supports technological advancements in rail safety and automation through research and funding.
Long summary:
Require railroads seeking to use automation technology non-compliant with FRA safety regulations to file a petition for rulemaking or a waiver.

Mandate a risk assessment before initiating operations under special approval processes.

Acknowledge freight rail industry's concerns about competition with automated trucking but emphasize rail safety hazards from reduced crew sizes.

Disagree with assertions that labor-saving technologies like PTC justify removal of crew members, stating such technologies are not fully developed.

Support technological advancement in rail through research on AI and automation, including drones and real-time safety systems.

Permit railroads to petition for rulemaking or waivers to use technology that doesn't meet existing regulatory requirements, ensuring safety justifications are provided.

Clarify that the rule does not impede innovation but requires description of technology used to support tasks typically performed by a second crew member.

Official name: H.R. 9626, To direct the Department of Defense to develop a plan for the establishment of a secure computing and data storage environment for the testing of artificial intelligence trained on biological data, and for other purposes.
Casual name: H.R. 9626, DOD Secure Computing and Data Storage Plan Development
Short summary: Establishes a secure AIxBio sandbox for testing AI trained on biological data. Designates the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering to manage it. Involves selecting defense-applicable projects and facilitating partnerships with DoD and academic labs. Requires reporting to Congress.
Long summary:
Mandates the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering to develop a plan for a secure computing and data storage environment, termed the "AIxBio sandbox," to facilitate the testing of AI models trained on biological data.

Requires the AIxBio sandbox to utilize existing Department of Defense infrastructure when feasible and designates the Under Secretary of Defense for managing and overseeing its activities.

Directs the Under Secretary to select projects for the sandbox that demonstrate potential defense applications at the intersection of AI and biotechnology, such as medical countermeasures and biomanufacturing.

Establishes mechanisms for collaboration between Department of Defense laboratories and academic institutions to support AIxBio projects, with streamlined processes for efficient partnerships.

Obligates the Under Secretary to report and brief Congress on the plan within one year of the Act's enactment.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Allied Collaboration for Crucial Operations, Research, and Development Act of 2024
Casual name: AI ACCORD Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy for enhancing AI-driven defense collaboration with Middle Eastern allies. Establishes a forum for combatant commands to coordinate AI tools and training. Mandates reporting to Congress on progress and recommendations for legislative action.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Defense to submit a strategy to Congress within 180 days to enhance cooperation with Middle Eastern allies using partner-sharing network capabilities for joint defense.

Requires the strategy to include a summary of ongoing efforts, challenges, and recommended actions for implementing joint partner-sharing networks.

Directs the Chief Data and Artificial Intelligence Officer of the Department of Defense to establish a forum for warfighters to coordinate on AI tools, methodologies, and training within 180 days.

Specifies that the forum should identify AI use cases, categorize risks, and prioritize AI tools while considering training shortfalls and opportunities for cooperation with allies.

Obligates the Secretary of Defense to report progress on the forum's establishment and recommend legislative actions to Congress within one year.

Official name: Veterans Online Information and Cybersecurity Empowerment Act of 2024
Casual name: VOICE Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes a grant program to enhance veterans' digital literacy and cybersecurity skills. Promotes media literacy, critical thinking, and understanding of foreign influence tactics. Requires grant recipients and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to report on program effectiveness. Allocates $20 million for specified fiscal years.
Long summary:
Establishes a grant program to promote digital citizenship and media literacy among veterans, requiring the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to award grants to eligible entities.

Mandates grant recipients to develop cybersecurity best practices and improve veterans' competencies in digital and media literacy.

Requires grant recipients to submit a report on their activities and effectiveness one year after receiving funds.

Obliges the Secretary to report to Congress on the program's overall activities and effectiveness after receiving the last report from grant recipients.

Authorizes $20 million in appropriations for fiscal years 2023, 2025, and 2027 to fund the program.

Defines key terms such as "cybersecurity best practices," "digital citizenship," "media literacy," and "eligible entity."

Encourages the Secretary to maintain a list of grant recipients and promote communication among them.

Acknowledges the role of foreign influence campaigns and online scams targeting veterans as critical issues that need addressing.

Official name: Protecting Patients from Deceptive Drug Ads Online Act
Casual name: Protecting Patients from Deceptive Drug Ads Online Act
Short summary: Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to penalize false or misleading drug communications by social media influencers and healthcare providers. Requires guidance and regulations for telehealth providers. Authorizes FDA to conduct AI-enhanced market surveillance of drug promotions.
Long summary:
Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to impose civil penalties on social media influencers and healthcare providers who make false or misleading communications about prescription drugs.

Mandates the issuance of guidance within 180 days to define false or misleading communications and outline compliance procedures.

Expands the definition of "manufacturer, packer, or distributor" to include telehealth providers involved in drug advertising.

Requires reporting of payments related to drug promotion to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Authorizes market surveillance activities using AI to monitor prescription drug promotions on social media and coordinate efforts with the Federal Trade Commission.

Allocates $15 million annually for fiscal years 2025 to 2029 to support these activities.

Establishes a process for notifying drug manufacturers of non-compliant communications by influencers or healthcare providers.

Ensures the severability of the Act's provisions, maintaining validity even if parts are invalidated.

Official name: Transformational Artificial intelligence to Modernize the Economy against Extreme Weather Act
Casual name: TAME Extreme Weather Act
Short summary: Develops advanced AI applications for weather forecasting, enhances AI weather model integration, and improves emissions monitoring. Supports AI use to predict extreme weather impacts and fires. Encourages public-private partnerships and workforce development, ensuring data access while safeguarding national security and intellectual property.
Long summary:
Mandates the development of comprehensive weather forecasting training datasets using AI to improve Earth system modeling and weather forecasts.

Requires collaboration with federal agencies and experts to enhance AI weather models and explore AI's role in public preparedness and resilience.

Directs the use of AI for fire environment modeling to predict, detect, and forecast wildfires and associated hazards.

Establishes an emissions monitoring program using AI to analyze global atmospheric data and improve greenhouse gas emission models.

Encourages partnerships with private and academic entities to advance AI in weather forecasting and environmental predictions.

Calls for recruitment and development of a diverse workforce skilled in AI applications for weather forecasting.

Allows public access to data and code developed under this Act, with safeguards for national security and intellectual property.

Supports ongoing research and data acquisition for AI and numerical weather models, ensuring continued advancement in weather prediction technologies.

Official name: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Grand Challenges Act of 2024
