Short summary: Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to award prizes for AI research in areas like health, cybersecurity, and national security. Requires $1 million minimum prize per winner, with potential awards exceeding $50 million. Encourages public and interagency collaboration.
Long summary:
Establishes the AI Grand Challenges Program to stimulate AI research, development, and commercialization through prize competitions addressing grand challenges in various sectors like national security, health, and environment.

Requires the Director of the National Science Foundation, in coordination with other federal agencies, to oversee the program and consult with public and private entities.

Mandates the creation of a specific grand challenge for AI-enabled cancer breakthroughs, with prize awards of at least $10,000,000.

Sets eligibility criteria for participants, requiring private entities to be U.S.-based and individuals to be U.S. citizens or permanent residents.

Allows for substantial prize amounts, with minimum awards of $1,000,000 and potential for awards exceeding $50,000,000.

Permits funding from various governmental and non-governmental sources and mandates reporting to Congress on the program's progress and outcomes.

Ensures prize competitions are publicly accessible via Challenge.gov.

Official name: AI Development Practices Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Development Practices Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to require developing voluntary AI development guidelines. Focuses on risk management, communication practices, and collaboration. Involves public reporting, security measures, and international standards alignment. Mandates committee briefings 18 months post-enactment.
Long summary:
Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to require the development of voluntary guidelines for AI system development, release, and assessment.

Mandates the Director of NIST to collaborate with public and private organizations to create guidance on AI risk tolerances and communication of system characteristics.

Requires categorization of practices related to security, safety, fairness, privacy, and other attributes of AI systems.

Obligates the Director to update the voluntary risk management framework for trustworthy AI systems.

Prohibits prescribing specific technologies; mandates reliance on international standards and industry best practices.

Requires collaboration with public, industry, and academic entities for guidance development.

Demands a report to Congress within 18 months on new materials or systems produced and policy recommendations for private-public sector coordination.

Defines "artificial intelligence red teaming" and "artificial intelligence system" for clarity.

Official name: Expanding AI Voices Act
Casual name: Expanding AI Voices Act
Short summary: Amends the National AI Initiative Act to require the National Science Foundation to award grants to broaden AI research, education, and workforce development. Targets underrepresented institutions, fosters collaborations, and emphasizes ethical practices in AI education.
Long summary:
Amends the National AI Initiative Act by introducing a new subsection focused on expanding AI capacity.

Mandates the Director of the National Science Foundation to competitively award eligible higher education institutions and nonprofit organizations to enhance AI research, education, and workforce development.

Specifies eligibility for institutions not among the top 100 in federal R&D spending, historically Black colleges, minority-serving institutions, Tribal colleges, and their consortia.

Encourages collaborations with various stakeholders, including AI research institutes and private sector entities.

Allows use of funds for AI research programs, faculty development, resource access, community building, workshops, and ethical AI education.

Requires outreach to eligible entities, emphasizing underserved and underrepresented communities.

Ensures awarded projects complement existing programs without duplication.

Considers diversity, geographic distribution, and resource constraints in award decisions.

Official name: Unleashing AI Innovation in Financial Services Act
Casual name: Unleashing AI Innovation in Financial Services Act
Short summary: Establishes regulatory sandboxes for financial entities to test AI projects with reduced regulatory burden. Requires applications detailing compliance strategies, potential impacts, and public interest benefits. Mandates annual reports on outcomes and allows agencies to create additional AI project regulations post-approval.
Long summary:
Establishes regulatory sandboxes allowing financial entities to experiment with AI test projects under reduced regulatory burdens.

Requires financial entities to apply for sandbox participation by detailing their AI project, compliance strategies, and potential public benefits.

Mandates applications include risk assessments for systemic financial stability and national security.

Obligates financial regulatory agencies to review applications within 90 days, with provisions for approval, denial, or extension.

Allows joint applications by multiple entities and necessitates notification to all relevant regulatory bodies.

Stipulates data security measures for information provided by AI project sponsors.

Directs each financial regulatory agency to promulgate regulations, including modification procedures and confidentiality protocols, within 180 days of the Act’s enactment.

Mandates annual reporting to Congress on AI test project outcomes.

Permits regulatory agencies to establish additional AI projects as qualifying test projects after public consultation.

Official name: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program Reauthorization Act of 2024
Casual name: National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program Reauthorization Act of 2024
Short summary: Integrates machine learning and advanced technologies into windstorm research, supporting interdisciplinary collaborations. Enhances understanding of climate change impacts on windstorms. Allocates funding for research, infrastructure, and resilience measures to mitigate windstorm effects across diverse communities.
Long summary:
Amends the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Act of 2004 to include provisions for understanding climate variability and its impact on windstorms, aiming to inform future building codes.

Supports the integration of emerging technologies, such as machine learning, in research and engineering activities related to windstorm mitigation.

Encourages interdisciplinary research, including collaborations between social scientists and engineers, to enhance atmospheric measurements relevant to building engineering.

Promotes the use of advanced construction methods and materials to strengthen properties against windstorms and related impacts.

Mandates an analysis of the need for a tornado research facility to study tornado impacts on buildings.

Requires research into public response to windstorm risks and factors influencing risk communication and reduction measures.

Allocates specific funding amounts for the program from fiscal years 2025 to 2029.

Sets deadlines for reports and analyses, including future research infrastructure needs, to be completed by specified dates.

Official name: Bureau of Industry and Security Information Technology Modernization Act
Casual name: BIS IT Modernization Act
Short summary: Requires the Bureau of Industry and Security to integrate AI, machine learning, and advanced tools into IT systems. Mandates data fusion and analytics for export controls. Enhances data sharing and security. Allocates $25 million annually through 2028 for modernization.
Long summary:
Mandates the Bureau of Industry and Security to adopt advanced data fusion, analytics, and AI capabilities to enhance export control processes and identify evasive trade patterns.

Requires the integration of AI and machine learning into Bureau IT systems to improve decision-making and enforce export controls effectively.

Obligates the Bureau to automate and streamline data sharing with industry, federal agencies, and international partners.

Demands the modernization of IT systems to support seamless data management, enhance security, and facilitate the use of cutting-edge technology.

Stipulates objectives for technology adoption, including productivity enhancement, cost reduction, and improved user experience for U.S. exporters.

Instructs the Under Secretary to reassess staffing needs and consult Congress on personnel adjustments during the modernization.

Authorizes $25 million annually from 2025 to 2028 for these initiatives.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Acquisitions Act of 2024
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence Acquisitions Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits federal agencies from acquiring AI products/services linked to foreign adversaries, requiring divestment within specified timelines. Mandates public disclosure of risky AI products/services. Exempts intelligence and specific Department of Defense activities from these restrictions.
Long summary:
Mandates the development of a list of artificial intelligence products or services posing national security risks, focusing on those associated with foreign entities of concern.

Requires the Executive Director, alongside the Under Secretary of Commerce and the Federal Acquisition Security Council, to publish and annually update this list.

Prohibits federal agencies from purchasing or procuring AI products or services included on this list.

Obligates contractors with federal agencies to divest from listed AI products within specified timeframes.

Allows exceptions for intelligence activities and specific Department of Defense operations related to defense intelligence and adversarial AI research.

Defines key terms including "artificial intelligence," "foreign person of concern," and "country of concern," specifying entities like China, Russia, and Iran as countries of concern.

Sets a timeline for initial list publication within one year of the Act's enactment and mandates public notification if no updates are made annually.

Official name: Forecasting Optimization for Robust Earth Climate Analysis and Subseasonal-to-Seasonal Tracking Act of 2024
Casual name: FORECASTS Tracking Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes the Weather and Earth System Modeling and Data Assimilation Workforce Innovation Program to advance AI in forecasting. Prioritizes multi-model ensemble systems, emerging technologies, and workforce development. Authorizes significant appropriations for research and operational advancements in weather prediction.
Long summary:
Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to improve subseasonal-to-seasonal weather forecasting by requiring the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to enhance research, data collection, and model development.

Mandates the development of multi-model ensemble forecast systems and data management strategies, and the operationalization of new modeling technologies.

Establishes an Internet clearinghouse for forecasts and related information.

Creates the Weather and Earth System Modeling and Data Assimilation Workforce Innovation Program to support education, recruitment, and workforce development in weather modeling and data assimilation, emphasizing artificial intelligence and machine learning.

Requires the Under Secretary to develop and update a workforce human capital plan and report on the program's effectiveness.

Authorizes appropriations for these initiatives, including $40 million annually from 2025 to 2030 for the workforce program and additional funding for NOAA's weather research activities.

Official name: AI Innovation and Development for Efficiency Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Innovation and Development for Efficiency Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the National Science Foundation to support research on AI-enabled efficient technologies, focusing on smart grids, transportation, and emissions reduction. Emphasizes impact assessments and prioritizes projects at EPSCoR institutions. Mandates reporting findings and recommendations to Congress.
Long summary:
Mandates the National Science Foundation Director to support research on AI-enabled efficient technologies through merit-reviewed and competitively awarded projects.

Requires consideration of projects focusing on smart technologies for infrastructure efficiency, pollution minimization, and upgrading existing constructions.

Obliges researchers to conduct impact assessments of energy consumption for AI-enabled technologies.

Prioritizes research conducted at EPSCoR institutions.

Directs the Director to report findings and recommendations on research opportunities and coordination with federal agencies and the private sector within 18 months of enactment.

Requires a report on research results within four years to relevant Senate and House committees.

Official name: Workforce for AI Trust Act
Casual name: Workforce for AI Trust Act
Short summary: Amends the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act to support NSF fellowships for interdisciplinary AI research, emphasizing ethics and responsible practices. Enhances NIST's role in AI governance workforce development and risk management, focusing on education, technical standards, and professional certifications.
Long summary:
Amends the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 to authorize the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support interdisciplinary AI fellowships, encouraging ethical AI practices.

Mandates the NSF to conduct outreach to diverse institutions and groups underrepresented in STEM fields for fellowship applicants.

Directs the NSF to promote AI-based training and workshops across STEM fields to accelerate scientific discovery and technology development.

Requires the integration of diverse disciplinary perspectives in AI research peer review panels.

Instructs the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to support education and workforce development to expand the AI governance workforce, focusing on managing AI-related risks.

Mandates NIST to develop technical standards and guidance for AI risk management careers, including mapping, measuring, and validating AI systems.

Official name: Literacy in Future Technologies Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: LIFT AI Act
Short summary: Establishes awards for developing K-12 AI literacy curricula. Supports research and professional development to enhance AI literacy. Prioritizes adaptable skills amidst evolving AI technology. Defines AI literacy as the ability to use and interpret AI effectively and ethically.
Long summary:
Establishes the "LIFT AI Act" to advance AI literacy in K–12 education.

Empowers the Director of the National Science Foundation to award competitive grants to higher education institutions or nonprofits for developing AI literacy curricula and evaluation methods.

Mandates AI literacy education to prepare a skilled workforce and maintain U.S. leadership in AI.

Recognizes the importance of AI literacy in mitigating ethical challenges and adapting to rapidly evolving AI technologies.

Supports curriculum development focused on essential AI abilities and competencies, including project-based, personalized learning.

Engages educational stakeholders in professional learning to enhance AI literacy and establish best practices.

Develops evaluation tools for assessing AI literacy proficiency.

Designs professional development courses for educators integrating various learning experiences.

Encourages incorporating AI literacy in existing curricula, emphasizing responsible AI use.

Official name: Atomic Supply Chain Solutions Act
Casual name: Atomic Supply Chain Solutions Act
Short summary: Analyzes potential AI applications in the nuclear supply chain, including cybersecurity, efficiency, maintenance, and workforce training. Evaluates AI's role in identifying counterfeit components and economic considerations. Considers regulatory challenges related to AI usage in the nuclear industry.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Energy to evaluate the U.S. nuclear supply chain within 270 days, including past efforts, future needs, and lessons from projects like Vogtle 3 and 4.

Analyzes regulatory challenges, including the necessity of N-stamps for nuclear components, cost implications, and potential certification streamlining.

Considers advanced manufacturing and innovative technologies like AI, 3D printing, and robotics for enhancing the nuclear supply chain, with attention to cybersecurity, efficiency, and workforce training.

Describes U.S.-Canada cooperation on nuclear components, assessing competitiveness and recommending collaboration to enhance North American nuclear leadership.

Assesses the impact of anticipated demand for advanced nuclear technology on the supply chain, proposing strategies for resilience.

Establishes U.S. policy to prioritize a robust HALEU market to strengthen energy independence and national security, addressing risks associated with increased nuclear technology demand.

Official name: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Advancement Act
Casual name: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Advancement Act
Short summary: Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to develop, update, and disseminate AI resources for small businesses, ensuring applicability, promoting understanding, including case studies, and aligning with international standards. Requires biennial reviews, voluntary usage, and reporting to Congress.
Long summary:
Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to mandate the development and dissemination of AI resources for small businesses.

Requires these resources to include technical standards, best practices, benchmarks, methodologies, and case studies, ensuring they are widely applicable and technology-neutral.

Mandates that resources promote understanding and adoption of AI, adhere to international standards, and incorporate federal educational resources.

Obligates the Director to review and update these resources every two years.

Coordinates with the Small Business Administration for the distribution and utilization of AI resources through its partners, emphasizing voluntary use.

Compels a report to Congress within four years, detailing resources, feedback, and recommendations for enhancing AI utilization by small businesses.

Official name: Nucleic Acid Standards for Biosecurity Act
Casual name: Nucleic Acid Standards for Biosecurity Act
Short summary: Amends the law to develop best practices and technical standards for managing AI-related risks in engineering biology. Establishes a consortium to create guidelines for nucleic acid synthesis screening. Allocates $5 million annually for 2025-2029 for these activities.
Long summary:
Amends the Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act to include best practices and technical standards for managing risks in engineering biology and biomanufacturing, specifically addressing artificial intelligence.

Requires the Director, in consultation with Federal agencies, to conduct measurement research supporting biosecurity measures related to nucleic acid synthesis.

Mandates testing to improve screening accuracy, efficacy, and reliability, along with best practices for operational security and database management.

Directs the development of technical guidance for effective and secure screening and conformity-assessment standards.

Establishes a consortium of stakeholders to develop and update best practices and roadmaps for synthetic nucleic acid procurement screening.

Requires the consortium to report its findings to Congress within 18 months of its first meeting.

Authorizes $5,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2025 through 2029 for scientific and technical research activities under this initiative.

Official name: S.4870, A bill to require reports on artificial intelligence regulation in the financial services industry.
Casual name: S.4870, A bill to require reports on artificial intelligence regulation in the financial services industry.
Short summary: Require federal financial agencies to report to Congress on AI knowledge gaps, usage, governance standards, regulatory needs, interagency issues, and resource requirements within 90 days. Exclude confidential supervisory and nonpublic information from reports.
Long summary:
Require the Federal Reserve, FDIC, OCC, NCUA, and CFPB to report on AI knowledge gaps in financial services within 90 days.

Mandate analysis on AI-assisted tasks in regulated institutions.

Assess current AI governance and oversight standards.

Identify additional regulatory authorities needed for effective mission execution.

Clarify overlapping AI regulatory issues between agencies.

Evaluate current and planned agency use of AI over the next three years, including fiscal and staffing impacts.

Determine necessary resources to adapt to AI changes and oversee its use.

Ensure reports exclude confidential or nonpublic information.

Official name: S.4862, A bill to ensure that new advances in artificial intelligence are ethically adopted to improve the health of all individuals, and for other purposes.
Casual name: S.4862, A bill to ensure that new advances in artificial intelligence are ethically adopted to improve the health of all individuals, and for other purposes.
Short summary: Amends the Public Health Service Act to require NIH to develop AI resources and datasets for health research, and to provide education for ethical AI use. Requires hospitals to request patients' consent for EHR data sharing. Allocates $660 million for AI initiatives.
Long summary:
Amends the Public Health Service Act to mandate the NIH Director develop AI resources and datasets for health research, provide AI expertise, and maintain data access resources.

Authorizes $400 million for NIH AI initiatives in fiscal year 2025.

Directs the National Coordinator for Health IT to utilize electronic health records for research, establish data standards, and align with national interoperability frameworks.

Appropriates $10 million for data collection and $50 million for data standards.

Requires hospitals to request patient consent to use health records for research, contingent upon patient approval.

Expresses the Senate's view that NIH representation is crucial in steering committees for national AI research resources.

Mandates the National Library of Medicine to establish data-sharing facilities and create a core data science program.

Appropriates $100 million each for these library initiatives in fiscal year 2025.

Official name: Digital Social Platform Transparency Act
Casual name: Digital Social Platform Transparency Act
Short summary: Requires digital social companies to post and translate terms of service, including content moderation details, within 180 days. Mandates semiannual reports to the Attorney General on terms of service updates and content moderation practices. Imposes penalties for non-compliance.
Long summary:
Mandates digital social companies to post terms of service for each platform within 180 days, detailing contact information, content flagging processes, and potential actions like banning or demonetization.

Requires translation of terms into all supported languages.

Obligates companies to submit semiannual terms of service reports to the Attorney General, detailing content moderation practices and AI involvement, including flagged content statistics and appeal outcomes.

Establishes penalties up to $15,000 per day for non-compliance, managed by the Attorney General, who can take legal action.

Specifies the creation of a public repository of reports for transparency.

Excludes platforms limited to direct messaging or transactions from the Act's scope and protects end-to-end encryption.

Defines key terms and grants the Attorney General interpretive authority.

Ensures Act's obligations and penalties are additional to existing laws.

Official name: Validation and Evaluation for Trustworthy (VET) Artificial Intelligence Act
Casual name: VET Artificial Intelligence Act
Short summary: Establishes voluntary guidelines for AI assurance, requiring testing and validation to build trust and accountability. Involves stakeholder input, sets qualifications for evaluators, and mandates a study on assurance capabilities. Aligns with existing AI risk management frameworks.
Long summary:
Establishes the "VET Artificial Intelligence Act" to create voluntary guidelines for the testing, evaluation, validation, and verification of AI systems, aiming to enhance trust, adoption, and governance.

Mandates the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to develop and update these guidelines, addressing consumer privacy, harm mitigation, dataset quality, and governance.

Requires the establishment of an Artificial Intelligence Assurance Qualifications Advisory Committee to provide recommendations on qualifications and accreditation for AI assurance processes.

Directs a study to evaluate the capabilities of entities conducting AI assurances, assessing their resources, methodologies, and market demand, and exploring the use of existing accredited facilities for these purposes.

Obliges the publication of guidelines and recommendations for assurance qualifications, ensuring alignment with international standards, without mandating specific technologies. 

Involves stakeholder outreach, public comment, and collaboration with various sectors to refine guidelines.

Official name: Civilian Agency AI Watermark Act
Casual name: Civilian Agency AI Watermark Act
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to consult with relevant directors to develop an AI watermark system for civilian agency applications. Authorizes necessary appropriations annually for this purpose.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to consult with the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office within eight months to develop an AI watermark and trademark system for identifying Federal agency-approved AI applications for civilian agency use.

Authorizes the appropriation of necessary funds each fiscal year to the Secretary of Homeland Security to implement this AI watermark system.

Official name: Fraudulent Artificial Intelligence Regulations (FAIR) Elections Act of 2024
Casual name: Fraudulent Artificial Intelligence Regulations (FAIR) Elections Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits knowingly distributing false AI-generated election media to mislead voters or intimidate officials. Exempts certain media organizations if falsehoods are clearly disclosed. Authorizes the Attorney General to enforce violations.
Long summary:
Prohibits the distribution of false AI-generated election media containing materially false information about election details or voter eligibility with the intent to impede voting in federal elections.

Prohibits the distribution of false AI-generated depictions of election officials intended to intimidate or harass officials or deter voting.

Exempts bona fide news entities from these prohibitions if they clearly disclose the falsity of the AI-generated content.

Empowers the Attorney General to enforce these prohibitions through civil actions in U.S. District Courts.

Amends the National Voter Registration Act to prevent states from using unverified databases to remove voters from official lists, requiring government-verified information approved by the Attorney General.

Sets criteria for source information, including monthly updates and non-violation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

Ensures severability of the Act’s provisions, maintaining the validity of remaining sections if any part is invalidated.

Official name: Department of Energy AI Act
Casual name: Department of Energy AI Act
Short summary: Establishes a centralized AI program within the Department of Energy to advance AI research and deployment for science, security, and technology. Requires development of AI models, datasets, and infrastructure. Mandates AI risk evaluation, workforce development, and partnerships. Allocates $2.4 billion annually for five years.
Long summary:
Establishes the "Department of Energy AI Act" to advance AI capabilities within the Department of Energy (DOE).

Requires the Secretary of Energy to create a centralized AI program focused on research and deployment of AI for science, security, and technology.

Mandates the development of AI training datasets, next-generation computing infrastructure, and safe AI models.

Directs the establishment of at least eight multidisciplinary AI Research and Development Centers to enhance U.S. leadership in AI.

Implements an AI Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Program to address safety and security concerns.

Allocates funds for STEM education and workforce development, emphasizing AI skill training and diversity.

Establishes a program to use AI to improve federal permitting processes for energy projects.

Initiates rulemaking to standardize AI use in grid interconnection.

Requires a report on the impact of AI on data centers and energy security.

Creates the Office of Critical and Emerging Technology to coordinate AI efforts across the DOE and assess technological impacts on national security.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Public Awareness and Education Campaign Act
Casual name: Artificial Intelligence Public Awareness and Education Campaign Act
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Commerce to conduct an AI awareness and education campaign. Involves evaluating effectiveness with key performance indicators, promoting best practices, and targeting vulnerable populations against AI-enabled fraud. Mandates reporting to Congress within one year.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a public awareness and education campaign on artificial intelligence within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in coordination with relevant Federal agencies.

Requires determination of key performance indicators for evaluating the AI Campaign’s effectiveness and gathering baseline data for comparison.

Facilitates information exchange on AI to promote knowledge and rights awareness, and identifies best practices for detecting AI-generated media like deepfakes.

Conducts outreach to the public about AI's prevalence and applications in daily life and commercial settings.

Targets outreach to vulnerable groups, such as senior citizens, to prevent AI-enabled fraud.

Promotes workforce opportunities in AI, including Federal Government roles, and engages with educational institutions.

Consults with stakeholders from academia, industry, and community organizations on AI usage.

Requires a report to Congress within one year on the AI Campaign’s activities, key performance indicators, and recommendations for future actions.

Prohibits authorization of additional funds for implementing this Act.

Official name: Ending FCC Meddling in Our Elections Act
Casual name: Ending FCC Meddling in Our Elections Act
Short summary: Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission from creating or enforcing rules about disclosing AI-generated content in political advertisements, as outlined in a May 22, 2024, draft proposal by the Commission's Chairwoman.
Long summary:
Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) from promulgating or enforcing any rules related to the disclosure of artificial intelligence-generated content in political advertisements.

Restricts the FCC specifically from acting on the draft notice of proposed rulemaking circulated by the Chairwoman on May 22, 2024, concerning AI-generated content disclosure in political ads across television, radio, or other services.

Bars the FCC from enacting any rules substantially similar to the aforementioned proposal.

Official name: State Industrial Competitiveness Act of 2024
Casual name: State Industrial Competitiveness Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish a Flex-Tech Energy Program. Provides financial assistance for manufacturers to enhance competitiveness, including AI adoption. Allocates funding, emphasizes technical assistance, and mandates a minimum 5% funding for Indian Tribes.
Long summary:
Amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish the Flex-Tech Energy Program aimed at enhancing manufacturing competitiveness.

Requires the Secretary to provide financial assistance to State energy agencies or Indian Tribes for developing and implementing flex-tech programs, including measures related to advanced manufacturing technologies and artificial intelligence.

Mandates that energy studies of manufacturing facilities evaluate systems, emissions, and potential efficiency measures, including AI applications.

Allocates at least 5% of funds specifically for Indian Tribes or manufacturers in Indian Country.

Limits financial assistance usage, capping administrative expenses at 10% and individual facility funding at $100,000 or 5% of total assistance.

Encourages the use of both public and private financing in program implementation.

Authorizes $100 million annually from 2025 to 2029 for the program.

Official name: Improving Seniors’ Timely Access to Care Act of 2024
Casual name: Improving Seniors’ Timely Access to Care Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires Medicare Advantage plans to implement electronic prior authorization programs by 2027, ensuring secure data transmission and compliance with technical standards. Mandates transparency in technology use, including AI, and reporting on decision-making, appeals, and access impacts. Establishes enrollee protection standards.
Long summary:
Mandates Medicare Advantage plans, starting January 1, 2027, to implement an electronic prior authorization program for secure electronic transmission of requests and responses, excluding certain formats like facsimiles.

Requires plans, beginning January 1, 2026, to meet transparency requirements, including submitting annual data on prior authorization requests, appeals, and the use of AI technologies in decision-making.

Obligates plans to provide access to authorization criteria and documentation requirements to providers, suppliers, and enrollees upon request.

Empowers the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish response timeframes for prior authorization requests, potentially as short as 24 hours.

Tasks the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission with analyzing and reporting on prior authorization use and recommending improvements.

Directs the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to study and report on real-time decision processes and the impact of AI on patient access, especially for rural and low-income beneficiaries.

Official name: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Training Act of 2024
Casual name: Small Business Artificial Intelligence Training Act of 2024
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Commerce to develop AI training resources for small businesses, including those in rural and underserved areas. Mandates annual review and updates of resources. Allows grants for AI training. Terminates the program after three years.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with various agencies, to develop AI training resources for small businesses, including those in rural, Tribal, or underserved areas.

Requires these resources to cover topics such as prompt engineering, financial management, cybersecurity, and government contracting.

Obligates the review and update of these resources every year to ensure relevance and effectiveness.

Coordinates with the Small Business Administration for the distribution of these resources through its network, including development centers and business opportunity centers.

Allows for a grants program to fund training providers using the developed resources.

Demands initial and annual reports to Congress on the progress and impact of the training resources.

Establishes a sunset clause terminating the program three years after the Act's enactment.

Official name: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
Casual name: AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require disclaimers on political ads using AI-generated content. Establishes penalties for non-compliance and mandates the Federal Election Commission to issue regulations and periodic reports on enforcement and compliance.
Long summary:
Enacts the "AI Transparency in Elections Act of 2024."

Requires disclaimers on political advertisements with content generated by AI, defining "covered communications" and "substantially generated by artificial intelligence."

Mandates clear disclosure in ads using AI-generated images, audio, or video, specifying format requirements for visibility and audibility.

Imposes penalties for non-compliance, with fines up to $50,000 per violation, considering factors like previous violations and distribution scope.

Defines "qualified disclaimer requirement" and expedites judicial review for related complaints.

Obliges the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to issue regulations within 90 days, outlining criteria for AI content identification and statement requirements.

Applies provisions to communications post-enactment, regardless of FEC regulation status.

Requires FEC to report biannually on compliance and enforcement, providing recommendations for improvements.

Includes a severability clause ensuring the act's continuity if parts are deemed unconstitutional.

Official name: Supercritical Geothermal Research and Development Act
Casual name: Supercritical Geothermal Research and Development Act
Short summary: Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act to incorporate machine learning in geothermal research. Establishes a supercritical geothermal research program focusing on supercritical conditions. Requires periodic updates to geothermal data repositories. Authorizes funding for research and development through 2030.
Long summary:
Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to include machine learning algorithms in geothermal research and development.

Establishes a supercritical geothermal research and development program within the Geothermal Technologies Office, focusing on well completion, permeability, materials, sensors, and water-rock geochemistry.

Requires the creation of a repository for geothermal data, with periodic updates for data standardization and accessibility.

Mandates a memorandum of understanding for data sharing regarding geothermal development among federal departments.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to drill deep exploration boreholes for geothermal mapping.

Establishes a next-generation geothermal center of excellence to coordinate research, development, and workforce initiatives.

Authorizes $5 million annually from 2026 to 2030 for these activities.

Updates geothermal resource assessments quadrennially to include supercritical geothermal regions.

Requires progress reports on geothermal resource potential and commercialization barriers.

Official name: Detection Equipment and Technology Evaluation to Counter the Threat of Fentanyl and Xylazine Act of 2024
Casual name: DETECT Fentanyl and Xylazine Act of 2024
Short summary: Amends the Homeland Security Act to enhance drug detection capabilities using AI, requiring research and development of equipment for law enforcement. Directs adherence to AI risk management guidelines and prioritization based on DEA threat reports.
Long summary:
Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance the detection and disruption of drugs like fentanyl and xylazine using advanced technologies.

Mandates research and development of equipment for drug detection and trafficking disruption, emphasizing minimal handling and separation of complex mixtures.

Incorporates machine learning and artificial intelligence to predict controlled substance analogues and new psychoactive substances.

Requires the Under Secretary for Science and Technology to adhere to the NIST AI Risk Management Framework or its successor.

Establishes research and evaluation priorities using the latest information from reports on drug threats by the Drug Enforcement Administration.

Ensures federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement agencies have access to improved detection technologies.

Official name: Preventing the Algorithmic Facilitation of Rental Housing Cartels Act of 2024
Casual name: Preventing the Algorithmic Facilitation of Rental Housing Cartels Act of 2024
Short summary: Prohibits rental property owners from using coordinators to manipulate rental prices. Prohibits coordinators from facilitating non-competitive agreements and engaging in anti-competitive mergers. Empowers the FTC and state attorneys general to enforce the Act.
Long summary:
Prohibits rental property owners from using coordinators for algorithmic price coordination, deeming such actions per se violations of the Sherman Act.

Prohibits coordinators from facilitating non-competitive agreements among rental property owners or performing coordinating functions.

Prohibits coordinators from acquiring another coordinator if it lessens competition, violating the Clayton Act.

Empowers the Federal Trade Commission, the Attorney General, and State Attorneys General to enforce the Act with the same powers and duties as the FTC Act, Sherman Act, and Clayton Act.

Allows civil actions by injured persons to recover treble damages and litigation costs, with the option to invalidate pre-dispute arbitration agreements.

Clarifies that the Act does not preempt State, Tribal, or local laws that supplement its provisions.

Ensures severability of the Act if any provision is deemed unconstitutional, maintaining the effectiveness of remaining provisions.

Official name: NSF and USDA Interagency Research Act
Casual name: NSF and USDA Interagency Research Act
Short summary: Require collaborative AI research by the USDA and NSF, emphasizing emerging technologies like AI, machine learning, and robotics for agriculture. Establish memoranda of understanding, promote data sharing, and support infrastructure and workforce development. Report on achievements and opportunities biennially.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Agriculture and the Director of the National Science Foundation to conduct collaborative research and development activities, including those involving artificial intelligence and digital agriculture, to advance their mission priorities.

Requires the establishment of memoranda of understanding to coordinate these activities through competitive, merit-based processes.

Permits collaborative research in key areas, such as AI, machine learning, automation, and digital agriculture.

Encourages data sharing and collaboration among federal agencies, educational institutions, and nonprofit entities.

Supports research infrastructure and the development of translational technologies for commercial use.

Facilitates public-private partnerships and awards grants to educational institutions to establish a Center for Agricultural Research, Education, and Workforce Development.

Authorizes reimbursable agreements to enhance research effectiveness and mandates a report to Congress on interagency coordination and future collaboration opportunities.

Ensures research security consistent with the CHIPS Act of 2022.

Official name: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act
Casual name: Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act
Short summary: Requires the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance on using AI and technology for retrospective regulatory reviews. Mandates agencies to submit and implement plans for reviewing regulations using this guidance, identifying obsolete or burdensome regulations.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to report on the progress of making agency regulations available in machine-readable format within 180 days.

Mandates the issuance of guidance within 18 months on using technology, including AI, for conducting retrospective reviews of agency regulations.

Instructs agencies to use technology to identify obsolete, ineffective, or problematic regulations and adequately train personnel in its use.

Obliges agency heads to submit a detailed plan within two years for implementing the guidance, including identifying regulations for review.

Compels agency heads to implement the strategy for retrospective review within 180 days after plan submission.

Official name: Synthetic Biology Advancement Act of 2024
Casual name: Synthetic Biology Advancement Act of 2024
Short summary: Establishes a National Synthetic Biology Center to award grants for projects integrating AI and synthetic biology in agriculture. Prioritizes research on gene editing, digital agriculture, and AI applications. Requires reporting on funded research and innovation progress to Congress biennially.
Long summary:
Establishes the National Synthetic Biology Center to award grants for advancing synthetic biology in agriculture.

Requires the Center to prioritize research in areas like cellular biology, gene editing, and digital agriculture.

Mandates the use of artificial intelligence to accelerate modeling and measurement for synthetic biological solutions.

Provides grants to eligible institutions, fostering partnerships with entities such as nonprofits and national laboratories.

Sets criteria for grant applications, emphasizing the promotion of synthetic biology technologies and sustainability in agriculture.

Directs the Center to coordinate with technology transfer offices to commercialize innovations.

Requires the Center to maintain a website for disseminating findings and facilitating collaboration.

Obligates the Center to submit biennial reports to Congress on research findings and grant progress.

Authorizes appropriations for the Center's operation and grant awards from 2025 to 2029.

Official name: American Privacy Rights Act of 2024, Sec. 114-5
Casual name: American Privacy Rights Act of 2024, Sec. 114-5
Short summary: Establishes a pilot program to promote privacy-enhancing technologies like homomorphic encryption and federated learning. Requires development of a petition process and an auditing system for oversight. Mandates ongoing audits and allows withdrawal for non-compliance. Provides liability limitations for compliant participants.
Long summary:
Establishes a pilot program to encourage private sector use of privacy-enhancing technologies within one year of the Act's enactment to protect covered data.

Requires the Commission to develop a petition process for entities to join the pilot program and implement an auditing system using privacy-enhancing technologies for enforcement purposes.

Mandates ongoing audits of participating entities to ensure compliance with privacy-enhancing technologies.

Allows covered entities deemed compliant to be considered in compliance with section 109, with a rebuttable presumption in certain legal actions.

Obligates the Comptroller General to study the pilot program's progress and effectiveness, with an initial briefing and a final report to Congress.

Creates a new bureau within the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to enforce the title with experts, including technologists experienced with AI.

Establishes a Privacy and Security Victims Relief Fund for consumer redress and technological research.

Requires the FTC to report to Congress on investigations and future plans related to the title.

Official name: Sec. 103, Supporting Affordability and Fairness with Every Bet Act
Casual name: Sec. 103, Supporting Affordability and Fairness with Every Bet Act
Short summary: Prohibits sports wagering operators from using AI to track individual wagers, target promotions, or create gambling products like microbets. Requires operators to follow strict data security and consumer protection standards, including preventing underage gambling and ensuring contest integrity.
Long summary:
Prohibits sports wagering operators from using artificial intelligence to track individual wagers, target specific individuals with offers or promotions, or create gambling products like microbets.

Requires sports wagering operators to ensure data security and to take reasonable steps to prevent unauthorized access or dissemination of wagering and customer data.

Mandates real-time or near-real-time sharing of anonymized sports wagering data with the State regulatory entity.

Imposes strict consumer protections, including restrictions on AI use, limits on deposits, and mandatory affordability checks for high-value wagers.

Establishes comprehensive standards for licensing, recordkeeping, and employee background checks to ensure the integrity and accountability of sports wagering operators.

Requires cooperation with investigations by regulatory authorities and sports organizations, and mandates robust internal controls for operators.

Prohibits advertising targeting problem gamblers or individuals ineligible to wager, and restricts broadcast times and content. 

Enforces restrictions to maintain contest integrity and prevent betting on certain events and by prohibited individuals.

Official name: American Medical Innovation and Investment Act of 2024 (Sec. 5)
Casual name: American Medical Innovation and Investment Act of 2024 (Sec. 5)
Short summary: Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue guidance by January 1, 2026, on Medicare payment requirements for remote monitoring devices with AI components that transmit data to healthcare providers for patient management and treatment.
Long summary:
Mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue guidance on Medicare payment requirements for remote monitoring devices with AI components by January 1, 2026. 

Specifies that the devices, including continuous glucose monitors, must use AI components like continuous adjustment. 

Requires that these devices transmit information to healthcare providers for management and treatment purposes.

Official name: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 201
Casual name: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 201
Short summary: Amends Medicare Advantage plans to ensure mental health and substance use benefits parity. Mandates standards-based necessity determination and NQTL analyses. Imposes penalties for non-compliance. Extends parity to drug plans. Directs regulation issuance within 18 months. Allocates $10 million for implementation.
Long summary:
Amends Medicare Advantage plans to require parity in mental health and substance use disorder benefits, ensuring financial and treatment limitations are no more restrictive than those for medical benefits.

Mandates MA organizations to determine medical necessity for mental health and substance use benefits based on generally accepted standards.

Requires MA organizations to conduct and submit comparative analyses of nonquantitative treatment limitations (NQTLs) for mental health and substance use disorder benefits.

Imposes penalties for failing to comply with the mental health parity requirements.

Extends parity provisions to prescription drug plans, ensuring consistent application across Medicare Advantage and prescription drug plans.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue implementing regulations within 18 months.

Sets the effective date for amendments to plan years beginning two years post-enactment, with $10 million allocated for implementation funding through the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.

Official name: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 203
Casual name: Better Mental Health Care for Americans Act, Sec. 203
Short summary: Amends the Social Security Act to require behavioral health information disclosure, including provider access, wait times, payment statistics, and denial data. Specifies AI and technology use in denial processes. Aims to enhance transparency and informed choice in behavioral health coverage.
Long summary:
Amends Section 1851(d)(4) of the Social Security Act to include provisions for behavioral health information starting in 2025.

Requires the provision of information on access to in-network behavioral health providers, including average wait times for new patient appointments and data on provider participation agreements.

Mandates disclosure of payment request statistics for mental health or substance use disorder services, specifying the percentage handled by in-network versus out-of-network providers.

Requires reporting on the number and percentage of denials for prior authorization or payment for mental health services compared to non-mental health services, categorized by denial type and service type.

Specifies the use of decision support, AI, machine learning, clinical decision-making, or other technologies in denial processes, with comparisons to similar physical health conditions.

Aims to promote informed choice by enhancing transparency in behavioral health service coverage.

Official name: Microsoft Responsible AI Standard, v2
Casual name: Microsoft Responsible AI Standard, v2
Short summary: Establishes Microsoft's Responsible AI Standard, requiring AI systems to undergo impact assessments, oversight for adverse impacts, and fit-for-purpose validation. Mandates data governance, human oversight, system intelligibility, fairness, reliability, ongoing monitoring, and compliance with privacy, security, and accessibility standards.
Long summary:
Mandates Microsoft to conduct Impact Assessments for AI systems early in development to evaluate societal impacts, requiring annual updates and reviews for significant adverse impacts.

Requires identifying and overseeing AI systems with potential adverse effects, alongside applying additional oversight for Sensitive and Restricted Uses.

Ensures AI systems are fit for purpose, with detailed documentation and ongoing evaluation of performance metrics and error types.

Imposes data governance, requiring documentation of data requirements and processes, and evaluation of datasets for inclusivity.

Demands human oversight capabilities, identifying stakeholders responsible for system control and providing necessary tools and documentation.

Requires systems to be intelligible for decision-making, supporting stakeholders' understanding of system outputs and discouraging automation bias.

Mandates transparency and communication about system capabilities, limitations, and any AI-generated content.

Ensures fairness, focusing on quality of service and opportunities, minimizing disparities for demographic groups in AI system outputs. 

Emphasizes reliability and safety, requiring evaluation for safe performance within operational ranges, and ongoing monitoring and feedback. 

Insists on compliance with Microsoft’s Privacy, Security, and Accessibility Standards to ensure inclusive, secure, and private AI system design.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 504 ("National security procedures to address certain risks and threats relating to artificial intelligence")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 504 ("National security procedures to address certain risks and threats relating to artificial intelligence")
Short summary: Requires the President to develop procedures for notifying the government of AI-related security risks. Mandates government threat briefings to AI vendors. Obligates a briefing to Congress on agency responsibilities, industry outreach, and public education plans regarding AI risks.
Long summary:
Mandates the President to develop procedures within 180 days to enable vendors, users, and researchers to notify the U.S. Government of AI-related security and biosecurity risks, including malicious software development, system compromise, and foreign malign influence.

Requires federal elements to provide threat briefings to AI vendors about foreign exploitation and threats.

Obligates the President to brief Congress on the procedures, specifying responsible federal agencies and outlining industry outreach and public education plans.

Utilizes existing laws and federal guidelines for research, stakeholder engagement, and risk management frameworks related to AI systems.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 505 ("Establishment of Artificial Intelligence Security Center")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 505 ("Establishment of Artificial Intelligence Security Center")
Short summary: Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within the NSA. Provides a research test bed, develops counter-AI guidance, promotes secure AI adoption, and coordinates with NIST. Ensures access to proprietary models for qualified researchers and sets usage terms.
Long summary:
Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Security Center within the National Security Agency's Cybersecurity Collaboration Center.

Requires the provision of a research test bed for AI security research to private sector and academic researchers, including secure access to proprietary third-party models with vendor consent.

Develops guidance to prevent or mitigate counter-artificial intelligence techniques.

Promotes secure AI adoption practices for national security systems and the defense industrial base.

Coordinates with the Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute of the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Mandates terms of usage for researcher access to the test bed, ensuring limited publication to protect classified or proprietary information.

Ensures test bed availability to federal agencies on a cost-recovery basis.

Leverages existing infrastructure and resources for AI security research.

Establishes mechanisms, including contractual incentives, for providing access to proprietary models for qualified researchers.

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025, Title V, Section 510 ("Management of artificial intelligence security risks")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act FY 2025, Title V, Section 510 ("Management of artificial intelligence security risks")
Short summary: Requires the National Institute of Standards and Technology to update vulnerability management processes for AI security risks. Establishes a voluntary database to track AI security and safety incidents. Evaluates standards for AI vulnerability reporting. Encourages best practices for AI supply chain risks.
Long summary:
Mandates the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to update the National Vulnerability Database to incorporate AI security vulnerabilities within 180 days.

Requires the development of a voluntary database to track AI security and safety incidents, ensuring confidentiality and standardized reporting formats.

Instructs the Director to evaluate AI incidents for potential inclusion in the database, prioritizing critical infrastructure and high-impact cases.

Directs the Director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to update the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures Program to address AI security vulnerabilities.

Initiates a multi-stakeholder evaluation of consensus standards for AI vulnerability reporting, with a report due to Congress within 180 days.

Requires collaboration to develop best practices for managing AI supply chain risks, focusing on data collection, documentation, and the use of open-source and proprietary datasets.

Official name: American Competitiveness Of a More Productive Emerging Tech Economy Act
Casual name: American COMPETE Act
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Commerce and the Federal Trade Commission to complete studies on the AI industry and supply chain, assess risks of exploitation and online harms, and provide recommendations on AI adoption.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Commerce and the Federal Trade Commission to conduct a study on the state of the AI industry and its impact on the US economy.

Directs the Secretary and the Commission to conduct a survey of the AI market and supply chain, identify risks of exploitation by third parties, and provide recommendations to reduce bias, and protect privacy and security in AI applications.

Requires the Commission to conduct a study on how AI can be used to address online harms, including harmful content, disinformation, and crime.

Official name: Artificial Intelligence Training for the Acquisition Workforce Act
Casual name: AI Training Act
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish an AI training program for the acquisition workforce.
Long summary:
Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish an artificial intelligence training program for the acquisition workforce to garner knowledge of the capabilities and risks associated with AI.

Requires the program to include information relating to AI risks mitigation and the identification of  reliable, safe, and trustworthy AI.

Requires the program to include information relating to future trends in AI, including trends for homeland and national security and innovation.
           
Requires the Director of the AI program to develop an interactive learning portfolio with technologists, scholars and experts from private, public and non profit sectors.

Requires the Director of the AI program to develop an evaluation system to track participation and improve the program

Official name: An act to amend Chapter 12 of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, relating to the control of hazardous conditions, preventable diseases, and metabolic disorders [...]
Casual name: Georgia House Bill 203 (2023)
Collections: U.S. state and local laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Regulates the use of artificial intelligence and other technology in eye assessments for medical purposes, including by requiring medical professionals to analyze any data collected or generated by automated systems.
Long summary:
Requires all eye assessments that utilize artificial intelligence or other advanced technology to conform to the traditional standards of in-person care.

Requires a medical professional to analyze any information collected or generated by an automated system during the eye assessment process.

Requires all eye assessments to involve the collection of a patient's relevant medical information, which must be stored in a medical record for at least 7 years.

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021
Casual name: FY2021 NDAA
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies;NDAA provisions

Official name: William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021, Division E ("National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act")
Casual name: National AI Initiative Act
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Requires the President to establish a National Artificial Intelligence Initiative to support AI-related research, education, workforce development, planning, and international cooperation; creates new AI-related research and funding programs within several federal agencies.
Long summary:
Requires the President to establish a National Artificial Intelligence Initiative to support AI-related research, education, workforce development, planning, and international cooperation. 

Requires the creation of an office, interagency coordinating committee, external advisory committee, and a task force for a potential National AI Research Resource. Directs the interagency committee to create and periodically update a strategic plan for artificial intelligence.

Requires a National Academies study of the impact of AI on the workforce.

Directs the Director of the National Science Foundation to fund new AI research institutes as well as various activities related to AI research, education, engineering, and ethics.

Amends the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to give NIST various duties and powers related to AI and data.

Directs the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to establish a Center for Artificial Intelligence.

Directs the Secretary of Energy to carry out an AI research and development program on topics including AI for science and trustworthy AI.

Official name: Countering Human Trafficking Act of 2021, Section 4 ("Specialized Initiatives")
Casual name: Countering Human Trafficking Act of 2021, Section 4
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Establishes a specialized initiative (under section 4) in conjuction with the Science and Technology Directorate Office of Science and Engineering to modify systems and processes towards countering human trafficking.
Long summary:
Establishes a department of Homeland security center for countering human trafficking.

Establishes (under section 4), a specialized initiative in conjuction with the Science and Technology Directorate Office of Science and Engineering to modify systems and processes towards countering human trafficking. 

Instructs the CCHT Director, in conjunction with the Science and Technology Directorate Office of Science and Engineering to apply analytics to automate manual processes.

Instructs the CCHT Director, in conjunction with the Science and Technology Directorate Office of Science and Engineering to provide artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques towards increasing system capabilities and enhancing data availability,  reliability, comparability, and verifiability.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Governance development;Applications: Security

Official name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 834 ("Plan for Artificial Intelligence Digital Ecosystem")
Casual name: Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022, Section 834 ("Plan for Artificial Intelligence Digital Ecosystem")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan with other heads of the intelligence community regarding the development of a modern digital ecosystem for artificial intelligence; details the minimum requirements of the plan.
Long summary:
Instructs the Director of National Intelligence to develop a plan with other heads of the intelligence community for a modern digital ecosystem that enables the development and progress of artificial intelligence applications and present it to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act.

Requires that the plan include policies to allow flexible access to classified facilities to select companies, establishes a system to allow for investments into the ecosystem that would address technical issues including but not limited to common interfaces, authentication, and software, and includes policies to prevent duplication of AI capabilities within the intelligence community.

Requires that the plan establish a governance structure to standardize implementation throughout the intelligence community and adheres to community and federal standards.
Tags: Risk factors: Transparency;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Government: military and public safety

Official name: Health Extenders, Improving Access to Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP, and Strengthening Public Health Act of 2022, Section 1432 ("Research on the Health and Development Effects of Media and Related Technology on Infants, Children, and Adolescents")
Casual name: Health Extenders, Improving Access to Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP, and Strengthening Public Health Act of 2022, Section 1432 ("Research on the Health and Development Effects of Media and Related Technology on Minors")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to investigate the health and developmental effects of media and technology use, including artificial intelligence, on infants, children, and adolescents.
Long summary:
Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to produce a report about the effects of media and technology use on the cognitive development, physical health, and mental health of infants, children, and adolescents.

Authorizes the Secretary to provide financial support to research agendas and programs on the same issues.

Instructs the Secretary to submit the aforementioned report, including grants and research funded under this act, to Congress no later than two years after the passage of this legislation.

Official name: Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2023, Section 101 ("Manufacturing.gov Hub")
Casual name: Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2023, Section 101 ("Manufacturing.gov Hub")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Instructs the Secretary of Commerce to use machine learning within the establishment of the manufacturing.gov hub.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of Commerce in coordination with the Information Officer of the Department of Commerce to modify the manufacturing.gov website to include a section called the manufacturing.gov hub. 

Instructs the Secretary of Commerce to use machine learning in this hub to identify frequently asked questions and disseminate the answers to these questions to the public.

Official name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Section 40210 ("Critical Minerals Mining and Recycling Research")
Casual name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Section 40210 ("Critical Minerals Mining and Recycling Research")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Authorizes the use of funds for the advancement and development of artficial intelligence and machine learning.
Long summary:
Authorizes the use of funds towards examining the application of artificial intelligence for geological exploration of critical minerals, including what size and diversity of data sets would be require

Authorizes the use of funds towards examining the application of machine learning for detection and sorting of critical minerals, including what size and diversity of data sets would be required.

Authorizes the advancement and development of reserach in AI and machine learning.

Addresses government support for AI-related research and development activities.

Official name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Section 40433 ("Digital Climate Solutions Report")
Casual name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Section 40433 ("Digital Climate Solutions Report")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Directs the Secretary of Energy to produce a report that assesses the usage of digital climate tools.
Long summary:
Defines digital climate solutions as those that use artificial intelligence, blockchain technologies, and the Internet of Things. 

Directs the Secretary of Energy to create a report that contains a full inventory of digital climate solutions, an analysis of how the private sector can use the digital climate solutions, and a summary of opportunities to enhance the standardization of regulatory climate protocols.
Tags: Strategies: Evaluation;Strategies: Evaluation: Impact assessment;Strategies: Government study or report;Applications: Energy and utilities

Official name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Title V, Subtitle C, Part II ("Smart Manufacturing")
Casual name: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Title V, Subtitle C, Part II ("Smart Manufacturing")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Facilitates access to high-performance computing resources at the National Laboratories for small and medium manufacturers; provides funding for the establishment of programs that accelerate the implementation of smart manufacturing technologies.
Long summary:
Defines "smart manufacturing" as advanced technologies in artificial intelligence, computation, and modeling that streamline manufacturing production lines.

Directs the Secretary of Energy the conduct a study on how to increase access to the computing facilities of the National Laboratories for small and medium manufacturers.

Instructs the Secretary to make the National Laboratories' high-performance computing resources available to small and medium manufacturers to increase their manufacturing competitiveness.

Authorizes the Secretary to distribute financial assistance to programs that support the  implementation of smart manufacturing technologies, based on technical merit and research record.

Requires the Secretary to submit an annual report to Congress about the status of smart manufacturing in the United States.
Tags: Strategies: Government study or report;Strategies: Government support;Strategies: Government support: For R&D;Applications: Manufacturing and process automation

Official name: AI in Government Act of 2020
Casual name: AI in Government Act of 2020
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Creates the AI Centre for Excellence( AI CoE) and establishes a Director to manage the affairs of the CoE. Stipulates the functions of the CoE program and establishes collaboration with other departments within the government. Mitigates biases stemming from the use of AI.
Long summary:
Defines Artificial Intelligence

Creates a program called ‘‘AI Center of Excellence’’, (CoE) which shall facilitate the adoption of AI technologies in the Federal Government and improve cohesion in the adoption of artificial intelligence.

Stipulates certain functions of this program which includes; 
a.  Collaborating with individual agencies, federal laboratories, nonprofit organizations, institutions and other entities to discuss recent developments in AI.

b. Assisting agencies in applying Federal policies on the management and use of data in the use of AI.

c. Consulting with agencies, including the Department of Defense, the Department of Commerce, the Department of Energy, the Department of Homeland Security, the Office of Management and Budget, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the National Science Foundation, on issues relating to AI.

Identifies the skills needed for future job positions within the CoE and establishes jobs within the CoE and their duration (2 and 5 years).

Instructs the Director of the CoE to submit a comprehensive plan to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and the Committee on Oversight and Reform with a timeline to achieve paragraphs a,b,c,d within 120 days of the date of the enactment of the instrument.

Instructs the Director of the AI CoE to recommend approaches to remove barriers for use by agencies of AI technologies in order to promote their innovative application while protecting civil rights, and economic and national security; identify best practices for assessing and mitigating any discriminatory impact or bias on the basis of any classification protected under Federal nondiscrimination laws, or any unintended consequence of the use of AI.

Official name: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title I ("Department of Energy Science for the Future")
Casual name: Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act, Title I ("Department of Energy Science for the Future")
Collections: U.S. federal laws;Enacted laws and policies
Short summary: Initiates several projects using artificial intelligence and emerging technologies, all directives emphasizing support for artificial intelligence and data science development, establishing technical standards, and creating testbeds for robust systems. Efforts on scholarships, fellowships, and ongoing research to nurture the next generation of artificial intelligence professionals and enhance biometric identification technologies.
Long summary:
Instructs the Secretary of the Advanced Computing Program to maintain foundational research programs in mathematical and computational sciences, including new and emerging computing needs within the mission of the Department like novel approaches to modelling and simulation, artificial intelligence, and machine learning.

Instructs the Secretary to issue and ensure adherence to guidance for the Department, the National Laboratories, and users. This guidance pertains to how high-performance computing systems, including machine learning algorithms for data analysis and artificial intelligence, should be employed. 

Instructed the Director to prioritize research and development of sustainable chemistry, autonomous chemistry, and materials synthesis, leveraging  advances in artificial intelligence.

Instructs the Director to carry out research and testing to improve the effectiveness of artificial intelligence-enabled cybersecurity. 

Instructs the Director to support the development of artificial intelligence and data science. 

Instructs the Director to support the development of technical standards and guidelines- creating a framework for managing risks associated with artificial intelligence systems. 

Instructs the Director to establish testbeds to support the development of robust and trustworthy artificial intelligence and machine learning systems. These testbeds will examine the vulnerabilities and conditions that may lead to failure, malfunction, or attacks on such systems.

Instructs the Director to establish a report on the need, feasibility, and plans to implement a program to recruit and train the next generation of artificial intelligence professionals. This program is meant to meet the needs of Federal, State, local, and Tribal governments.

Provides scholarships through qualified institutions of higher education to students enrolled in programs related to artificial intelligence. Provides fellowships to masters and doctoral students pursuing degrees or research in artificial intelligence and related fields.

Necessitates research and testing to improve the accuracy, efficacy, and bias of biometric identification technologies.
